Relatively rare in this condition
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (â†º, 09h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R Material: Gold
Year: 1262 (AH 661 on the coin) Fineness: 958
Country: MamlÅ«k Sultanate Weight (g): Measured: 7.4; Expected: -
Issuer: MamlÅ«k Sultanate Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Measured: 24; Expected: -
Unit: Dinar Thickness (mm): -
Mint: al-QÄhirah (Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø§Ù‡Ø±Ø©) Mintage:
Mint mark: Ø§Ù„Ù‚Ø§Ù‡Ø±Ø© Emission period: AH 658-676
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: MS62 (NGC) Variety: None
References: Balog#36; Album#880; Fr#5; ICV1#959
Varieties:

None
Note:

The early centre of the FÄá¹­imid Caliphate, which controlled, at various times, much of the Islamic world from Morocco to Syria, was situated in that part of North Africa which had been ruled by the Aghlabid Emirate (800-909). Therefore, it was natural that the earliest Fatimid coinage resembled that of the Aghlabids in style, fabric and appearance. Only the date, mint and inscriptions differentiated the coins of the FÄá¹­imids from the issues of their predecessors. It is likely that Aghlabid and FÄá¹­imid coins circulated together during the first decades of the new regime in IfriqÄ«yah and Sicily, that is, until enough of the older coinage had been melted and reminted in the FÄá¹­imid model that the latter would predominate in circulation.

The coinage issues of individual caliphs are surprisingly quite varied and distinctively different given that the FÄá¹­imid Caliphate's rule lasted for 260-odd years. The coins of the FÄá¹­imids fall into two main categories: the gold dinar and its fractions and the silver dirham and its fractions and multiples. Within these two categories, the dinar itself and the half dirham are the two denominations that have survived to the present day in rather large quantities. Some denominations were peculiar to certain geographical areas, whereas others were common to all parts of the FÄá¹­imid realm. The dinar was the standard gold coin in use throughout the Fatimid Empire, except in Sicily, where the quarter dinar predominated. The half dirham, common throughout North Africa and Egypt, was almost unknown in Sicily, which had a variety of silver fractions in use throughout the island. The half dirham was also not common in Syria and Palestine, but full dirhams and even silver coins of approximately two dirhams weight are not unknown, although one hesitates to call the latter "double dirhams." Billon coinage was produced by a number of Palestinian mints and are known in a wide range of weights, but were probably all generically called dishams. The silver issues of the later FÄá¹­imid caliphs, almost exclusively struck in Egypt were the small, irregularly-shaped black dirhams, the production of which was continued by the AyyÅ«bid Sultanate of Egypt (1171-1260). A very few copper or bronze coins have been encountered. Some of these exhibit traces of a silver wash, which indicated that they were not considered to be copper coins as such, but rather small change in the dirham series.

FÄá¹­imid coinage, and particularly gold coinage, played an important part in the economy of North Africa and the Middle East during the period of the FÄá¹­imid Caliphate. Indeed, the FÄá¹­imid dinar had a wider impact throughout the Mediterranean world because of the reputation the regime's coinage carried with it far beyond the borders of the empire. FÄá¹­imid gold coins were struck to a high standard of fineness and this standard was generally maintained during most of the time the FÄá¹­imid Caliphate was in power. In the Syrian and Palestinian territories, the dinar was frequently struck to a lighter standard, especially in the later years of the FÄá¹­imid Caliphate.
Historical notes:

al-áº’Ähir (li-I'zÄz DÄ«n AllÄh) (Ø§Ù„Ø¸Ø§Ù‡Ø± Ù„Ø¥Ø¹Ø²Ø§Ø² Ø¯ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡) (born on 10 RamadÄn AH 395 (20 June 1005); proclaimed caliph on 10 DhÅ« al-Hijjah AH 411 (27 March 1021); died on 15 Sha'bÄn AH 427 (13 June 1036))

(To the right) Photograph of the al-Azhar Mosque in Cairo, Egypt, taken by an anonym in 2018. The FÄá¹­imid Caliphate conquered Egypt and founded Cairo (al-QÄhira) in AH 358 (969). The mosque was established in AH 361 (972) and the capital of the FÄá¹­imid Caliphate moved from al-Maná¹£Å«rÄ«yah to Cairo in AH 362 (972-973).

Some time passed after the disappearance of his predecessor al-á¸¤Äkim on 27 ShawwÄl AH 411 (13 February 1021) before al-áº’Ähir was proclaimed caliph on 10 DhÅ« al-Hijjah AH 411 (27 March 1021). The FÄá¹­imid regime was fairly stable during the first few years of al-áº’Ähir's caliphate, but this situation did not last very long. By 414-415 AH (1024-1025), the wasteful extravagances of al-á¸¤Äkim's rule began to take a toll on the health of the empire. A financial crisis ensued in which the cash reserves of the treasury were depleted. The army remained unpaid for an overly long period, then riots in Cairo and the provinces broke out, al-áº’Ähir lost control of his government and a ruling clique came to be in charge in the capital. This was followed by first drought and then famine in Egypt during AH 415 (1024-1025).

Despite his political incompetence and a life given over to the pursuit of pleasure, al-áº’Ähir was able to weather the political storm and on 16 JumÄdÄ II AH 420 (2 July 1029), his heir, AbÅ« TamÄ«m Ma'add, who was destined to become the Caliph al-Mustaná¹£ir, was born.

Trouble did not long stay away from al-áº’Ähir, however. His military commanders exercised almost independent control and in AH 421 (1030), attacks by the army on the populace in North Africa diminished support for the caliph. A powerful earthquake caused massive destruction in Palestine and al-áº’Ähir spent massive sums to rebuild the walls of Jerusalem during the years AH 421-424 (1030-1033). Famine once again visited North Africa in AH 425 (1034) and in the midst of all these problems, al-áº’Ähir died some two years later, just under thirty-two years of age.

 -

+ AD 1252 - England - Penny - Henry III:

Open description in new window
Period: Middle Ages; Kingdom of England (927-1649); House of Plantagenet (1154-1399)
Ruler: Henry III (1216-1272)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Large round portrait of Henry III, surrounded by an inner beaded border, facing, with round eyes formed by a pellet in a circle, small crescents in field between and below hair curls (depicted by pellet-in-crescent motifs), crowned with a large and well defined fleur as a central ornament atop the crown and pellets at crown ends, holding a sceptre in the right hand
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 10h) hE(ligature NR)ICVS REX III
Traduction: King Henry III
Designer: -

Director: Nicole (1247-circa 1270)

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Voided long cross pommÃ©e with a pellet at the centre and a trefoil in each quadrant, surrounded by an inner beaded border
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 07h, in each of the four quadrants) NIC (1st quadrant; first half of the director's name) oLE (2nd quadrant; second half of the director's name) (ligature oN)C (4th quadrant) (ligature aN)T (3rd quadrant)
Traduction: Nicole of Canterbury
Designer: -

Director: Nicole (1247-circa 1270)

Engraver: -
Features:

Total NGC (PCGS) Census: 47 (-)
NGC (PCGS) Census in this grade: 14 (-)
NGC (PCGS) Census in higher grade: 13 (-)
NGC (PCGS) Top Pop: 2 MS62, 1 MS61 (-)
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (â†º, 07h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: C Material: Silver
Year: 1252 (not dated) Fineness: 925
Country: England Weight (g): Measured: 1.37; Expected: 1.48
Issuer: England Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 18
Unit: Penny (1158-1970) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Canterbury Mintage:
Mint mark: ONC ANT Emission period: 1250-1272
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: AU55 (NGC) Variety: Class 5a2
References: S1#1367A; North1#991/2; CT#C232
Varieties:

There are two varieties, for which the letter X has either straight limbs (Class 5a2) or one straight limb and one S-shaped limb (Class 5a3).

This coin is classified as "Long Cross" type (1250-1279), Phase III (1250-1272, post-provincial phase), Class 5a2 (1251-circa 1253).
Note:

By the middle of Henry III's reign the "Short Cross" coinage in circulation was in a poor state and, in 1247, a new "Long Cross" coinage was ordered with the cross on the reverse being extended to the edge of the coin in an attempt to prevent clipping. The earliest coins (Class 1a) showed the name of neither the mint nor the moneyer. Class 1b includes the name of the mint. From Class 2 onwards all coins show the name of both the mint and the moneyer.

Following publication of the 1908 Brussels Hoard by Churchill and Thomas (2012) the classification of the "Long Cross" coinage was revised. This divided the "Long Cross" coinage into four phases: Phase I (1247, pre-provincial), Phase II (1248-1250, provincial, when sixteen provincial mints, in addition to the main mints of London and Canterbury plus Bury St Edmunds were opened to facilitate the production and distribution of the new coins), Phase III (1250-1272, post-provincial, in which the mint of Durham re-opened, operating intermittently), and Phase IV (1272-1280, posthumous, when the "Long Cross" coinage was continued in the name of Henry III through the first seven years of the reign of Edward I).

In Phases I and II the obverse features the Henry III's head without a sceptre (Classes 1-3) but during Phase III the sceptre was re-introduced (Class 4 onwards). No round hald-pennies ir farthings were struck during the "Long Cross" coinage but cut halves and quarters were used in considerable numbers.

Mint marks features in all coins from Class 1 to 4 and are an important aid to both chronology and identification. Five main varieties of mint mark exist, all in the shape of a star.
Historical notes:

Henry III (born on 1st Octobre 1207 in Winchester; accession on 28 Octobre 1216; died on 16 Novembre 1272)

(To the right) Illustration of the coronation of Henry III, accompanied by a short account of his reign in Anglo-Norman prose, from the recto of the parchment folio f.6 (referred to as f.6r) of the work "Cotton MS Vitellius A XIII", created circa 1280-circa 1300 and conserved at the British Library in London. It is part of a collection of four folios representing the kings of England from Edward the Confessor (r. 1042â€“1066) to Edward I (r. 1272â€“1307). These folios were extracted in 1939 from a manuscript that was damaged in the fire of Ashburnham House, which was the repository of the Cotton Library, on 23 October 1731, and are now mounted in separate glass frames. In this folio, Henri III is crowned by two accompanying bishops, He is represented as holding in his hand a model of Westminster Abbey, which he enlarged, laying the first stone himself; and caused to be there erected the magnificent monument of Edward the Confessor. It was very common with the illuminators, to make the principal figure holding a model of the abbey, or monastery, they were benefactors to. The author gives a rudimentary description of his reign: "Apres Jon regna Henry le Terz, sun fiz, Ivi aunz ; se fust de ix aunz de age quant fust corone. E en sun tens fust la bataylle de Eveshame, ou fust occys syr Syraund de Munfort, e sun fiz Henry ; e syre Hugh le Despenser, e muz des Barons e des Chevalers de Engletere â€“ Puis morust cyl Henry le Roy, e gyst a Westminster.", which can be translated in English as "After John, reigned Henry the Third, his son, 56 years; he was nine years of age when he was crowned. In his time was the battle of Evesham, where was slain Sir Simon de Mountfort, and his son Henry; and Sir Hugh le Despenser, and many barons and knights of England. â€“ After died this Henry the king, and lies [buried] at Westminster.â€

Henry III, King John's son, was only nine when he became king. By 1227, when he assumed power from his regent, order had been restored, based on his acceptance of Magna Carta. However, the king's failed campaigns in France (1230 and 1242), his choice of friends and advisers, together with the cost of his scheme to make one of his younger sons, Edmund, King of Sicily and help the Pope against the Holy Roman Emperor, led to further disputes with the barons and united opposition in Church and State.

Although Henry was extravagant and his tax demands were resented, the king's accounts show a list of many charitable donations and payments for building works (including the rebuilding of Westminster Abbey which began in 1245).

The Provisions of Oxford (1258) and the Provisions of Westminster (1259) were attempts by the nobles to define common law in the spirit of Magna Carta, control appointments and set up an aristocratic council. Henry tried to defeat them by obtaining papal absolution from his oaths, and enlisting the help of King Louis IX (saint Louis) of France. Henry renounced the Provisions in 1262 and war broke out. The barons, under their leader, Simon de Montfort, were initially successful and even captured Henry. However, Henry escaped, joined forces with the lords of the Marches (on the Welsh border), and finally defeated and killed de Montfort at the Battle of Evesham in 1265. Royal authority was restored by the Statute of Marlborough (1267), in which the king also promised to uphold Magna Carta and some of the Provisions of Westminster.

Henry died in 1272 and his tomb is in Westminster Abbey, in front of the Church's High Altar, the former resting place of Edward the Confessor, who his son Edward I was named after.

+ AD 1178 - Royaume de France - Denier - Chapitre ou Ã‰vÃªchÃ© de Clermont (Anonyme):

Open description in new window
Period: Moyen Ã‚ge ; Royaume de France (987-1792) ; Maison de Capet (987-1328)

Type: Regular issue

Script: Latin

Traduction: Urbs Arverna (Ville de Clermont)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Croix pattÃ©e Ã  bras rectilignes, entourÃ©e d'un grÃ¨netis intÃ©rieur, le champ entourÃ© d'un grÃ¨netis extÃ©rieur
Script: Latin
Lettering: (entre les grÃ¨netis intÃ©rieur et extÃ©rieur) âœ S(ligature ct)aÂ·Maria
Traduction: Sancta Maria (Sainte Marie)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin was sent to NGC for grading. Despite some minor environmental damage in the form of a few spots of green residue on the surface of both the obverse and reverse, the grade that I expected it would receive was XF45. The grade that it received was AU55, which exceeded my expectation. The emission period attributed by NGC to this coin type is 1200-1300 instead of 1030-1099. I have not found the reference(s) that NGC may have used to make this attribution. To reflect the uncertainty in the emission period, I have assigned the year 1178 to this coin type.

Cette piÃ¨ce me fait penser Ã  la pÃ©riode oÃ¹ j'habitais rue du Port Ã  Clermont-Ferrand, laquelle fut une des plus riches de ma vie. ğŸ¦“
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (â†º, 08h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R2 Material: Silver
Year: 1178 (not dated) Fineness: 500
Country: Royaume de France Weight (g): Measured: 1.06; Expected: 1.17
Issuer: Chapitre ou Ã‰vÃªchÃ© de Clermont Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 20.5
Unit: Denier tournois (987-1795) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Clermont-Ferrand Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 1030-1099
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: AU55 (NGC) Variety: Sans cantonnement
References: PA1#2241; DyFeo1#825; Boudeau#377; Roberts#4158
Varieties:

Il existe plusieurs variÃ©tÃ©s: de grand module, sans ponctuation Ã  l'avers et au revers, avec la croix au revers sans cantonnement (DyFeo1#824), et de module de taille normale, avec ponctuation Ã  l'avers et avec (DyFeo1#825 et DyFeo1#828) ou sans (DyFeo1#826 et DyFeo1#827) ponctuation au revers, avec la croix au revers sans cantonnement (DyFeo1#825) ou cantonnÃ©e d'un V au 1er canton et (DyFeo1#826), d'un V aux 2Ã¨me et 3Ã¨me cantons (DyFeo1#827) et d'un besant divergeant du centre aux 1er et 4Ã¨me cantons (DyFeo1#828). Cette derniÃ¨re variÃ©tÃ© (DyFeo1#828) a Ã©galement les lettres R et B du motif en forme de croix au centre de l'avers inversÃ©es.
Note:

Le comtÃ© d'Auvergne, fief du duchÃ© d'Aquitaine, entre dans la maison de Toulouse en 928, puis dans celle de Poitiers en 950. Mais la maison de Poitiers ne le garda pas longtemps. En effet, Guillaume Taillefer, comte de Toulouse, en lutte avec cette derniÃ¨re, sâ€™empare du comtÃ© d'Auvergne Ã  la mort du comte de Poitiers (qui Ã©tait aussi comte d'Auvergne), Guillaume TÃªte d'Etoupe, en 963. En 979, il investit Guy Ier, vicomte de Clermont des comtÃ©s dâ€™Auvergne et de Velay. La vacance laissÃ©e par le dernier comte dâ€™Auvergne (Guillaume TÃªte d'Etoupe), a trÃ¨s probablement incitÃ© le vicomte Guy Ier Ã  se proclamer par la suite comte d'Auvergne. A partir de ce moment l'histoire de l'Auvergne se rÃ©sume dans une lutte obscure et continuelle dont la suzerainetÃ© de la province, que se disputent les ducs d'Aquitaine et les rois de France, est l'enjeu.

Bien avant la fin de la dynastie Carolingienne, les comtes d'Auvergne usurpÃ¨rent les droits rÃ©galiens et battirent monnaie. La frappe des deniers au monogramme carolingien a Ã©tÃ© quelque temps continuÃ©e par les comtes dâ€™Auvergne, mais ils nâ€™ont pas tardÃ© Ã  altÃ©rer le monogramme carolingien et Ã  substituer leur nom propre au nom royal. Cette pratique pris fin lorsque, en 1030, Guillaume V cÃ©da au chapitre de Notre-Dame de Clermont sa monnaie avec ses monnayeurs. Plus tard, le privilÃ¨ge devint commun entre le chapitre et l'Ã©vÃªque ; cependant, des textes ultÃ©rieurs prouvent que le comte avait gardÃ© une certaine suprÃ©matie sur la monnaie de Clermont et peut-Ãªtre une part des profits.

Le chapitre ou les Ã©vÃªques de Clermont ne paraissent pas avoir eu un monnayage antÃ©rieur. Le premier type, avec les lettres V, R, B et S disposÃ©es en forme de croix, est du XIÃ¨me siÃ¨cle et, au lieu de Claromont, on reprend la lÃ©gende Urbs Arverna. D'oÃ¹ vient le type adoptÃ© par le chapitre de Clermont ? A-t-il voulu copier, en le dÃ©figurant, le monogramme carolingien ? C'est ce qu'il est difficile d'Ã©tablir, en l'absence des monnaies intermÃ©diaires. Peut-Ãªtre aussi, pour ce monnayage tout nouveau, a-t-on crÃ©Ã© un nouveau type. Au XIIÃ¨me siÃ¨cle, nous trouvons un changement radical dans le type des monnaies sur lesquelles nous voyons paraitre la tÃªte de face de la Vierge. L'influence des Ã©vÃªques dut Ãªtre fort probablement la cause de ce changement de type.

En 1269, l'Ã©vÃªque avait Ã©mis une monnaie plus faible de 1/5 que l'ancienne ; sur la plainte d'Alphonse de Poitiers, son frÃ¨re Louis IX (saint Louis) intervint. En 1295, Philippe IV le Bel dÃ©livre Ã  l'Ã©vÃªque et au chapitre une lettre de non-prÃ©judice Ã  l'occasion du monnayage royal de Montferrand. Le denier de Clermont est encore mentionnÃ© en 1315 (13 pour 12 denier tournois), mais c'Ã©tait la fin de la monnaie frappÃ©e Ã  Clermont, et plus gÃ©nÃ©ralement de la plupart des monnaies seigneuriales (laÃ¯ques et ecclÃ©siastiques). Cependant, jusqu'en 1360, l'Ã©vÃªque, en prenant possession de sa charge, prÃªtait serment auprÃ¨s du souverain de ne rien changer Ã  la monnaie. Celle-ci Ã©tait en rÃ©alitÃ© devenue thÃ©orique.
Historical notes:

(To the right) Clocher de la Basilique Notre-Dame-du-Port de Clermont-Ferrand, dessinÃ© par Charles-Justin Le CÅ“ur (1830-1906) entre 1868 et 1882

La basilique Notre-Dame-du-Port de Clermont-Ferrand est une Ã©glise collÃ©giale franÃ§aise de style roman auvergnat, situÃ©e dans le centre historique de Clermont-Ferrand, au cÅ“ur du quartier du Port, entre la place Delille et la cathÃ©drale Notre-Dame de lâ€™Assomption de Clermont. ClassÃ©e monument historique de France sur la premiÃ¨re liste de 1840, elle a Ã©tÃ© inscrite en 1998 sur la Â« Liste du patrimoine mondiale Â» de l'United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) au titre des Â« Chemins de Saint-Jacques-de-Compostelle en France Â». Sa dÃ©nomination proviendrait du nom du quartier oÃ¹ elle a Ã©tÃ© construite, Â« le Port Â», en occitan Â« Lo PÃ²rt Â», dÃ©rivant lui-mÃªme du latin "portus", et qui signifient tous deux Â« l'entrepÃ´t Â». C'Ã©tait l'endroit oÃ¹ l'on apportait et stockait les marchandises. En auvergnat, on disait NÃ²stra-Dama dÃ³u-PÃ²rt. Dans les parlers plus mÃ©ridionaux se trouve la forme NÃ²stra DÃ²na del PÃ²rt. L'ancienne Porte Royale qui se situait en bas de l'actuelle rue du Port, Ã©tait le lieu par lequel arrivaient les marchandises dans la ville, ce qui confirme le rÃ´le de passage et d'Ã©change de l'endroit. NÃ©anmoins, Â« le Port Â» n'est pas attestÃ© dans les Ã©crits anciens avant 1065. L'Ã©glise a d'abord portÃ© le nom de Â« Sainte-Marie Principale Â», ce qui la distinguait de la cathÃ©drale nommÃ©e Â« Sainte-Marie Â» et de l'abbaye de Saint-Alyre nommÃ©e Â« Sainte-Marie-d'Entre-Saints Â».

+ AD 1128 - India - Gajapati pagoda - Gangas of Talakad (Anonymous):

Open description in new window
Period:
Ruler: Romanos IV Diogenes (1068-1071)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: The three co-emperor stepsons of Romanos IV, all wearing a loros with a loros-waist and a crown with cross and pendilia, standing facing on a single dais represented as a dotted exergual band, the field surrounded by a double grÃ¨netis: in the centre, Michael, large, holding a labarum-headed sceptre in the right hand and an akakia in the left hand; to the left and the right, Konstantios and Andronikos, respectively, holding a globus cruciger in the outer hand and an akakia in the inner hand
Script: Greek
Lettering: (starting at 08h) KÑ N MX ANÎ”
Traduction: Konstantios, Michael and Andronikos
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: In the centre, Christ, large, nimbate, wearing a tunic and a himation, standing facing on a square footstool, crowing: to the left Romanos IV, wearing a loros, a sakkos, and a crown with cross and pendilia; to the right, Eudokia, wearing a loros, a kite-shaped panel, and a crown with pinnacles and pendilia; both standing facing, holding the outer hand on the breast and a globus cruciger in the inner hand and the inner hand on the breast; with divided inscription IÌ…CÌ… XÌ…CÌ… (Jesus Christ; partly abbreviated form of the Greek "á¾½Î™Î·ÏƒÎ¿Ï…Ì‘Ï‚ ÎÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„á½¸Ï‚"), across the field on the sides of Christ's head; the field surrounded by a double grÃ¨netis
Script: Greek
Lettering: +IÑ MA CVÎ”KIA
Traduction: Romanos and Eudokia
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin makes me think of my children LÃ©onie and Louis. ğŸ¦›ğŸ¦“
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (â†º, 06h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: C Material: Gold
Year: 1128 (not dated) Fineness: 667
Country: India Weight (g): Measured: 4.4; Expected: 4.55
Issuer: Gangas of Talakad Shape: Concave (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 27
Unit: Second Solidus Nomisma ("Reform" of Leo III; 720-1092) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: CÅnstantÄ«nopolis Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 1068-1071
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: MS61 (NGC) Variety: Without footstools
References: BCV#1861; DOC3_2#2; Fr#261
Varieties:

There are three varieties, for which the three co-emperor stepsons of Romanos IV are standing on footstools set on a single dais represented as a dotted exergual band (BCV#1860 and DOC3_2#2) or without the single dais (BCV#1859 and DOC3_2#1) or without the footstools (BCV#1861).
Note:

The twin pivots of the Byzantine monetary system in the 5th and 6th centuries had been the gold solidus or nomisma and the copper nummus. The gold solidus was a coin struck 72 to the Roman pound and consequently weighing, in Greco-Roman units, 24 siliquae or carats. The weight of the Roman pound is normally reckoned at 327.45 g, giving the solidus a theoretical weight in modern terms of 4.55 g. The nummus, sometimes called by contemporaries a denarius, was a small coin of varying weight, usually about 1 g or a little less. It has then been reckoned as 1/7200 of the solidus, but its value in fact varied and seems frequently to have fallen to a much lower figure. The gap between the solidus and the nummus was bridged in part by real coins (the gold semissis and tremissis, fractions of the solidus, and the copper pentanummium, decanummium, half follis, and follis, multiples of the nummus), in part by a money of account, the keration, and in part by the miliaresion, which was sometimes one and sometimes the other.

Treating them in descending order of value, the semissis and tremissis require no discussion. They were actual coins, worth one-half and one-third of a solidus, respectively. Miliaresion was a Greek loan word from the Latin "miliarense", a term applied to a silver coin current in the 4th century from the period of the Tetrarchy onward. In the 6th century, when no silver coinage was being struck for regular circulation in the East, it had become the generic name for any silver coin at all, being applied indifferently to the Roman denarius and to the Persian dirham. When the hexagram was created by the Byzantine emperor Heraclius (r. 610â€“641) this was known as the silver coin of six grammata, and when the hexagram ceased to be struck the term remained available for application to whatever silver coin would take its place.

The keration was not a coin, but primarily a unit of weight, 1/1728 of the Roman pound, 1/144 of the Roman ounce, or about 0.189 g in modern terms. Since the solidus was one-sixth of a Roman ounce, the solidus weighed 24 keratia. Consequently, as a money of account, the keration was 1/24 of the Roman solidus, a relationship that lasted throughout the whole of the Byzantine Empire's history. Keratia are omnipresent in Byzantine monetary reckonings, but they are always notional. A debt expressed in solidi, keratia, and fractions of keratia would be paid in solidi, miliaresia, folles, and such fractions of these as were in circulation at the time.

The follis, sometimes called the obol, reintroduced in 498 with the monetary reform of the Byzantine emperor Anastasius I Dicorus (r. 491-518), was a copper coin worth forty nummi. Various fractions were struck during the 6th and 7th centuries, the half follis, decanummium, and pentanummium being the most important. In the mid 6th century the follis was reckoned 180 to the solidus. How the relationships between the solidus, keration, follis and nummus were affected by the "debasement" of the follis in the later 6th and 7th centuries â€“ the gradual reduction of its weight to less than one-sixth of what it had been in the peak years of Justinian I's reign (527-565) â€“ is a question to which there is not yet any answer. The nummus disappeared completely as a coin, but since the follis and its fractions still bore marks of value expressed as multiples of nummi, these were presumably still thought of as the lowest units in the monetary system.

This monetary system was not as unified in the three and a half centuries between the accession of the Byzantine emperor Leo III (r. 717-741) in 717, marking the end of the "Twenty Years' Anarchy" (695-717), and the monetary reform of the Byzantine emperor Alexios I Komnenos (r. 1081-1118) in 1092, following his accession in 1081, marking the end of a prolonged period of civil war resulting from the defeat to the Seljuk Turks at Manzikert in 1071. The silver miliaresion introduced by Leo III in 720 and continued by his successors provided a certain element of unity nonetheless. The essential features of the monetary system during this period may be summarized as follows:

Gold coinage â€“ In the East, the semissis and tremissis ceased to be struck, save as ceremonial coins, toward the middle of the 8th century. Henceforward the only gold coin was the solidus. Its fineness remained virtually unchanged down to the 1030's, when debasement set in, and while its weight seems ot have declined very slightly the coin remained one theoretically struck 72 to the Roman pound. In the reign of Nikephoros II Phokas (r. 963-969), however, there began a series of experiments in light-weight nomismata comparable to the light-weight solidi of the 6th and 7th centuries. Of these the light-weight nomisma of 22 keratia, known as a tetarteron, finally gained the day, so that from the late 10th century down to Alexios I Komnenos' monetary reform of 1092 one has to distinguish between the full-weight nomisma histamenon and the light-weight nomisma tetarteron.

Things went differently in the West. The solidus and tremissis continued to be struck in mainland Italy as long as the mints of Ravenna and Rome remained in Byzantine hands, i.e., to the mid and late 8th century, respectively. In Sicily they continued down to the reign of Basil I (r. 867-886), and there was even a revival of the use of the semissis in the early 9th century. The weight standard of the western gold coins, however, was substantially less than that of their eastern counterparts, and both on the mainland and in Sicily there was a serious reduction in fineness during the last decades of Byzantine rule. The fate of the fractional gold was related inversely to the presence or absence of a silver coinage, since the miliaresion flourished in the East but was not adopted in the West.

Silver coinage â€“ The history of the silver coinage is that of a new miliaresion, a coin much lighter than the hexagram of the 7th century, which was introduced by Leo III in 720. It lasted, with remarkably few changes in external appearance, down to Alexios I Komnenos' monetary reform of 1092. The weight, however, was several times altered, and in its final phase it was badly debased in both weight and fineness. Fractions were struck only under Leo III, of whose half miliaresion specimens are known, and in the middle of the 11th century. Over much of the period the miliaresion was valued as a double keration, i.e., as a coin worth 1/12 of a solidus, so that sums of money are as commonly expressed in terms of nomismata and miliaresia as of nomismata and keratia. But when this ratio became fixed, or how the value of the actual coins changed, in relation to the debased nomisma, during the last decades of their existence, are not known exactly.

Copper Coinage â€“ The evolution of the copper resembled that of the gold in that both underwent a process of drastic simplification and differed from it in that the weight of the follis altered greatly over the centuries.
Historical notes:

Romanos IV (Diogenes) (born circa 1030; crown emperor on 1st January 1068; died in 1072)

(To the right) Photograph of the Grand Ã‡amlÄ±ca Mosque in Istanbul, Turkey, taken by an anonym in 2021. The landmark complex was completed in 2019. The mosque has six minarets, which represent the six articles of Islamic faith (iman). Four of the minarets, centred around the central dome, feature three balconies that stand 107.1-metre high in recognition of the victory of the Seljuk Turks at Manzikert in 1071. The other two minarets, on the outer ends of the mosque, feature two balconies and are 90-metre high.

The final act of Constantine X (Doukas) before he died in 1067 was to demand that only his two sons he had elevated to co-emperors, Michael and Konstantios, succeed him, thereby forcing his wife Eudokia (Makrembolitissa) to take a vow not to remarry. Michael was about 17-year old while Konstantios was about 7-year old at the time. Since they were too young to rule, Eudokia ruled as regent until 1st January 1068, when she married Romanos IV (Diogenes) and crowned him emperor. Romanos IV was now the senior emperor and guardian of his stepsons Michael, Konstantios, and Andronikos who he also elevated to co-emperor. However, his accession to the throne had antagonised not only the Doukas family, in particular Constantine X (Doukas)'s brother John Doukas who led the opposition of the palace officials to Romanos IV (Diogenes) authority, but also the Varangian Guard, who openly expressed their discontent at the marriage of Eudokia. Romanos IV (Diogenes) therefore decided that he could only exercise his authority by placing himself at the head of the army in the field, thereby focusing the whole government's attention on the war against the Seljuk Turks.

By 1067, the Seljuk Turks had been making incursions at will across the eastern border of the Byzantine Empire. In 1068, the new emperor immediately set about trying to defend Asia Minor against the advance of the Seljuk Turks. He was confident of Byzantine superiority on the field of battle, looking on the Seljuk Turks as little more than hordes of robbers who would melt away at the first encounter. He did not take into account the degraded state of the Byzantine army, which had suffered years of neglect from his predecessors, in particular Constantine X (Doukas). With an army composed mainly of ill-disciplined, disorganised, and uncoordinated foreign mercenaries he achieved some initial success, but at the famous battle of Mantzikert in 1071 the Seljuk Turks won a devastating victory and Romanus IV (Diogenes) himself was taken prisoner. The opposition party in Constantinople took the opportunity to depose the unfortunate emperor and re-establish Eudokia on the throne together with her eldest son Michael VII (Dukas).

 -

+ AD 1068 - Byzantine Empire - Histamenon nomisma - Romanos IV Diogenes:

Script: Greek

Engraver: -
Features:

Relatively rare in this condition
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (â†º, 06h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: C Material: Gold

Issuer: Byzantine Empire Shape: Concave (Irregular)

Unit: Second Solidus Nomisma ("Reform" of Leo III; 720-1092) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: CÅnstantÄ«nopolis Mintage:

Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients MS; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 4/5 (NGC) Variety: Without footstools
References: BCV#1861; DOC3_2#2; Fr#261
Varieties:

There are three varieties, for which the three co-emperor stepsons of Romanos IV are standing on footstools set on a single dais represented as a dotted exergual band (BCV#1860 and DOC3_2#2) or without the single dais (BCV#1859 and DOC3_2#1) or without the footstools (BCV#1861).
Note:

The twin pivots of the Byzantine monetary system in the 5th and 6th centuries had been the gold solidus or nomisma and the copper nummus. The gold solidus was a coin struck 72 to the Roman pound and consequently weighing, in Greco-Roman units, 24 siliquae or carats. The weight of the Roman pound is normally reckoned at 327.45 g, giving the solidus a theoretical weight in modern terms of 4.55 g. The nummus, sometimes called by contemporaries a denarius, was a small coin of varying weight, usually about 1 g or a little less. It has then been reckoned as 1/7200 of the solidus, but its value in fact varied and seems frequently to have fallen to a much lower figure. The gap between the solidus and the nummus was bridged in part by real coins (the gold semissis and tremissis, fractions of the solidus, and the copper pentanummium, decanummium, half follis, and follis, multiples of the nummus), in part by a money of account, the keration, and in part by the miliaresion, which was sometimes one and sometimes the other.

Treating them in descending order of value, the semissis and tremissis require no discussion. They were actual coins, worth one-half and one-third of a solidus, respectively. When the hexagram was created by the Byzantine emperor Heraclius (r. 610â€“641) this was known as the silver coin of six grammata, and when the hexagram ceased to be struck the term remained available for application to whatever silver coin would take its place.

The keration was not a coin, but primarily a unit of weight, 1/1728 of the Roman pound, 1/144 of the Roman ounce, or about 0.189 g in modern terms. A debt expressed in solidi, keratia, and fractions of keratia would be paid in solidi, miliaresia, folles, and such fractions of these as were in circulation at the time.

The follis, sometimes called the obol, reintroduced in 498 with the monetary reform of the Byzantine emperor Anastasius I Dicorus (r. 491-518), was a copper coin worth forty nummi. Various fractions were struck during the 6th and 7th centuries, the half follis, decanummium, and pentanummium being the most important. In the mid 6th century the follis was reckoned 180 to the solidus. How the relationships between the solidus, keration, follis and nummus were affected by the "debasement" of the follis in the later 6th and 7th centuries â€“ the gradual reduction of its weight to less than one-sixth of what it had been in the peak years of Justinian I's reign (527-565) â€“ is a question to which there is not yet any answer. The nummus disappeared completely as a coin, but since the follis and its fractions still bore marks of value expressed as multiples of nummi, these were presumably still thought of as the lowest units in the monetary system.

This monetary system was not as unified in the three and a half centuries between the accession of the Byzantine emperor Leo III (r. 717-741) in 717, marking the end of the "Twenty Years' Anarchy" (695-717), and the monetary reform of the Byzantine emperor Alexios I Komnenos (r. 1081-1118) in 1092, following his accession in 1081, marking the end of a prolonged period of civil war resulting from the defeat to the Seljuk Turks at Manzikert in 1071. The essential features of the monetary system during this period may be summarized as follows:

Its fineness remained virtually unchanged down to the 1030's, when debasement set in, and while its weight seems ot have declined very slightly the coin remained one theoretically struck 72 to the Roman pound. Of these the light-weight nomisma of 22 keratia, known as a tetarteron, finally gained the day, so that from the late 10th century down to Alexios I Komnenos' monetary reform of 1092 one has to distinguish between the full-weight nomisma histamenon and the light-weight nomisma tetarteron.

The fate of the fractional gold was related inversely to the presence or absence of a silver coinage, since the miliaresion flourished in the East but was not adopted in the West.

Silver coinage â€“ The history of the silver coinage is that of a new miliaresion, a coin much lighter than the hexagram of the 7th century, which was introduced by Leo III in 720. It lasted, with remarkably few changes in external appearance, down to Alexios I Komnenos' monetary reform of 1092. The weight, however, was several times altered, and in its final phase it was badly debased in both weight and fineness. Fractions were struck only under Leo III, of whose half miliaresion specimens are known, and in the middle of the 11th century. Over much of the period the miliaresion was valued as a double keration, i.e., as a coin worth 1/12 of a solidus, so that sums of money are as commonly expressed in terms of nomismata and miliaresia as of nomismata and keratia. But when this ratio became fixed, or how the value of the actual coins changed, in relation to the debased nomisma, during the last decades of their existence, are not known exactly.

Copper Coinage â€“ The evolution of the copper resembled that of the gold in that both underwent a process of drastic simplification and differed from it in that the weight of the follis altered greatly over the centuries.
Historical notes:

Romanos IV (Diogenes) (born circa 1030; crown emperor on 1st January 1068; died in 1072)

(To the right) Photograph of the Grand Ã‡amlÄ±ca Mosque in Istanbul, Turkey, taken by an anonym in 2021. The landmark complex was completed in 2019. The mosque has six minarets, which represent the six articles of Islamic faith (iman). Four of the minarets, centred around the central dome, feature three balconies that stand 107.1-metre high in recognition of the victory of the Seljuk Turks at Manzikert in 1071. The other two minarets, on the outer ends of the mosque, feature two balconies and are 90-metre high.

The final act of Constantine X (Doukas) before he died in 1067 was to demand that only his two sons he had elevated to co-emperors, Michael and Konstantios, succeed him, thereby forcing his wife Eudokia (Makrembolitissa) to take a vow not to remarry. Michael was about 17-year old while Konstantios was about 7-year old at the time. Since they were too young to rule, Eudokia ruled as regent until 1st January 1068, when she married Romanos IV (Diogenes) and crowned him emperor. Romanos IV was now the senior emperor and guardian of his stepsons Michael, Konstantios, and Andronikos who he also elevated to co-emperor. However, his accession to the throne had antagonised not only the Doukas family, in particular Constantine X (Doukas)'s brother John Doukas who led the opposition of the palace officials to Romanos IV (Diogenes) authority, but also the Varangian Guard, who openly expressed their discontent at the marriage of Eudokia. Romanos IV (Diogenes) therefore decided that he could only exercise his authority by placing himself at the head of the army in the field, thereby focusing the whole government's attention on the war against the Seljuk Turks.

By 1067, the Seljuk Turks had been making incursions at will across the eastern border of the Byzantine Empire. In 1068, the new emperor immediately set about trying to defend Asia Minor against the advance of the Seljuk Turks. He was confident of Byzantine superiority on the field of battle, looking on the Seljuk Turks as little more than hordes of robbers who would melt away at the first encounter. He did not take into account the degraded state of the Byzantine army, which had suffered years of neglect from his predecessors, in particular Constantine X (Doukas). With an army composed mainly of ill-disciplined, disorganised, and uncoordinated foreign mercenaries he achieved some initial success, but at the famous battle of Mantzikert in 1071 the Seljuk Turks won a devastating victory and Romanus IV (Diogenes) himself was taken prisoner. The opposition party in Constantinople took the opportunity to depose the unfortunate emperor and re-establish Eudokia on the throne together with her eldest son Michael VII (Dukas).

+ AD 1036 - FÄá¹­imid Caliphate - Â¼ Dinar - al-áº’Ähir li-I'zÄz DÄ«n AllÄh (Ø§Ù„Ø¸Ø§Ù‡Ø± Ù„Ø¥Ø¹Ø²Ø§Ø² Ø¯ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡):

Open description in new window
Period: Middle Ages; FÄá¹­imid Caliphate (909-1171); FÄá¹­imid dynasty (909-1171)
Ruler: al-áº’Ähir li-I'zÄz DÄ«n AllÄh (Ø§Ù„Ø¸Ø§Ù‡Ø± Ù„Ø¥Ø¹Ø²Ø§Ø² Ø¯ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡) (AH 411-427)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Two concentric circles with a single marginal incription on the outer circle and an inscription within the inner circle (Nicol "Type C1")
Script: Arabic
Lettering: (on the outer circle, starting at 01h) Ø¨Ø³Ù… Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø¶Ø±Ø¨ Ù‡Ø°Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ø¯ÛŒÙ†Ø§Ø± Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù†ØµÙˆØ±ÙŠØ© Ø³Ø¨Ø¹ Ùˆ Ø¹Ø´Ø±ÙˆÙ† Ùˆ Ø£Ø±Ø¨Ø¹Ù…Ø§Ø¦Ø© (within the inner circle) Ù„ØµØ¨Ø± Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø¤Ù…Ù†ÙŠÙ†/Ù„Ø¥Ø¹Ø²Ø§Ø² Ø¯ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡/Ø§Ù„Ø¸Ø§Ù‡Ø±
Traduction: (on the outer circle, starting at 01h) In the Name of God this Dinar was struck in al-Maná¹£Å«rÄ«yah in Seven and Twenty and Four Hundred (within the inner circle) He Who Appears Openly (al-áº’Ähir)/To Strengthen the Religion of God (li-I'zÄz DÄ«n AllÄh)/For the Patience of the Faithful (al-á¹£abr al-mu'minÄ«n)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Two concentric circles with a single marginal incription on the outer circle and an inscription within the inner circle (Nicol "Type C1")
Script: Arabic
Lettering: (on the outer circle, starting at 01h) Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ø±Ø³Ù„Ù‡ Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù‡Ø¯ÛŒ Ùˆ Ø¯ÛŒÙ† Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚ Ù„ÛŒØ¸Ù‡Ø±Ù‡ Ø¹Ù„ÛŒ Ø§Ù„Ø¯ÛŒÙ† Ú©Ù„Ù‡ Ùˆ Ù„Ùˆ Ú©Ø±Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø´Ø±Ú©ÙˆÙ† (within the inner circle) Ø¹Ù„Ù‰ ÙˆÙ„Ù‰ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡/Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø±Ø³ÙˆÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡/Ù„Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù‡ Ø§Ù„Ø§ Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡
Traduction: (on the outer circle, starting at 01h) Qur'Än IX:33 Muhammad is the Messenger of God Who has Sent Him with Guidance and the Religion of Truth that He May Make it Prevail over all Religion, even if the Polytheists are Averse (within the inner circle) There is No Deity but God/Muhammad is the Messenger of God/Ali is the Chosen Guardian of God
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This NGC-certified coin was described incorrectly on the certification label as: AH421. Siqilliya. It was sent to NGC for correction. The certification label was corrected.
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (â†º, 05h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R Material: Gold
Year: 1036 (AH 427 on the coin) Fineness: 958
Country: FÄá¹­imid Caliphate Weight (g): Measured: 0.89; Expected: 1.1
Issuer: FÄá¹­imid Caliphate Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: Â¼ Diameter (mm): Measured: 12; Expected: 11.4
Unit: Dinar Thickness (mm): -
Mint: al-Maná¹£Å«rÄ«yah (Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù†ØµÙˆØ±ÙŠØ©) Mintage:
Mint mark: Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù†ØµÙˆØ±ÙŠØ© Emission period: AH 411-427
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: MS64 (NGC) Variety: Nicol "Type C1" and without Ø³Ù†Ø©
References: Nicol#1573; Album#715; Fr#27; ICV1#836
Varieties:

The lettering on the outer circle on the observe is missing "Ø³Ù†Ø©" (literally "year") before the year (AH 427).

There is a large variety in the types and styles of the issues of individual caliphs. The earlier caliphs settled on one or two main types, but varieties made their appearance, especially from mints far from the capital. In the middle years of the FÄá¹­imid Caliphate, new types were introduced periodically, but there was often an overlap and several types might have been produced in the same mint in the same years. In Sicily, which seems to have been a world of its own, multiple types were struck, seemingly in a single mint, in any given year. This may mean that a single mint, perhaps that at Palemo, operated a number of workshops and the die makers of each workshop were able to create the dies in an independent manner, at least in deciding the design of the coin.
Note:

The early centre of the FÄá¹­imid Caliphate, which controlled, at various times, much of the Islamic world from Morocco to Syria, was situated in that part of North Africa which had been ruled by the Aghlabid Emirate (800-909). Therefore, it was natural that the earliest Fatimid coinage resembled that of the Aghlabids in style, fabric and appearance. Only the date, mint and inscriptions differentiated the coins of the FÄá¹­imids from the issues of their predecessors. It is likely that Aghlabid and FÄá¹­imid coins circulated together during the first decades of the new regime in IfriqÄ«yah and Sicily, that is, until enough of the older coinage had been melted and reminted in the FÄá¹­imid model that the latter would predominate in circulation.

The coinage issues of individual caliphs are surprisingly quite varied and distinctively different given that the FÄá¹­imid Caliphate's rule lasted for 260-odd years. The coins of the FÄá¹­imids fall into two main categories: the gold dinar and its fractions and the silver dirham and its fractions and multiples. Within these two categories, the dinar itself and the half dirham are the two denominations that have survived to the present day in rather large quantities. Some denominations were peculiar to certain geographical areas, whereas others were common to all parts of the FÄá¹­imid realm. The dinar was the standard gold coin in use throughout the Fatimid Empire, except in Sicily, where the quarter dinar predominated. The half dirham, common throughout North Africa and Egypt, was almost unknown in Sicily, which had a variety of silver fractions in use throughout the island. The half dirham was also not common in Syria and Palestine, but full dirhams and even silver coins of approximately two dirhams weight are not unknown, although one hesitates to call the latter "double dirhams." Billon coinage was produced by a number of Palestinian mints and are known in a wide range of weights, but were probably all generically called dishams. The silver issues of the later FÄá¹­imid caliphs, almost exclusively struck in Egypt were the small, irregularly-shaped black dirhams, the production of which was continued by the AyyÅ«bid Sultanate of Egypt (1171-1260). A very few copper or bronze coins have been encountered. Some of these exhibit traces of a silver wash, which indicated that they were not considered to be copper coins as such, but rather small change in the dirham series.

FÄá¹­imid coinage, and particularly gold coinage, played an important part in the economy of North Africa and the Middle East during the period of the FÄá¹­imid Caliphate. Indeed, the FÄá¹­imid dinar had a wider impact throughout the Mediterranean world because of the reputation the regime's coinage carried with it far beyond the borders of the empire. FÄá¹­imid gold coins were struck to a high standard of fineness and this standard was generally maintained during most of the time the FÄá¹­imid Caliphate was in power. In the Syrian and Palestinian territories, the dinar was frequently struck to a lighter standard, especially in the later years of the FÄá¹­imid Caliphate.
Historical notes:

al-áº’Ähir (li-I'zÄz DÄ«n AllÄh) (Ø§Ù„Ø¸Ø§Ù‡Ø± Ù„Ø¥Ø¹Ø²Ø§Ø² Ø¯ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡) (born on 10 RamadÄn AH 395 (20 June 1005); proclaimed caliph on 10 DhÅ« al-Hijjah AH 411 (27 March 1021); died on 15 Sha'bÄn AH 427 (13 June 1036))

(To the right) Photograph of the al-Azhar Mosque in Cairo, Egypt, taken by an anonym in 2018. The FÄá¹­imid Caliphate conquered Egypt and founded Cairo (al-QÄhira) in AH 358 (969). The mosque was established in AH 361 (972) and the capital of the FÄá¹­imid Caliphate moved from al-Maná¹£Å«rÄ«yah to Cairo in AH 362 (972-973).

Some time passed after the disappearance of his predecessor al-á¸¤Äkim on 27 ShawwÄl AH 411 (13 February 1021) before al-áº’Ähir was proclaimed caliph on 10 DhÅ« al-Hijjah AH 411 (27 March 1021). The FÄá¹­imid regime was fairly stable during the first few years of al-áº’Ähir's caliphate, but this situation did not last very long. By 414-415 AH (1024-1025), the wasteful extravagances of al-á¸¤Äkim's rule began to take a toll on the health of the empire. A financial crisis ensued in which the cash reserves of the treasury were depleted. The army remained unpaid for an overly long period, then riots in Cairo and the provinces broke out, al-áº’Ähir lost control of his government and a ruling clique came to be in charge in the capital. This was followed by first drought and then famine in Egypt during AH 415 (1024-1025).

Despite his political incompetence and a life given over to the pursuit of pleasure, al-áº’Ähir was able to weather the political storm and on 16 JumÄdÄ II AH 420 (2 July 1029), his heir, AbÅ« TamÄ«m Ma'add, who was destined to become the Caliph al-Mustaná¹£ir, was born.

Trouble did not long stay away from al-áº’Ähir, however. His military commanders exercised almost independent control and in AH 421 (1030), attacks by the army on the populace in North Africa diminished support for the caliph. A powerful earthquake caused massive destruction in Palestine and al-áº’Ähir spent massive sums to rebuild the walls of Jerusalem during the years AH 421-424 (1030-1033). Famine once again visited North Africa in AH 425 (1034) and in the midst of all these problems, al-áº’Ähir died some two years later, just under thirty-two years of age.

â†’ Ier millÃ©naire de l'Ã¨re Â« commune Â» de 0501 Ã  1000 :

Les seules monnaies authentiques du roi Hugues Capet actuellement connues sont les deniers et oboles de Beauvais et le denier de Laon. Historical notes:

Hugues Capet (naissance vers 939-941 probablement Ã  Dourdan ; avÃ¨nement le 3 juillet 987 ; mort le 24 octobre 996)

(To the right) Vue d'artiste de Hugues Capet, peinte par Charles Auguste, baron de Steuben (1788-1856) vers 1837. Cette Å“uvre fait partie d'une sÃ©rie de portraits, commandÃ©e par Louis-Philippe entre 1836 et 1838 afin d'enrichir les collections du MusÃ©e historique de Versailles.

Hugues Capet, comte de Paris et d'OrlÃ©ans, marquis de Neustrie et duc des Francs, Ã©lu roi par les grands du royaume, fut couronnÃ© Ã  Noyon le 3 juillet 987. + AD 0914 - AbbÄsid Caliphate - 1 Dinar - al-Muqtadir bi'LlÄh (Ø§Ù„Ù…Ù‚ØªØ¯Ø± Ø¨Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡):

Note:

The early centre of the FÄá¹­imid Caliphate, which controlled, at various times, much of the Islamic world from Morocco to Syria, was situated in that part of North Africa which had been ruled by the Aghlabid Emirate (800-909). Therefore, it was natural that the earliest Fatimid coinage resembled that of the Aghlabids in style, fabric and appearance. Only the date, mint and inscriptions differentiated the coins of the FÄá¹­imids from the issues of their predecessors. It is likely that Aghlabid and FÄá¹­imid coins circulated together during the first decades of the new regime in IfriqÄ«yah and Sicily, that is, until enough of the older coinage had been melted and reminted in the FÄá¹­imid model that the latter would predominate in circulation.

The coinage issues of individual caliphs are surprisingly quite varied and distinctively different given that the FÄá¹­imid Caliphate's rule lasted for 260-odd years. The coins of the FÄá¹­imids fall into two main categories: the gold dinar and its fractions and the silver dirham and its fractions and multiples. Within these two categories, the dinar itself and the half dirham are the two denominations that have survived to the present day in rather large quantities. Some denominations were peculiar to certain geographical areas, whereas others were common to all parts of the FÄá¹­imid realm. The dinar was the standard gold coin in use throughout the Fatimid Empire, except in Sicily, where the quarter dinar predominated. The half dirham, common throughout North Africa and Egypt, was almost unknown in Sicily, which had a variety of silver fractions in use throughout the island. The half dirham was also not common in Syria and Palestine, but full dirhams and even silver coins of approximately two dirhams weight are not unknown, although one hesitates to call the latter "double dirhams." Billon coinage was produced by a number of Palestinian mints and are known in a wide range of weights, but were probably all generically called dishams. The silver issues of the later FÄá¹­imid caliphs, almost exclusively struck in Egypt were the small, irregularly-shaped black dirhams, the production of which was continued by the AyyÅ«bid Sultanate of Egypt (1171-1260). A very few copper or bronze coins have been encountered. Some of these exhibit traces of a silver wash, which indicated that they were not considered to be copper coins as such, but rather small change in the dirham series.

FÄá¹­imid coinage, and particularly gold coinage, played an important part in the economy of North Africa and the Middle East during the period of the FÄá¹­imid Caliphate. Indeed, the FÄá¹­imid dinar had a wider impact throughout the Mediterranean world because of the reputation the regime's coinage carried with it far beyond the borders of the empire. FÄá¹­imid gold coins were struck to a high standard of fineness and this standard was generally maintained during most of the time the FÄá¹­imid Caliphate was in power. In the Syrian and Palestinian territories, the dinar was frequently struck to a lighter standard, especially in the later years of the FÄá¹­imid Caliphate.
Historical notes:

al-áº’Ähir (li-I'zÄz DÄ«n AllÄh) (Ø§Ù„Ø¸Ø§Ù‡Ø± Ù„Ø¥Ø¹Ø²Ø§Ø² Ø¯ÙŠÙ† Ø§Ù„Ù„Ù‡) (born on 10 RamadÄn AH 395 (20 June 1005); proclaimed caliph on 10 DhÅ« al-Hijjah AH 411 (27 March 1021); died on 15 Sha'bÄn AH 427 (13 June 1036))

(To the right) Photograph of the al-Azhar Mosque in Cairo, Egypt, taken by an anonym in 2018. The FÄá¹­imid Caliphate conquered Egypt and founded Cairo (al-QÄhira) in AH 358 (969). The mosque was established in AH 361 (972) and the capital of the FÄá¹­imid Caliphate moved from al-Maná¹£Å«rÄ«yah to Cairo in AH 362 (972-973).

Some time passed after the disappearance of his predecessor al-á¸¤Äkim on 27 ShawwÄl AH 411 (13 February 1021) before al-áº’Ähir was proclaimed caliph on 10 DhÅ« al-Hijjah AH 411 (27 March 1021). The FÄá¹­imid regime was fairly stable during the first few years of al-áº’Ähir's caliphate, but this situation did not last very long. By 414-415 AH (1024-1025), the wasteful extravagances of al-á¸¤Äkim's rule began to take a toll on the health of the empire. A financial crisis ensued in which the cash reserves of the treasury were depleted. The army remained unpaid for an overly long period, then riots in Cairo and the provinces broke out, al-áº’Ähir lost control of his government and a ruling clique came to be in charge in the capital. This was followed by first drought and then famine in Egypt during AH 415 (1024-1025).

Despite his political incompetence and a life given over to the pursuit of pleasure, al-áº’Ähir was able to weather the political storm and on 16 JumÄdÄ II AH 420 (2 July 1029), his heir, AbÅ« TamÄ«m Ma'add, who was destined to become the Caliph al-Mustaná¹£ir, was born.

Trouble did not long stay away from al-áº’Ähir, however. His military commanders exercised almost independent control and in AH 421 (1030), attacks by the army on the populace in North Africa diminished support for the caliph. A powerful earthquake caused massive destruction in Palestine and al-áº’Ähir spent massive sums to rebuild the walls of Jerusalem during the years AH 421-424 (1030-1033). Famine once again visited North Africa in AH 425 (1034) and in the midst of all these problems, al-áº’Ähir died some two years later, just under thirty-two years of age.

 -

L'article XI de l'Ã©dit de PÃ®tres prÃ©scrit :

Ceci peut Ãªtre traduit en franÃ§ais par: Â« Que les deniers de notre nouvelle monnaie aient d'un cÃ´tÃ© notre titre en cercle, et au centre le monogramme de notre nom, et de l'autre cÃ´tÃ© le nom de la ville, et au centre une croix. Â» Les trouvailles de ces monnaies du type de l'Ã©dit de PÃ®tres indiquent que la lÃ©gende donnant le titre est Â« GRATIADÌ…IREX Â», c'est-Ã -dire Â« GRATIADEIREX Â». L'article XII de l'Ã©dit de PÃ®tres prÃ©scrit :

Script: -
Lettering: -
Traduction: -
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin was sent to NGC for grading. The grade that I expected it would receive was AU58. The coin was not encapsulated by NGC. It was described as "Ineligible Type" on the certification label, that is a class of coin, medal or token that NGC does not certify, regardless of its condition. NGC will refund the grading fee, less a USD 5 processing charge. I learnt a lesson in the process: NGC does not certify Merovingian coins. PCGS does not appear to certify Merovingian coins either. Hence, I decided to encapsulate this coin myself for convenience of storage and long-term preservation of the coin. To proceed, I purchased a coin of similar diameter, encapsulated by NGC Ancients (with the certification # 6828451-004), so that I could "crack" the NGC holder and replace the coin by this coin. The operation was a success, though fitting the coin in the holder turned out not to be a trivial task.

Traditionnellement, ces deniers avec la lettre E lunaire (Ïµ, en onciale) croisetÃ©e au revers sont attribuÃ©s Ã  Paris, mais sans argument convaincant. Les analyses mÃ©talliques tendraient Ã  prouver que ces monnaies ont Ã©tÃ© frappÃ©es avec de lâ€™argent de Melle en Poitou et qu'elles proviendraient plutÃ´t d'un atelier monÃ©taire local. La lettre Ğ„ croisetÃ©e serait alors la lettre M lunaire (m, en onciale) croisetÃ©e, la lettre M Ã©tant la premiÃ¨re lettre des diverses variations des anciens noms de la ville de Melle (Metalus Vicus, Metulo, Metullo, Metulum, Metullum, Metalo, Metallo, Metalum, Metallum, etc.). L'atelier monÃ©taire de Melle, dans le sud est des Deux-SÃ¨vres, fut important Ã  l'Ã©poque carolingienne et semble avoir fonctionnÃ© dÃ¨s l'Ã©poque mÃ©rovingienne. Les mines de plomb argentifÃ¨re sont toujours accessibles et visitables par un large public. D'aprÃ¨s les informations que l'on aurait transmises au prÃ©cÃ©dent acquÃ©reur, cette monnaie aurait Ã©tÃ© trouvÃ©e Ã  Richelieu en Touraine, qui se trouve Ã  environ 100 km de Melle. Cette proximitÃ© gÃ©ographique est compatible avec une frappe dans un atelier monÃ©taire de la rÃ©gion melloise.

DiffÃ©rentes monnaies d'or, d'argent et de cuivre circulaient en Gaule Ã  la fin de l'Empire romain d'Occident en 476. Aux temps mÃ©rovingiens ne subsiste guÃ¨re que la monnaie d'or, sou (du nom de la monnaie romaine d'or, le solidus) et surtout tiers de sou, appelÃ© aussi triens (du nom de la monnaie romaine d'or, le tremissis, valant un tiers de solidus), imitations plus ou moins rÃ©ussies des piÃ¨ces impÃ©riales romaines. Le triens d'or devient quasiment espÃ¨ce unique au dÃ©but du VIIÃ¨me siÃ¨cle. L'or provient principalement du bassin mÃ©diterranÃ©en, en particulier des monnaies de l'Empire byzantin. Mais vers 650, le centre de gravitÃ© des relations commerciales europÃ©ennes se dÃ©place vers le nord de l'Europe oÃ¹ les anglo-saxons et les frisons qui dÃ©veloppe le commerce le long des cÃ´tes de la mer du Nord utilisent des monnaies d'argent, les sceattas. Les monnayages mÃ©rovingiens passent ainsi du monomÃ©talisme or au monomÃ©talisme argent, inspirÃ© des pays nordiques. Vers 670, le sou d'or est complÃ©tÃ© par une piÃ¨ce d'argent : le denier (du nom de l'ancienne monnaie romaine d'argent, le denarius, remplacÃ© au IIIÃ¨me siÃ¨cle par l'antoninianus, puis par d'autres monnaies d'argent). Entre 670 et 751 environ, seul l'argent est frappÃ© dans le royaume mÃ©rovingien, sous forme de denier et de demi-denier ou obole.

Par son aspect le denier d'argent mÃ©rovingien ne diffÃ¨re qu'assez peu du triens d'or. Ce sont les mÃªmes types qui sont continuÃ©s au moins pendant un certain temps, les lÃ©gendes indiquent le nom du lieu d'Ã©mission, le nom du monÃ©taire. Le diamÃ¨tre qui varie entre 11 et 13 mm est le mÃªme, seul le mÃ©tal diffÃ¨re. Cependant, avec le temps, le denier se transforme. Les lÃ©gendes deviennent sibyllines ou disparaissent complÃ¨tement, les diamÃ¨tres des deniers de certains ateliers monÃ©taires augmentent, 12 Ã  14 mm, les gravures sont plus grossiÃ¨res et schÃ©matiques et l'iconographie devient parfois exubÃ©rante. L'Ã©pigraphie aussi se transforme, au moins dans certains ateliers monÃ©taires, et les inscriptions, avant de disparaÃ®tre, deviennent souvent incohÃ©rentes. Un bon exemple de cette incohÃ©rence est fourni par cet exemplaire pour lequel la lÃ©gende Ã  l'avers est sujette Ã  interprÃ©tation.

Le contrÃ´le des monnaies semble Ã©chapper en grande partie au pouvoir royal mÃ©rovingien. Le pouvoir royal sur la monnaie sera rÃ©affirmÃ© sous l'Ã©gide de la dynastie carolingienne (Ã  partir de 751) qui imposera le denier d'argent carolingien comme monnaie unique et prescrira un ensemble de rÃ¨glements et de contrÃ´les organisant sa fabrication et sa mise en circulation.

To proceed, I purchased a coin of similar diameter, encapsulated by NGC Ancients (with the certification # 6828451-091), so that I could ""crack"" the NGC holder and replace the coin by this coin. The operation was a success, though fitting the coin in the holder turned out not to be a trivial task.

This coin makes me think of my son Louis. ğŸ¦“

Ces deniers au monogramme Â« AR Â» sont attribuÃ©s Ã  Clermont-Ferrand (Arvernus). Le monogramme Â« AR Â» est formÃ© des Iettres AR, les deux premiÃ¨res du nom de lieu d'emission, Arvernis. Des trouvailles assez nombreuses de monnaies portant cette marque, parfois en monogramme, ont Ã©tÃ© faites en Auvergne pour confirmer cette attribution et Ã©liminer quelques propositions d'y voir les marques d'Aurelianis (OrlÃ©ans), Arelate (Arles) ou Argentorate (Strasbourg). Lafaurie (1992) prÃ©sente un rapport dÃ©taillÃ© sur les deniers, dit Â« au cavalier Â», de Clermont-Ferrand. Le seul de ces deniers qui soit issu d'un trÃ©sor connu est celui du trÃ©sor trouvÃ© Ã  Nice-Cimiez, enfoui autour de 740, qui contenait aussi la plupart des deniers Ã©piscopaux connus de Clermont-Ferrand.
Edge: Plain
