Varieties:

Il existe plusieurs variÃ©tÃ©s de styles de cheval et de cavalier Ã  l'avers, ainsi qu'une variÃ©tÃ© avec le monogramme Â« AR Â» renversÃ© au revers (voir Lafaurie, 1992). L'agencement des perles au revers, est Ã©galement variable d'un exemplaire Ã  l'autre.

Cet exemplaire est issu des mÃªmes coins de frappe que les exemplaires conservÃ©s aux Cabinets des MÃ©dailles des MusÃ©es des Beaux-Arts de Lyon, provenant du trÃ©sor de Nice-Cimiez, et de Copenhague (Belfort#411).
Note:

DiffÃ©rentes monnaies d'or, d'argent et de cuivre circulaient en Gaule Ã  la fin de l'Empire romain d'Occident en 476. Aux temps mÃ©rovingiens ne subsiste guÃ¨re que la monnaie d'or, sou (du nom de la monnaie romaine d'or, le solidus) et surtout tiers de sou, appelÃ© aussi triens (du nom de la monnaie romaine d'or, le tremissis, valant un tiers de solidus), imitations plus ou moins rÃ©ussies des piÃ¨ces impÃ©riales romaines. Le triens d'or devient quasiment espÃ¨ce unique au dÃ©but du VIIÃ¨me siÃ¨cle. L'or provient principalement du bassin mÃ©diterranÃ©en, en particulier des monnaies de l'Empire byzantin. Mais vers 650, le centre de gravitÃ© des relations commerciales europÃ©ennes se dÃ©place vers le nord de l'Europe oÃ¹ les anglo-saxons et les frisons qui dÃ©veloppe le commerce le long des cÃ´tes de la mer du Nord utilisent des monnaies d'argent, les sceattas. Les monnayages mÃ©rovingiens passent ainsi du monomÃ©talisme or au monomÃ©talisme argent, inspirÃ© des pays nordiques. Vers 670, le sou d'or est complÃ©tÃ© par une piÃ¨ce d'argent : le denier (du nom de l'ancienne monnaie romaine d'argent, le denarius, remplacÃ© au IIIÃ¨me siÃ¨cle par l'antoninianus, puis par d'autres monnaies d'argent). Entre 670 et 751 environ, seul l'argent est frappÃ© dans le royaume mÃ©rovingien, sous forme de denier et de demi-denier ou obole.

Par son aspect le denier d'argent mÃ©rovingien ne diffÃ¨re qu'assez peu du triens d'or. Ce sont les mÃªmes types qui sont continuÃ©s au moins pendant un certain temps, les lÃ©gendes indiquent le nom du lieu d'Ã©mission, le nom du monÃ©taire. Le diamÃ¨tre qui varie entre 11 et 13 mm est le mÃªme, seul le mÃ©tal diffÃ¨re. Cependant, avec le temps, le denier se transforme. Les lÃ©gendes deviennent sibyllines ou disparaissent complÃ¨tement, les diamÃ¨tres des deniers de certains ateliers monÃ©taires augmentent, 12 Ã  14 mm, les gravures sont plus grossiÃ¨res et schÃ©matiques et l'iconographie devient parfois exubÃ©rante. L'Ã©pigraphie aussi se transforme, au moins dans certains ateliers monÃ©taires, et les inscriptions, avant de disparaÃ®tre, deviennent souvent incohÃ©rentes.

Le contrÃ´le des monnaies semble Ã©chapper en grande partie au pouvoir royal mÃ©rovingien. Le pouvoir royal sur la monnaie sera rÃ©affirmÃ© sous l'Ã©gide de la dynastie carolingienne (Ã  partir de 751) qui imposera le denier d'argent carolingien comme monnaie unique et prescrira un ensemble de rÃ¨glements et de contrÃ´les organisant sa fabrication et sa mise en circulation.
Historical notes:

(To the right) Vue d'artiste de la Â« Bataille de Poitiers. Octobre 732 Â», peinte par Charles Auguste, baron de Steuben (1788-1856) en 1837. Cette Å“uvre fut commandÃ©e par Louis-Philippe en 1834 afin d'enrichir les collections du MusÃ©e historique de Versailles. La peinture est une reprÃ©sentation romantique du gÃ©nÃ©ral franc Charles Martel (718-741) combattant le gÃ©nÃ©ral omeyyade Abd al-Rahman ibn Abd Allah Al-Ghafiqi Ã  la Bataille de Tours (Ã©galement connue sous le nom de Â« Bataille de Poitiers Â» et, dans les sources arabes, de Â« Bataille de la Route des Martyrs Â») en 732. Le combat en tÃªte-Ã -tÃªte dÃ©crit n'a jamais eu lieu, car Abd Al-Rahman a Ã©tÃ© tuÃ© par une lance et ses forces ont battu en retraite de maniÃ¨re dÃ©sorganisÃ©e.

+ AD 0610 - Byzantine Empire - Tremissis - Heraclius:

Open description in new window
Period: Middle Ages; Byzantine Empire (395-1453); Heraclian dynasty (610-711)
Ruler: Heraclius (610-641)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Bust of Heraclius, facing right, seen from three quarters forward, diademed with no pearl visible in the composition of diadem and a cross above its front, draped, cuirassed
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) DNHERî„”CL-IVSPPî„”VC (D N HERî„”CLIVS PP î„”VC)
Traduction: Our Lord (Dominus Noster) Heraclius, perpetual (Perpetuus) Emperor (Augustus) (Dominus Noster Heraclius Perpetuus Augustus)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Cross potent, with a pellet in the fourth quadrant, the abbreviation "CONOB" (standing for "CÅnstantÄ«nopolis obryzum", with "obryzum" the Latin word for "refined gold") below in exergue
Script: Greek
Lettering: (starting at 08h) VICTORî„”î„”VCVSTORVN (VICTORî„” î„”VCVSTORVN)
Traduction: The victory of the Emperor (Victoria Augustorum)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

Rare in this condition
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (â†º, 06h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R Material: Gold
Year: 610 (not dated) Fineness: 1000
Country: Byzantine Empire Weight (g): Measured: 1.47; Expected: 1.52
Issuer: Byzantine Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: â…“ Diameter (mm): Expected: 15
Unit: First Solidus Nomisma ("Reform" of Anastasius I Dicorus; 498-720) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Ravenna Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 610-613
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients Ch AUâ˜…; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 4/5 (NGC) Variety: None
References: BCV#902; DOC2_1#276; MIB3#125A; Ranieri#574; MBR#11.124N; Fr#104
Varieties:

This tremissis might be an example of the Lombard coinage of tremisses from Tuscany (see for instance MEC1#307-310). However, because of their heavy annular border these tremisses are commonly ascribed to Ravenna.

A variety exists (MBR#11.125) with the obverse legend separated as DNHERî„”CLI-VSPPî„”VC rather than DNHERî„”CL-IVSPPî„”VC. The obverse legend of this variety corresponds to that of the semisses of type BCV#899D and MIB3#121. Hence, this variety was probably issued in parallel with the emission of this type of semissis in 637-641.
Note:

The twin pivots of the Byzantine monetary system in the 5th and 6th centuries had been the gold solidus or nomisma and the copper nummus. The gold solidus was a coin struck 72 to the Roman pound and consequently weighing, in Greco-Roman units, 24 siliquae or carats. The weight of the Roman pound is normally reckoned at 327.45 g, giving the solidus a theoretical weight in modern terms of 4.55 g. The nummus, sometimes called by contemporaries a denarius, was a small coin of varying weight, usually about 1 g or a little less. It has then been reckoned as 1/7200 of the solidus, but its value in fact varied and seems frequently to have fallen to a much lower figure. The gap between the solidus and the nummus was bridged in part by real coins (the gold semissis and tremissis, fractions of the solidus, and the copper pentanummium, decanummium, half follis, and follis, multiples of the nummus), in part by a money of account, the keration, and in part by the miliaresion, which was sometimes one and sometimes the other.

Treating them in descending order of value, the semissis and tremissis require no discussion. They were actual coins, worth one-half and one-third of a solidus, respectively. Miliaresion was a Greek loan word from the Latin "miliarense", a term applied to a silver coin current in the 4th century from the period of the Tetrarchy onward. In the 6th century, when no silver coinage was being struck for regular circulation in the East, it had become the generic name for any silver coin at all, being applied indifferently to the Roman denarius and to the Persian dirham. When the hexagram was created by the Byzantine emperor Heraclius (r. 610â€“641) this was known as the silver coin of six grammata, and when the hexagram ceased to be struck the term remained available for application to whatever silver coin would take its place.

The keration was not a coin, but primarily a unit of weight, 1/1728 of the Roman pound, 1/144 of the Roman ounce, or about 0.189 g in modern terms. Since the solidus was one-sixth of a Roman ounce, the solidus weighed 24 keratia. Consequently, as a money of account, the keration was 1/24 of the Roman solidus, a relationship that lasted throughout the whole of the Byzantine Empire's history. Keratia are omnipresent in Byzantine monetary reckonings, but they are always notional. A debt expressed in solidi, keratia, and fractions of keratia would be paid in solidi, miliaresia, folles, and such fractions of these as were in circulation at the time.

The follis, sometimes called the obol, reintroduced in 498 with the monetary reform of the Byzantine emperor Anastasius I Dicorus (r. 491-518), was a copper coin worth forty nummi. Various fractions were struck during the 6th and 7th centuries, the half follis, decanummium, and pentanummium being the most important. In the mid 6th century the follis was reckoned 180 to the solidus. How the relationships between the solidus, keration, follis and nummus were affected by the "debasement" of the follis in the later 6th and 7th centuries â€“ the gradual reduction of its weight to less than one-sixth of what it had been in the peak years of Justinian I's reign (527-565) â€“ is a question to which there is not yet any answer. The nummus disappeared completely as a coin, but since the follis and its fractions still bore marks of value expressed as multiples of nummi, these were presumably still thought of as the lowest units in the monetary system.

This monetary system was not as unified in the three and a half centuries between the accession of the Byzantine emperor Leo III (r. 717-741) in 717, marking the end of the "Twenty Years' Anarchy" (695-717), and the monetary reform of the Byzantine emperor Alexios I Komnenos (r. 1081-1118) in 1092, following his accession in 1081, marking the end of a prolonged period of civil war resulting from the defeat to the Seljuk Turks at Manzikert in 1071. The silver miliaresion introduced by Leo III in 720 and continued by his successors provided a certain element of unity nonetheless. The essential features of the monetary system during this period may be summarized as follows:

Gold coinage â€“ In the East, the semissis and tremissis ceased to be struck, save as ceremonial coins, toward the middle of the 8th century. Henceforward the only gold coin was the solidus. Its fineness remained virtually unchanged down to the 1030's, when debasement set in, and while its weight seems ot have declined very slightly the coin remained one theoretically struck 72 to the Roman pound. In the reign of Nikephoros II Phokas (r. 963-969), however, there began a series of experiments in light-weight nomismata comparable to the light-weight solidi of the 6th and 7th centuries. Of these the light-weight nomisma of 22 keratia, known as a tetarteron, finally gained the day, so that from the late 10th century down to Alexios I Komnenos' monetary reform of 1092 one has to distinguish between the full-weight nomisma histamenon and the light-weight nomisma tetarteron.

Things went differently in the West. The solidus and tremissis continued to be struck in mainland Italy as long as the mints of Ravenna and Rome remained in Byzantine hands, i.e., to the mid and late 8th century, respectively. In Sicily they continued down to the reign of Basil I (r. 867-886), and there was even a revival of the use of the semissis in the early 9th century. The weight standard of the western gold coins, however, was substantially less than that of their eastern counterparts, and both on the mainland and in Sicily there was a serious reduction in fineness during the last decades of Byzantine rule. The fate of the fractional gold was related inversely to the presence or absence of a silver coinage, since the miliaresion flourished in the East but was not adopted in the West.

Silver coinage â€“ The history of the silver coinage is that of a new miliaresion, a coin much lighter than the hexagram of the 7th century, which was introduced by Leo III in 720. It lasted, with remarkably few changes in external appearance, down to Alexios I Komnenos' monetary reform of 1092. The weight, however, was several times altered, and in its final phase it was badly debased in both weight and fineness. Fractions were struck only under Leo III, of whose half miliaresion specimens are known, and in the middle of the 11th century. Over much of the period the miliaresion was valued as a double keration, i.e., as a coin worth 1/12 of a solidus, so that sums of money are as commonly expressed in terms of nomismata and miliaresia as of nomismata and keratia. But when this ratio became fixed, or how the value of the actual coins changed, in relation to the debased nomisma, during the last decades of their existence, are not known exactly.

Copper Coinage â€“ The evolution of the copper resembled that of the gold in that both underwent a process of drastic simplification and differed from it in that the weight of the follis altered greatly over the centuries.
Historical notes:

Heraclius (born circa 575; crown emperor on 5 October 610; died on 11 February 641)

(To the right) Plaque from a cross: Cherub, Heraclius and Khosrow II, allegory of a (tetramorph) Cherub uniting the attributes of the Four Evangelists Matthew (lion), Mark (ox), Luke (man), and John (eagle), witnessing the submission of the Persian Shah Khosrow II to Heraclius, made by an anonym in the Meuse region circa 1160-1170 using ChamplevÃ© enamel over gilt copper, acquired by the MusÃ©e du Louvre in 1828 from Pierre Henri RÃ©voil (1776-1842)

One of the greatest of all Byzantine rulers, and the founder of a remarkable dynasty, Heraclius came to power when the Empire seemed close to disintegration. The Persians occupied much of Asia Minor, and soon added Syria and Egypt to their conquests. When they captured Jerusalem, the Holy Cross was carried off to Ctesiphon: this was a particularly heavy blow for the Christian Empire. The Slavs and Avars continued to savage the Balkans and Greece, and even penetrated to the Peloponnese and the Greek islands.

The emperor bided his time and took the first steps to recovery by reorganising the administration of those areas still under his control. Large military zones, called "themes", were created and grants of land were made to the soldiers on condition of hereditary service. This system of military government was gradually extended over the whole empire and formed the backbone of the Mediaeval Byzantine State.

Heraclius began his great counter-offensive in 622, and after six years of bitter fighting, the emperor often leading his troops in person, a miraculous change of fortune had occurred. The Avars were driven back from Constantinople and their fleet and army practically annihilated. The Persians were utterly defeated, and the Sassanian Empire, the great rival of the Romans and the Byzantines, stood in ruins. The Persian Shah Khosrow II was deposed and murdered. Amidst great rejoicings Heraclius restored the Holy Cross to Jerusalem, an act symbolic of the victorious conclusion of the war.

Unfortunately the emperor lived long enough to see the undoing of much of his achievements, for the closing years of the reign witnessed the fast dynamic expansion of Mulsim power. Persia succumbed almost without resistance and the Byzantines lost Syria and Palestine before Heraclius died early in 641, a broken man. Egypt fell to the Arabs soon afterwards, but despite these ultimate disasters the reign of Heraclius marked a turning point in Byzantine history, and his work laid the foundations for future greatness.

â†’ Ier millÃ©naire de l'Ã¨re Â« commune Â» de 0001 Ã  0500 :

+ AD 0388 - Roman Empire - Siliqua - Theodosius I:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Empire (-27-395); House of Theodosius (379-395)
Ruler: Theodosius I, sometimes called "the Great" (379-395)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Bust of Theodosius I, facing right, seen from three quarters forward, pearl-diademed, draped, cuirassed (RIC "Type A" and RCV "Type A")
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) DNTHEODO-SIVSPFAVG (D N THEODOSIVS P F AVG)
Traduction: Our Lord (Dominus Noster) Theodosius, dutiful (Pius) and happy (Felix) Emperor (Augustus) (Dominus Noster Theodosius Pius Felix Augustus)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Roma (Roman goddess and personification of the city of Rome, and in a wider sense the Empire which she had conquered), seated left on cuirass on a base, holding Victoria (Roman goddess and personification of victory) on a globe with the right hand and a reversed spear with the left hand, the mint mark (TR) and the abbreviation "PS" (standing for "pusulatum", the Latin word for "refined silver") below in exergue
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 07h) VIRTVSRO-MANORVM (VIRTVS ROMANORVM)
Traduction: Bravery of the Romans
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

Reportedly from the Gussage All Saints hoard, as indicated by an older ticket describing the coin, though not traced to any of the known coins from the hoard

The Gussage All Saints hoard of 662 late Roman silver coins was found on 21 March 2010 by Mr I. West using a metal detector on ploughed land in the parish of Gussage All Saints, Dorset, in southwest England. The hoard was contained in a small earthenware flagon, which was lifted and then taken to the British Museum in London where the coins were then removed, conserved and catalogued, following the application of the 1996 Treasure Act as Treasure case No. 2010T177. The find was recorded in the Portable Antiquities Scheme (PAS; see https://finds.org.uk) with record IDs DOR-A1CCB1 and IARCH-8D9AB1. It was also included in the list of coin hoards published in 2011 in The Numismatic Chronicle, volume 171, pp. 407â€“24, as item No. 54. The hoard comprised 653 siliquae and 9 miliarenses. Curiously the miliarenses were found at the top, in the neck of the flagon, thereby suggesting careful packing of the coins into the pot at the time of concealment. The earliest coins were issues of Constantius II (r. 337-361), struck in the period 355-361, and the latest coins were issues of Arcadius (r. 383-408) and Honorius (r. 393-423) from the Milan mint struck in the period 395-402. In addition to coins of these Roman emperors, coins of all the Roman emperors in the period 355-402, Julian (as Caesar from 355 to 360 and Augustus from 361 to 363), Jovian (r. 363-364), Valentinian I (r. 364-375), Valens (r. 364-378), Gratian (r. 367-383), Valentinian II (r. 375-392), Theodosius I (r. 379-395), Magnus Maximus (usurper; r. 383-388), Flavius Victor (usurper; r. 383-388), and Flavius Eugenius (usurper; r. 392-394) were all represented. A small number of coins could not be attributed with certainty to a specific emperor and a few others were unidentifiable issues.

The composition of the hoard by emperor and denomination was: Constantius II (22 siliquae), Julian (52 siliquae and 1 miliarense), Jovian (5 siliquae), Valentinian I (10 siliquae and 1 miliarense), Valens (76 siliquae and 3 miliarenses), Gratian (68 siliquae and 2 miliarenses), Valentinian II (38 siliquae), Theodosius I (70 siliquae), Magnus Maximus (72 siliquae and 1 miliarense), Flavius Victor (9 siliquae), Flavius Eugenius (33 siliquae and 1 miliarense), Arcadius (102 siliquae), Honorius (65 siliquae), and unidentified (31 siliquae, of which 1 from the House of Constantine, 13 from the House of Theodosius and 1 from the House of Valentinian).

The majority of the coins were from the Augusta Treverorum (now Trier; 351 coins) and Mediolanum (now Milan; 136 coins) mints. Other western Roman Empire mints represented were Lugdunum (now Lyon; 45 coins), Arelate (now Arles; 44 coins), Roma (now Rome; 27 coins), and Aquileia (17 coins). In addition there were a small number of eastern Roman Empire mints with Siscia (3 coins), Sirmium (3 coins), Thessalonica (1 coin), Constantinople (4 coins), Nicomedia (2 coins) and Antioch (6 coins).

The composition of the Gussage All Saints hoard is comparable to the much larger and more famous Hoxne hoard, found on 16 November 1992 in Hoxne, Suffolk, in east England. In comparison, the Gussage All Saints hoard has a higher percentage of coins of Trier as opposed to Milan and a higher proportion dating from 378-395, perhaps reflecting its slightly earlier deposition than the Hoxne hoard. Many of the coins have been subject to a low level of clipping, a practice common to British found Siliquae of this period; however the extent of clipping is far less severe than that noted for the Hoxne hoard. This, along with the content of the hoard, suggests a date of deposition of circa 410. The hoard therefore dates from the period when the Roman Empire in the West, beset with the collapse of the Rhine frontier and invasions in Gaul and Italy, relinquished its authority over the British province which was left to its own devices and increasingly vulnerable to Germanic and Irish raiding.

On completion of the Treasure process, one coin (siliqua of Valentinian II from the Siscia mint) was acquired by the British Museum, and the rest of the coins along with the earthenware flagon in which the hoard was found were returned to the finder, who brought them to Spink in 2012. Spink offered each variety of the miliarenses, a selection of the best of the siliquae, a few "large lots" and the flagon at auction on 26 September 2012.

The composition of the hoard revealed 47 siliquae of Theodosius I from the Trier mint struck in the period 388-392/395. These coins include all known varieties (RIC9#94B, RIC9#95B and RIC9#106A). The Spink auction offered some of these coins: 1 as individual lot (Lot 425) and a maximum of 7 as part of a "large lot" (Lot 457). Further coins were acquired by coin dealers, including Antiqua, Ltd., who put some of them for sale in their fixed price Catalogue XVII in 2013, and Roma Numismatics Ltd. However, I have not found any trace of the present coin in auction records that report the Gussage All Saints hoard as provenance.
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (â†º, 12h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: C Material: Silver
Year: 388 (not dated) Fineness: 970
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 1.87; Expected: 1.9
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1/24 Diameter (mm): Measured: 16.5; Expected: 17
Unit: Solidus (Reform of Constantine I; 310/324-395) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Augusta Treverorum Mintage:
Mint mark: TR Emission period: 388-392/395
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients Ch AU; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 3/5 (NGC) Variety: None
References: RIC9#94B,106A; RSC5#57A; RCV5#20459; Cohen8#57; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.9.tri.94B; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.9.tri.106A; MRK#160.18; PAS#https://finds.org.uk/database/search/results/q/2010T177
Varieties:

The siliquae of Theodosius I from the Trier mint struck in the period 388-392/395 can referred to those from the RIC 6th Period (from 28 August 388 to 15 May 392; RIC9#94B) or 7th Period (from 15 May 392 to 17 January 395; RIC9#106A), which are based on mint-marks and portraiture.
Note:

Constantine I (the Great; r. 307â€“337) made further changes to the monetary system that was reformed by Diocletian (r. 284-305) circa 294. In place of the gold aureus, which was currently being struck 60 to the pound, he introduced into the western provinces a new and lighter coin called the solidus, which was struck 72 to the pound and hence was weighing, in Greco-Roman units, 24 siliquae or carats. The weight of the Roman pound is normally reckoned at 327.45 g, giving the solidus a theoretical weight in modern terms of 4.55 g. With the defeat of Constantine Iâ€™s eastern rival Licinius (r. 308â€“324) production of the solidus became universal throughout the Roman Empire. The aureus was still occasionally struck thereafter, but its issue was generally confined to the celebration of special occasions. Two gold fractional denominations accompanied the solidus, though they were never produced in the same quantities as the larger piece. The semissis was the equivalent of a half solidus (12 siliquae), while the 9-siliqua piece (also called the one and a half scripulum) was the equivalent of three-eighths of a solidus. In 383 Theodosius I introduced the gold tremissis, or one-third solidus (8 siliquae), which quickly replaced the curious and seemingly inconvenient 9-siliqua piece. The tremissis became one of the commonest denominations in the 5th century and beyond.

In 325 Constantine I resumed production of the siliqua (or argenteus), which had been introduced by Diocletian and had lapsed after about 310. At the same time he introduced the larger silver miliarense, which was one-third heavier than the siliqua (four scrupula instead of three) and the same weight as the gold solidus (4.55 g). A few years later, after the death of Constantine I, a heavier version of the miliarense was introduced. This "heavy miliarenses" was struck 60 to the pound, the same weight as the old gold aureus (5.46 g). Both versions of the miliarense remained in issue over a considerable period of time, extending even into the period of the Byzantine Empire. The siliqua, however, soon underwent some fundamental changes. About 357 Constantius II (r. 337-361), the last surviving son of Constantine I, reduced the weight of the siliqua from 96 to the pound (about 3.41 g or three scrupula) to 144 to the pound (about 2.27 grams or two scrupula). In consequence, the lighter version of the miliarense now became a double siliqua.
Historical notes:

(Flavius) Theodosius I (born on 11 January 347 at Cauca in Gallaecia in the north-west of Spain; proclaimed emperor on 19 January 379; died on 17 January 395 at Mediolanum)

(To the right) St. Ambrose barring Theodosius from Milan Cathedral, painted by Sir Anthony van Dyck (1599-1641) circa 1619-1620. This painting depicts St. Ambrose (circa 339-397), bishop of Milan, stopping the emperor Theodosius I (circa 346â€“395) and his retinue from entering Milan Cathedral, as punishment for his massacre of the people of Thessalonica, who had murdered the Gothic "magister militum" Butheric (?-390) in 390.

Flavius Theodosius was the namesake son of the celebrated principal general, appointed "magister equitum" by Valentinian I (364-375) from 369 until his execution at Carthage circa 375. Theodosius thus had little reason to love the House of Valentinian and this may well have influenced his future behaviour. On his father's downfall, the future emperor retired to his Spanish estates and settled down to private life. He married Aella Flaccilla (circa 355-386), a fellow Spaniard, about 376. The following year a son, Arcadius (circa 377-408), was born to the couple, and a second son, Honorius (384-423), was added eight years later.

With the death of Valens (364-378), the Roman emperor in the East, in the catastrophic defeat by the Goths of the eastern Roman army at Hadrianopolis (on 9 August 378), Gratian (367-383), the Roman Emperor in the West, was faced with a dilemma. Clearly the throne of Constantinople needed to be filled promptly by a competent replacement. Gratian's younger brother and co-emperor Valentinian II (375-392) was still only eight-year old and obviously unequal to the daunting task. For the time being, Gratian decided to recall Theodosius from his provincial retirement and place him in command of the seriously threatened Danube frontier, with the rank of "magister equitum", which his father had borne under the rule of Valentinian I. He had already gained considerable military experience on his father's staff during the latter's brilliant campaigns against the Picts and the Scots in Britain in 368. Having achieved a measure of success over the invaders, Theodosius was summoned to Sirmium where he was invested by Gratian with the imperial purple and appointed ruler of the Roman emperor in the East in 379. The dynasty which he founded was to rule the eastern Roman Empire for the following seven decades, though unfortunately it did not produce any other rulers of note throughout this period.

The sixteen-year reign of Theodosius I was much troubled by western usurpations, from Magnus Maximus (383-388) and his son (Flavius) Victor (383-388) and Flavius Eugenius (392-394), the quelling of both of them required the emperor's personal intervention. Gratian had been overthrown by Magnus Maximus in the summer of 383 and the young Valentinian II was hardly in a position to avenge his brother. Theodosius, whose relations with Gratian had been steadily deteriorating, may not have been sorry to witness his removal from the political scene at the hands of a third party. Initially he tolerated the rule of the usurper in most of the western provinces and even struck some very rare coin issues in his name in the East. The authority of Valentinian II, the legitimate Roman Emperor in the West, was mostly confined to Italy, a state of affairs which prevailed until 387. At this point Magnus Maximus, clearly wishing to make himself sole Roman Emperor in the West and an equal partner with Theodosius I, invaded the peninsula. Valentinian II and his family were obliged to flee to Thessalonica and place themselves under the protection of Theodosius I. During this time Theodosius I met and fell in love with Valentinian II's sister Galla (circa 365-394) and the imperial nuptials were celebrated in 388 in return for a promise by Theodosius I to invade Italy and remove Magnus Maximus from power. Good to his word, Theodosius I defeated his adversary at Aquileia and executed him shortly thereafter. He may have been reluctant to do this as Magnus Maximus was a kinsman and would have been a far more competent western colleague than Valentinian II, but he made the sacrifice for the sake of his new wife. Valentinian II now returned to the West, but instead of becoming his brother-in-law's full colleague in the government of the Roman Empire, his authority was now restricted to Gaul. Theodosius I considered him too inexperienced to take on this responsibility and placed him under the guardianship of the Frankish "magister militum" Arbogastes (circa 375-394). Theodosius I remained in Italy for some three years while he endeavoured to settle affairs in the western Roman Empire, long subject to the rule of an usurper, but in 391 he returned to Constantinople. Arbogastes saw this as an opportunity to assert his own claims to power and his arrogant behaviour towards the now 21-year-old Valentinian II led the young man to despair of the hopelessness of his situation and to take his own life in 392. After an "interregnum" of over three months Arbogastes now nominated Flavius Eugenius, a former teacher of Latin grammar and rhetoric, to be his puppet-emperor. The empress Galla, obviously much distressed at news of her brother's death, urged her husband to take prompt action against the rebel regime. Perhaps sensing that his health was beginning to fall, Theodosius I raised his ten-year-old younger son Honorius to the rank of Augustus before organising another invasion of the West. On 6 September 394 he defeated the combined forces of the usurpers, probably at the battle of the Frigidus in Pannonia; Flavius Eugenius was executed and Arbogastes took his own life. Little more than four months later, Theodosius I himself died of dropsy (oedema) in his fiftieth year, leaving his inexperienced and incompetent sons Arcadius and Honorius to divide the Empire between them.

An accurate assessment of the abilities and achievements of Theodosius I is rendered difficult by the complexity of his character and the many seeming inconsistencies in his actions. A deeply devout Christian, he championed the cause of orthodoxy and was very intolerant towards "heretical" beliefs. It seems that the title "the Great" was due to his devout Christianity rather than having a secular basis. His religious views were greatly influenced by the powerful bishop Ambrose of Milan (circa 339-397), a patron saint of Milan and of beekeepers, and pagans and paganism received particularly severe treatment. He refused to allow the restoration of the Altar of Victory, which had been removed from the Roman Curia (Senate House) by Gratian in 382. Great controversy surrounded this issue and the altar's removal from its traditional home (since the time of Augustus) became symbolic of the final demise of paganism. It was briefly restored to its place under the usurper Flavius Eugenius but after that there is no further record of it in history. Theodosius I was the last ruler to exercise effective control over the entire Empire and the era of decline was ushered in with the succession in 395 of his two sons, Arcadius in the East and Honorius in the West, neither of whom had any aptitude for leadership.

+ AD 0321 - Roman Empire - AE3 (Billon Nummus) - Constantine I (the Great):

Note:

The coinage of Constantine I (the Great; r. 307-337), known as Constantine, is complex and its accurate interpretation presents serious challenges. The radical changes made by Constantine in the monetary system began quite early in his reign, circa 310, with the replacement of the Diocletianic gold aureus, struck 60 to the pound, by the lighter gold solidus, struck 72 to the pound. The weight of the Roman pound is normally reckoned at 327.45 g, giving the solidus a theoretical weight in modern terms of 4.55 g. However, at this time there were relatively few mints under direct Constantinian control so the reform was initially confined to the Gallic mints, later to be extended to Italy following Constantineâ€™s defeat of (Marcus Aurelius Valerius) Maxentius (circa 283-312; r. 306-312) in 312. As the territories of the Roman emperor in the West expanded so did the production of the solidus. In the East, however, (Galerius Valerius) Maximinus (Daza; circa 270-313; r. 310-313) and (Valerius Licinianus) Licinius (circa 265-325; r. 308-324) continued striking aurei, the latter right down to his defeat in 324, so for a considerable period of time a confusing situation existed with two gold denominations, of similar appearance but different values, circulating side by side. It hardly helped that Constantine struck some solidi in Licinius' name, while the Roman emperor in the East issued aurei in the name of his western colleague. Two fractional gold denominations also existed, though they are very rare in comparison with the full-weight solidus: the semissis, which was the equivalent to a half solidus, and the 9-siliqua piece (also called the one and a half scripulum), which was equivalent to three-eighths of a solidus. The last was a denomination of uncertain significance which, before the end of the 4th century, was replaced by the slightly lighter and more convenient gold tremissis, or one-third solidus.

Production of coined silver was very insignificant in the early part of Constantineâ€™s reign. The Diocletianic argenteus, struck 96 to the pound, did not long survive the end of the First Tetrarchy in 305, though at Roma (now Rome) and Ostia (the port of Rome) Maxentius extended production until late in his reign. Constantine abandoned the argenteus early, though in 312 he produced at the Trier mint an experimental denomination in billon (25% silver), which usually goes by the name of centenionalis, implying that it was tariffed at 100 to the gold solidus. This coin was also struck in the names of his co-emperors Maximinus and Licinius, each ruler having a distinct reverse type (two Victories for Constantine, Sol in quadriga for Maximinus, and Jupiter on eagle for Licinius). It is noteworthy that Constantine did not adopt the pagan Hercules as his reverse type, this being the year of his "vision of the cross". The billon centenionalis was soon abandoned, though at the mints of Ticinum and Aquileia Constantine did produce some very rare silver multiples, or medallions, which appear to have been on the weight standard of 50 to the pound. The reintroduction of regular silver issues did not occur until the year following the downfall of Licinius, in 325. At this time a denomination of the same weight as the Diocletianic argenteus (96 to the pound), though of thinner fabric, went into production. It is normally referred to as a siliqua, though in reality it was a revival of the argenteus. A larger silver coin, the miliarense, was also introduced by Constantine at this time. Its name, implying the numeral 1000, would seem to indicate that it was either a fraction or a multiple of other units. Being on the same weight standard as the solidus (72 to the pound) the miliarensis was worth 1/18th of the gold coin, while the siliqua was valued at 3â„4 of the miliarensis. Both new silver denominations were to have long histories extending into early Byzantine times.

The Constantinian billon coinage presents further complexities. At the time of Constantineâ€™s elevation to the rank of Caesar in 306 the Diocletianic follis was still being struck at its full weight of circa 10 g. The following year saw the commencement of its steady decline in size and weight and by 313 it averaged only slightly over 4 g. Various billon fractions were also produced, though not on a regular basis and all are scarce or rare today. Constantine finally abandoned the follis about 318/319, by which time its average weight had fallen to less than 3.5 g. In its place he introduced a new billon coin weighing about 3 g and displaying a range of non-pagan reverse types. In appearance, the coin closely resembles the experimental Trier centenionalis, containing 25% silver, which was issued by Constantine in 312. The new coin even seems to have derived its name from this prototype, despite the fact that its silver content was probably little more than that of the follis which it replaced. Meanwhile in the East, the Roman emperor Licinius continued the production of the traditional follis, still retaining the pagan Jupiter as its principal reverse type. But following Licinius' downfall in 324 and Constantine's acquisition of his eastern mints, the Constantinian denominations were issued uniformly throughout the Empire, thus ending what must have been a rather confusing situation with the gold and billon coinages. In 330 the weight of the centenionalis was reduced from circa 3 g to circa 2.5 g, and in the year preceding Constantineâ€™s death it fell even further to about 1.7 g. This situation was to prevail until 348 when the billon coinage was reformed by Constantine's two surviving sons, Constantius II (317-361; r. 337-361) and Constans (320 or 323-350; r. 337-350).

In addition to coinage in his own name, Constantine produced issues for his wife (Flavia Maxima) Fausta (circa 290-326), his mother (Flavia Julia) Helena (circa between 246 and 248-330), his four sons, Crispus (circa 300-326), Constantine II, Constantius II (317-361; r. 337-361), and Constans, who all served as Caesar during his reign, and his nephews (Flavius) Dalmatius (or Delmatius; ?-337) and (Flavius) Hannibalianus (or Hanniballianus; ?-337). A special coinage commencing in 330 was struck to commemorate the dedication of Constantinople and it included issues honouring the old imperial capital of Rome. At the beginning of his reign Constantine naturally issued coins commemorating his late father, (Flavius Valerius) Constantius (later Constantius I; circa 250-306; r. 305-306), and in 318 a remarkable series of reduced folles and fractions was produced honouring Divus (Marcus Aurelius) Claudius II "Gothicus" (214-270; r. 268-70), who Constantine claimed as an ancestor, his father-in-law (Marcus Aurelius Valerius) Maximianus (circa 250-circa 310; r. 286-305), known as Maximian and nicknamed Herculius, and his father Constantius. This was in the nature of a "pedigree" issue at a time when he was vying with Licinius for pre-eminence in the Roman world. Following Constantine's death in 337 a remarkable series of posthumous coins was struck for him, principally under Constantius II in the East, but also under Constantine II in the West. Constans appears to have disapproved of the issue because of the surprising inclusion of the pagan title "Divus" (abbreviated to "DV") preceding Constantineâ€™s name. It was the last such coinage to be produced.

The imperial minting establishment underwent a number of changes during the long reign of Constantine. Initially, the western mints were of prime importance to him as his power was centred in Gaul. Augusta Treverorum (now Trier), Lugdunum (now Lyon), and Londinium (now London) were his principal establishments down to his victory over Maxentius in 312, after which the Italian mints of Ticinum (now Pavia), Aquileia, and Roma also came under his control. Maxentiusâ€™ creation at Ostia also operated briefly under Constantine until its staff was transferred to a new Gallic mint at Arelate (now Arles). Carthage, under Maximian and Maxentius, also struck briefly for Constantine as Caesar prior to its closure in 307. The important mint of Siscia passed under Constantinian control in 316, in the early stages of the first civil was against Licinius. Serdica (now Sofia) struck briefly for Constantine as Caesar in 306-307 and again briefly for Constantine as Augustus in 313-314, just prior to its closure by Licinius. Sirmium was opened by Constantine in 320 and remained operational for about six years. Thessalonica, like Siscia, passed under the control of Constantine at the time of the First Licinian War in 316-317 and remained an important mint down to the end of his reign. After almost four decades of operation the mint of Londinium was closed by Constantine in 325, a victim of the vast expansion of minting capacity inherited by Constantine after his victory over Licinius in 324. Another closure at this time was the northern Italian mint of Ticinum. Its final issues appear to date to the end of 326 and as the first coinage from Constantine's new foundation of Constantinople are of about the same period it may well be that the staff of Ticinum was transferred to the new eastern capital. Constantinople, of course, was to become a mint of immense importance as befitted the capital of the Byzantine Empire, with issues stretching in a virtually unbroken sequence for more than a millennium down to the 15th century. The eastern mints of Licinius, from Heraclea in Thrace to Alexandria in Egypt, all passed to Constantine with the defeat of the eastern emperor in 324. All remained very active until the end of Constantine's reign and, as an important imperial residence, the issues of Nicomedia were of special significance, at least down to the time of the dedication of the new eastern capital of Constantinople in 330.
Historical notes:

(Flavius Valerius) Constantinus I, known as Constantine I (born on 27 February, probably 272 at Naissus in Moesia Superior in the south-east of Serbia; proclaimed emperor on 25 July 306; died on 22 May 337 at Achyron, near Nicomedia)

(To the right) Statue of Constantine I (the Great), designed by Philip (Henry Christopher) Jackson (1944-Present) in 1998, erected in the same year, and standing since then, outside the South Transept of York Minster in York, near the basilica of the Roman legionary fortress of Eboracum (now York), where Constantine I (the Great) was proclaimed emperor by his army, in 306

The reign of Constantine I (the Great; r. 307-337), known as Constantine, marked one of the principal turning-points in the history of the Roman Empire, the outcome of which still resonates today throughout the Western world. Flavius Valerius Constantinus was the eldest son of (Flavius Valerius) Constantius (later Constantius I; circa 250-306; r. 305-306) by his mistress, or first wife, Flavia Julia Helena (later the Empress Helena; between 246 and 248-330; r. 324-330). He later claimed descent through his father from the Emperor (Marcus Aurelius) Claudius II "Gothicus" (214-270; r. 268-70), but the assertion was politically motivated and is unlikely to have been true. Like his father, he adopted a military career and with Constantius' advancement to imperial rank in 293 the young Constantine was appointed a tribune at the court of (Gaius Aurelius Valerius) Diocletianus (between 242 and 245-311/12; r. 284-305), known as Diocletian, in Nicomedia. In the following years, he served under the eastern Caesar Galerius (Valerius Maximianus; circa 258-311; r. 305-311) in the latterâ€™s campaigns against the Persians (298) and the Sarmatians (299). During this period he probably became acquainted with his future rival, (Valerius Licinianus) Licinius (circa 265-325; r. 308-324), who was a friend and protÃ©gÃ© of Galerius.

At the time of the joint abdications of Diocletian and (Marcus Aurelius Valerius) Maximianus (circa 250-circa 310; r. 286-305), known as Maximian and nicknamed Herculius, in 305, Constantine was still at Nicomedia. The new Roman emperor in the East, Galerius, wished to keep him there in order to ensure peaceful relations with his western colleague Constantius I. But the latter was insistent that Constantine should join him on a military expedition to Britain necessitated by unrest on the northern frontier. Constantiusâ€™ health was beginning to fail and he clearly wanted his son to have an army behind him should his illness prove fatal. Galerius had little choice but to release Constantine. On his long journey westward he took elaborate precautions to avoid assassination at the hands of agents of Galerius or of the western Caesar (Flavius Valerius) Severus (later Severus II; circa 250-307; r. 306-307). Reunited with his father at Boulogne in Gaul, Constantine accompanied him on the gruelling campaign against the Picts. As Constantiusâ€™ health further deteriorated his son took command of the army with whom he rapidly became very popular, doubtless all part of his fatherâ€™s plan. At the legionary fortress of Eboracum (now York) on 25 July 306 Constantius died: the Emperor (Lucius) Septimius Severus (145-211; r. 193-211) had passed away in the same place just 95 years before. The death of Constantius after less than fifteen months of rule was to have devastating consequences for the delicate balance of power created by Diocletianâ€™s tetrarchy system and was ultimately to lead to its total collapse. Eighteen years later the Roman Empire was, once again, to come under the rule of a single Augustus in the person of Constantiusâ€™ son, Constantine I (the Great). However, at the time of his fatherâ€™s death, and for a number of years afterwards, Constantineâ€™s position was not strong and, like the first Augustus three and a half centuries before, he had to tread warily in his dealings with more powerful rivals. But by the skilful use of alliances he gradually strengthened his position until he could finally assert his supremacy in the complex political arena of the early 4th century.

Constantineâ€™s soldiers in Britain immediately proclaimed him emperor in succession to his late father, but Constantine "refused". Inevitably, this would have led to civil war with Galerius, so Constantine accepted the junior imperial rank of Caesar under the new Roman emperor in the West, Severus II, thus preserving the form of the tetrarchy. When Severus IIâ€™s authority in Rome was challenged by the uprising of (Marcus Aurelius Valerius) Maxentius (circa 283-312; r. 306-312) (soon to be joined by his father, the former Roman emperor in the West, Maximian) Constantine did not come to the assistance of his imperial colleague. Instead, he remained aloof while Severus II was defeated by the rebel alliance. Galeriusâ€™ subsequent invasion of Italy also failed to overcome the insurgency and Galerius was obliged to beat a hasty retreat. Again, Constantine had remained indifferent to the conflict and was even negotiating an alliance with the rebel regime. In the early spring of 307 Maximian paid a visit to the court of the western Caesar in Gaul and the resulting treaty was sealed by the marriage of Constantine to Maximianâ€™s daughter (Flavia Maxima) Fausta (circa 290-326), sister of Maxentius. In the late summer, Constantine adopted the title and rank of Augustus, though he was not accepted as such in the East until 310. The tetrarchy system was now fatally disrupted. Galerius made one final attempt to restore it towards the close of 308 when he convened the "Conference of Carnuntum". But his high-handed elevation of his friend Licinius to the rank of Augustus, over the heads of Constantine and his adopted son (Galerius Valerius) Maximinus (Daza; circa 270-313; r. 310-313), doomed the effort to failure. In order to appease them, Galerius offered the empty title of filii Augustorum ("sons of the Augusti"), but this was clearly unacceptable and by 310 both were regarded as full Augusti throughout the Empire. Before the "Conference of Carnuntum", Maximian had quarrelled with his son Maxentius and had been obliged to flee to Constantine in Gaul, where he remained for the following two years. In 310 he foolishly led an abortive uprising against his son-in-law which was revealed by his own daughter, Constantineâ€™s wife Fausta. Maximian was either forced to commit suicide or was executed for treason.

Galeriusâ€™ death from natural causes in 311, left only three legitimate Augusti (Constantine, Licinius, and Maximinus) and the usurper Maxentius in Italy. Constantine now decided it was time to eliminate his brother-in-law Maxentius and made preparations for war. He invaded Italy in the late summer of 312 and advanced on Rome, where Maxentius had decided to make his stand. The battle of the Milvian Bridge, on the sixth anniversary of Maxentiusâ€™ rule (28 October), was chiefly notable for Constantineâ€™s supposed "vision of the cross" on the previous night. Whatever the truth of this story, something certainly revolutionised his religious policy at this time, bringing about the rapid demise of belief in the old pagan gods and goddesses and its replacement by devotion to the teachings of the Christian Church. Meanwhile in the East, there was a growing rivalry between Licinius and Maximinus. The latter felt himself threatened when Constantine and Licinius jointly promulgated at Milan the edict on religious toleration and had sealed their accord by the marriage of Licinius to Constantineâ€™s half-sister, (Flavia Julia) Constantia (after 293-circa 330; r. 313-324). Maximinus invaded Liciniusâ€™ territory in the early spring of 313 and was totally defeated in a pitched battle fought on 30 April. Out of the political chaos resulting from the collapse of Diocletianâ€™s elaborately conceived tetrarchy system just two emperors now remained as potential rivals, Constantine in the West and Licinius in the East. Remarkably, this fragile status quo was maintained for the following thirteen years, though there were frequent disagreements between the Augusti and on two occasions (316-17 and 324) war was actually declared. During the First Licinian War the Roman emperor in the East audaciously elevated one of his generals, (Aurelius) Valerius Valens (?-317; r. 316-317), to the rank of co-emperor to replace Constantine. This bold move was to cost Licinius most of his European territory when peace was eventually patched up between the two rivals, while the unfortunate Valens had to pay with his life. Constantine now kept a close watch on the activities of Licinius and was clearly biding his time, awaiting an ideal opportunity for the removal of his troublesome colleague. The chance came in 322/3 when Gothic invaders entered Thrace and were promptly confronted by Constantine, who happened to be closer to the affected area than Licinius. Thrace being within his sphere of influence, Licinius interpreted this action as a declaration of war, just as Constantine had intended. Hostilities again broke out between the rivals and this time Constantine was decisively victorious, Licinius being deposed from power shortly after the disastrous battle of Chrysopolis (18 September 324). As in the case of the previous civil war, Licinius had elevated a co-emperor, Martinianus (?-325; r. 324), known as Martinian, to assist him in the struggle against Constantine. Following Chrysopolis, both dethroned emperors were imprisoned and the following year they were executed, despite Constantineâ€™s promise to Liciniusâ€™ wife Constantia to spare their lives.

After eighteen years of imperial power Constantine at last found himself sole Augustus, the first ruler to be in this position since Diocletian had succeeded (Marcus Aurelius) Carinus (?-285; r. 283-285) in the spring of 285. He remained sole Augustus for the next thirteen years, until his death in 337 at the age of 65. During this final phase of his reign he focused on a number of domestic issues, though he remained militarily active right up to the end and was even preparing for war against the Sasanid Persians at the time his death. Having espoused Christianity as early as 312, Constantine now made efforts to secure the unity of the Church through convening the Council of Nicaea (the First Ecumenical Council) in 325. This was to establish an orthodox belief formula which all Christians were supposed to accept. The seeds of dissent in the new state religion were thus sown at a very early stage, as many believers followed the teachings of the heretical Alexandrian priest Arius (250 or 256-336). Another event of momentous importance in the closing years of Constantineâ€™s reign was the foundation of a new imperial capital in the East, on the site of the ancient Greek city of Byzantium on the European side of the Bosporus. The decision to found the city of Constantinopolis was probably made as early as 324, just after the defeat of Licinius, though the official dedication only took place on 11 May 330. In future ages the city was to be of immense importance as the capital of the Christian Roman (later Byzantine) Empire and the bastion of European Christendom against the western spread of Islam.

Constantine also gave careful attention to the question of the succession, though his precise intentions in this regard are difficult to ascertain. It is possible that he may have been endeavouring to restore the tetrarchy system on the Diocletianic model, illogical as that may seem in the light of Constantineâ€™s own experiences in his rise to power. Constantine had four sons, Crispus (circa 300-326), by his first wife Minervina, Constantine II (316-340; r. 337-340), probably illegitimate, Constantius II (317-361; r. 337-361), and Constans (320 or 323-350; r. 337-350), by Fausta. He also had two daughters, (Flavia Valeria) Constantina (between 307 and 317-354) and Helena (?-360, r. 360). The picture is further complicated by the existence of three half-brothers and three half-sisters, his fatherâ€™s issue by his second wife (Flavia Maximiana) Theodora (?-337; r. 305-306), the step-daughter of Maximian. One of these half-brothers, (Flavius) Dalmatius (or Delmatius; after 293-337), had two sons, one named after himself (Flavius) Dalmatius (or Delmatius; ?-337), the other named (Flavius) Hannibalianus (or Hanniballianus; ?-337) after an uncle. These two brothers were thus nephews of Constantine. Crispus, who was probably the most capable of Constantineâ€™s sons, was eliminated early from the succession when he was executed in 326, having been found guilty of treason. The circumstances of this tragic incident remain unclear, but it appears in some way to have involved Constantineâ€™s second wife Fausta. The empress doubtless saw Crispus as a threat to the advancement of her own two sons, Constantius II and Constans, and perhaps fabricated the evidence against her stepson. Filled with remorse for his hasty action against his eldest son, Constantine then condemned his wife to death and she was suffocated in a hot bath. Constantineâ€™s second eldest son, also named Constantine, was born in 317 and was almost immediately raised to the rank of Caesar. His half-brother Crispus and their cousin Licinius II (315-circa 326), also called Licinius Junior, son of the Roman Emperor in the East, Licinius, were similarly elevated on the same day (1 March). It appears that Constantine II must have been illegitimate as Fausta gave birth to Constantius II just six months later. Constans, the youngest son of Constantine, was born either in 320 or 323. Both of the sons of Fausta were proclaimed Caesar, in 324 and 333, respectively. In 337 Constantine I thus had three living sons bearing the rank of Caesar; but two years earlier he had also elevated his nephew Dalmatius (Delmatius) to the same rank and had granted Dalmatiusâ€™ brother, Hannibalianus, the extraordinary title of "Rex regum" ("King of kings") with authority over Pontus and Armenia. Doubtless, this represented an initial move in the projected campaign against the Sasanid Persians. Death may have come suddenly and unexpectedly to Constantine I on 22 May, but in truth he left behind him a potentially explosive situation with regard to the succession â€“ no fewer than five contenders for power, all of whom were in their teens or early twenties. Given Constantineâ€™s own experiences in asserting his supremacy over numerous rivals for imperial office, it is hard to imagine how he could have thought that his arrangements for the succession would have a happy outcome. On his deathbed, at Achyron, near Nicomedia, the first Christian emperor was baptised by the Arian bishop Eusebius (between 260 and 265-339). Like his mother, (Flavia Julia) Helena (circa between 246 and 248-330), he was later to be declared a Christian saint and their feast day is still celebrated in the Orthodox Church on 21st May. Constantine is also regarded as the Thirteenth Apostle, a measure of the Churchâ€™s recognition of the vital role he had played in the advancement of Christianity from a persecuted minority sect to a world religion.

+ AD 0276 - Roman Empire - Antoninianus (Aurelianianus) - Probus:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Empire (-27-395); Crisis of the Third Century (235-284)
Ruler: Probus (276-282)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Bust of Probus, facing right, seen from three quarters forward, radiate, cuirassed (Bastien "Type B", RIC "Type F", and RCV "Type A"), with a knot on the left shoulder retaining a military cloak
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) IMPCMAVRPROBVSAVG (IMP C M AVR PROBVS AVG)
Traduction: Supreme military commander (Imperator), Caesar Marcus Aurelius Probus, Emperor (Augustus) (Imperator Caesar Marcus Aurelius Probus Augustus)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Laetitia (Roman goddess and personification of joy), draped, holding a wreath with the right hand and an anchor (in the form of a stylised staff) with the left hand, standing left on a base, the officina mark (IIII) below in exergue
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 07h) LAETITIAAVG (LAETITIA AVG)
Traduction: Joy of the Emperor (Laetitia Augusti)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin has been sent to NGC for grading. The grade that I expected it would receive was Ch MS; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 4/5; silvering. The grade that it received was MSâ˜…; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 5/5; silvering, which met somehow my expectation.
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (â†º, 01h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R3 Material: Silver
Year: 276 (not dated) Fineness: 45
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 3.07; Expected: 3.7
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 22
Unit: Antoninianus (Reform of Caracalla; 215-301) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Lugdunum Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 276
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients MSâ˜…; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 5/5; Attribute(s): silvering (NGC) Variety: LAETITIA AVG
References: Bastien#173; RIC5_2#31; RCV3#11990; Cohen6#324; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.5.pro.31; MRK#112.45
Varieties:

There are two varieties, for which the lettering on the reverse read "LAETITIA AVGVSTI" (Bastien#172 and Cohen6#329) and "LAETITIA AVG" (Bastien#173 and Cohen6#324).

This coin is classified as RIC Period I (mint-marks as numerals and portraits resembling Florianus) and Bastien Emission 2, 2nd Phase, November to December 276 (portraits resembling Florianus).
Note:

In 274, Aurelian undertook an important reform of the coinage which, under his immediate predecessors, had suffered a catastrophic decline. Three years earlier his eradication of abuses in the practices of the Rome mint had led to a revolt of the moneyers which seems to have brought about the temporary closure of the facility. Between 271 and 274 an interim improvement in the quality of the billon coinage saw a small increase in the average weight of the coins and an insistence on the employment of higher standards in their production. Finally, the full reform of 274 saw an increase in the average weight of the antoninianus to about 3.85 g and an improvement in its silver content to 4.5%. The reformed antoninianus also normally bore the mark of value XXI (or KA in Greek numerals at some mints), which is usually taken to mean that the coin was worth 1/20th of its equivalent weight in pure silver. Some scholars have preferred to assign the somewhat awkward name of "aurelianianus" (or "Aurelianus") to the reformed antoninianus. However, there seems no pressing need to depart from the traditional nomenclature simply because Aurelian had enacted a much-needed reform of a long-established denomination that had undergone a series of debasements over the preceding decades. Other denominations featured in Aurelian's reformed coinage were a smaller billon piece with laureate portrait, probably a denarius; a laureate bronze coin, usually regarded as a sestertius of reduced weight; and a larger radiate bronze, probably a reduced double sestertius.

With the restoration of the Empire to its full territorial extent during Aurelianâ€™s reign, the system of mints was inevitably expanded. In Italy Rome was initially augmented by Milan, but in 274 the mint establishment was transferred to nearby Ticinum. With the conquest of the Gallic Empire in the same year the rebel mints of Cologne and Mainz (or Trier) were closed and were replaced by Lugdunum, which had not been active since the rebellion of Clodius Albinus eight decades before. In the militarily important region of the Balkans the products of Siscia were augmented by a new establishment at Serdica, noted for its idiosyncratic obverse legends, and also by a mint the precise location of which has yet to be determined. Cyzicus continued to be active in Asia Minor while Antioch, liberated from the control of the Palmyrene Empire in 272, resumed its role as the major producer of currency in the eastern Mediterranean area. It was assisted by a new mint opened by Aurelian about 273 and attributed to the Phoenician city of Tripolis.

The vast antoninianus coinage of Probus is of exceptional interest and the system of mint marks employed is of considerable complexity. Another interesting feature of Probus' coinage, which provided a limited foretaste of future developments under the Tetrarchy, was the expansion of mint marks in some issues to include the initial letter or letters of the mint name. But perhaps the most noteworthy characteristic, on antoniniani (and aurei), was the dramatic proliferation of obverse bust varieties, unmatched by the coinage of any other reign, to include numerous left-facing military types and others showing the emperor in an elaborate imperial mantle and holding an eagle-tipped sceptre. Such busts had appeared under previous emperors and were to recur occasionally in succeeding reigns, but they were always limited issues, which are rare today. Under Probus, however, they formed part of the regular output of many of the mints.
Historical notes:

(Marcus Aurelius) Probus (born circa 232 in Sirmium; proclaimed emperor in 276; died in autumn 282 near Sirmium)

(To the right) Bust of Probus, sculpted by an unknown artist between 276 and 282, displayed in the Hall of the Emperors of the Palazzo Nuovo in Rome

Probus, the son of a military tribune, had a brilliant military career spanning the reigns of Valerian (253-260) to Tacitus (275-276) and attained the highest eminence as a general. It was under the reign of Aurelian (270-275) that he became one of the premier general of the Empire. Under the reign Tacitus he received the supreme command in the East, a powerful and highly prestigious posting. Soon after the death of Tacitus, Probus was proclaimed emperor by his troops. Probus had little difficulty in overcoming the feeble opposition of Florianus, the younger half-brother of the late-emperor Tacitus, who had assumed the imperial power, and his election was confirmed by the Senate in 276.

Probus then proceeded to repel a series of barbarian threats to the imperial frontiers: Alamannic and Frankish invaders were expelled across the Rhine frontier; the Burgundians and Vandals were defeated in Raetia; the Sarmatians and the Scythians were crushed in Thrace; the Pamphylian looters and pirates were eliminated in Asia Minor; the Blemmyes invasions were stopped in Africa. By 280 he was able to turn his attention to the East where his primary objective was to confront the Sasanid Persians. However, he had to face the usurpations of Saturninus, Bonosus and Proculus. In the meantime, he signed a peace treaty with the Persian shahanshah Bahram II (?-293; r. 274-293). Having triumphed over all his opponents, Probus returned to Rome in 281 and celebrated his victories. Before preparing a new expedition against the Sasanid Persians, he fell victim to the wrath of his own soldiers while supervising a land reclamation project near Sirmium in 282.

+ AD 0212 - Roman Empire - Denarius - Caracalla:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Empire (-27-395); Civil Wars and the Early Severans (193-217)
Ruler: Caracalla (198-217)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Laureate head of Caracalla, bearded, facing right
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 05h) ANTONINVSPIVS AVGBRIT (ANTONINVS PIVS AVG BRIT)
Traduction: Antoninus Pius, Emperor (Augustus), victor in Britannia (Antoninus Pius Augustus Britannicus)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Elephant, cuirassed, walking right, on a base
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) PMTRPXVCOSIIIPP (P M TR P XV COS III P P), with "XV" re-engraved over "XIIII"
Traduction: Greatest of the Pontifices, holder of tribunician power for the 15th time, consul for the third time, father of the patria (Pontifex Maximus, Tribunicia Potestate Quinta Decima, Consul Tertium, Pater Patriae)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin was submitted to NGC for grading. The grade that I expected it would receive was XF; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 4/5. The grade that it received was Ch XF; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 4/5, which exceeded my expectation.

This coin makes me think of my son Louis. ğŸ¦“
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (â†º, 06h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R Material: Silver
Year: 212 (not dated) Fineness: 515
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 3.27; Expected: 3.2
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Measured: 19; Expected: 18
Unit: Denarius (Reform of Augustus; -27-215) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Roma Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 212
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients Ch XF; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 4/5 (NGC) Variety: None
References: RIC4_1#199; RCV2#6827; RSC3#208; Cohen4#208; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.4.crl.199; MRK#51.85
Varieties:

None
Note:

As coinage in the name of Caracalla did not commence until 196 his issues from the temporary eastern mints are limited to those of Laodicea in Syria and the enigmatic cistophori from the unidentified city in Asia. After the closure of Laodicea in 202 all of Caracalla's subsequent coinage is from the mint of Rome, eastern issues not resuming until the rebellion of Elagabalus against Caracalla's successor Macrinus. The portraiture displayed on Caracalla's coinage is of considerable interest, as it follows closely his physical development from a young boy of eight through adolescence and early manhood, to the full maturity of his final years. That of his younger brother shows a similar progression, though in his case it does not become so fully developed. Geta being only in his 23rd year at the time of his murder.

In 215, during his sole reign, Caracalla reformed the monetary system to finance ever increasing imperial expenditures by introducing the antoninianus, named after Caracalla's official name "Antoninus". The newly introduced antoninianus had the same silver purity as the denarius (51.5%) but weighed 5.1 g, compared to 3.23 g for the denarius. Although its silver content was only equivalent to about one and a half denarii, the antoninianus was apparently officially tariffed as the equivalent of two. For this reason, it is sometimes referred to as "double-denarius". This new coin always shows the emperor wearing the radiate crown instead of the laurel wreath of the denarius. In the case of empresses, the coin is distinguished by the addition of a crescent placed beneath the bust. It was initially mostly silver, but was slowly debased, following the trend of the debasement of silver during the Severan dynasty (193-235), to bronze with a minimal silver content (see Pense, 1992). Elagabalus demonetised the antoninianus in 219 in favour of the denarius. The antoninianus was re-introduced in 238 by Gordian III who, in turn, saw to it intentionally or otherwise that the denarius would be phased out for good.
Historical notes:

Marcus Aurelius Antoninus (born on 4 April 188 in Lugdunum; accession on 28 January 198; died on 8 April 217)

(To the top right) Bust of Caracalla, sculpted by an unknown artist between 212 and 215, displayed in the Palazzo Massimo of the Museo Nazionale Romano in Rome

Born Lucius Septimius Bassianus, the elder of the two sons of (Lucius) Septimius Severus (145-211; r. 193-211) and Julia Domna (circa 160-217; r. 193-211), was born on 4 April 188 at Lugdunum (now Lyon), where his father was serving as governor of Gallia Lugdunensis. The name Bassianus was that of his maternal grandfather, who was high priest of the sun-god Elah-Gabal at the Syrian city of Emesa. The nickname "Caracalla" or "Caracallus" derived from a hooded cloak of Gallic origin which he adopted as his favourite dress during his later years. Towards the end of 195 Septimius Severus (who had ascended the Imperial throne two and a half years before) adopted himself into the Antonine dynasty and changed the name of his elder son to Marcus Aurelius Antoninus, raising him to the rank of Caesar. This, of course, led to civil war with the existing Caesar, (Decimus) Clodius Albinus (circa 150-197), who had been given the junior Imperial title soon after Septimius Severus' accession with the promise of eventual inheritance of the throne. Following Septimius Severus' capture of the Parthian capital of Ctesiphon early in 198, Caracalla was further advanced to the rank of Augustus and co-emperor, his younger brother Geta (189-211; r. 209-211) taking his place as Caesar at the same time. Even though he was less than a year younger than Caracalla, Geta was not made Augustus for a further eleven years, until 209. This was a serious mistake on Septimius Severus' part, which doubtless exacerbated the growing rivalry and mutual antipathy of the two brothers. On the return of the Imperial family to Rome in 202, following an extended absence in the East, the 14-year-old Caracalla was married to (Publia Fulvia) Plautilla (?-211; r. 202-205), daughter of the influential praetorian prefect (Gaius or Lucius Fulvius) Plautianus (circa 150-205). The young man hated his father-in-law and disliked his haughty daughter, so it may be doubted whether the 3-year marriage was ever consummated. Plautilla shared her father's downfall in 205 though, unlike the prefect, escaped with her life for the time being.

In 208 the entire Imperial family departed for Britannia where they were to remain until Septimius Severus death early in 211. Caracalla gained much military experience at this time campaigning with his father in the wild country of Caledonia, far beyond the northern frontier of the Roman province. As Septimius Severus' health continued to decline his elder son played an increasingly prominent role in the prosecution of the war whilst Geta remained further south gaining administrative experience in Ebaracum (now York) and Londinium (now London), the provincial capital. All three emperors, however, received the title of Britannicus in honour of the victories over the barbarians of the north.

With the removal of their father's firm hand in February 211 the fraternal strife of Caracalla and Geta escalated rapidly. On their return to Rome they physically divided the palace between them, posting armed guards at every crossing point. This absurd situation clearly could not last and near the end of the year (probably on 26 December 211) Geta was lured to a meeting of reconciliation by his brother during the course of which he was treacherously murdered. After a mass extermination of thousands of those who had supposedly supported his younger brother, Caracalla spent much of his half decade of sole rule away from the capital. He campaigned in Germania in 213-214, receiving the title Germanicus for his achievements, and then headed east for his projected conquest of Parthia. Driven by a crazed obsession to emulate Alexander III of Macedon (356-323 BC), known as Alexander the Great, his physical and mental health began to deteriorate and he even visited the famous shrine of Asklepios at Pergamum in the hope of finding cures for his numerous ailments. In 215 he established his military headquarters at the Syrian capital of Antioch, accompanied by his mother Julia Domna, who was by now virtually running the Imperial government. Rejected in his outlandish request to receive the hand in marriage of the daughter of the Parthian monarch Artabanus IV (?-224; r. 213-224), Caracalla prepared to attack the rival empire. It is doubtful whether he would have achieved any spectacular and lasting conquests, but in any case the opportunity was denied him by the assassin's hand on the road between the Mesopotamian cities of Edessa and Carrhoe on 8 April 217. He had reigned for almost two decades and was still under 30 years of age. Perhaps his most notable act â€“ whatever the motives â€“ was the granting of Roman citizenship to virtually every free inhabitant of the Empire under the terms of the Constitutio Antoniniana.

(To the bottom right) Photography of Joseph Markowitz (1897-1981), taken by an anonym

Joseph Markowitz was born into a Jewish family in Hungary and later moved to the town of VrÅ¡ac, then part of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia, in what is today Serbia. Together with his relatives, he was involved in a family firm known as Markowitz Brothers, active in the fur trade and leather tanning. It was in this setting â€“ shaped by enterprise, family tradition, and cultural exchange â€“ that his interest in ancient coins began to take root.

In 1930, he married Rosa, and the family later relocated to Belgrade amid growing political tensions. At some point before the outbreak of war, Joseph Markowitz began building a coin collection, focusing particularly on Roman silver. When he was drafted into the Yugoslav army, he hid the collection in the basement of the family home â€“ a quiet act of foresight in uncertain times.

During the war, Joseph Markowitz was taken prisoner by German forces. Rosa, left alone with their young son Chaim, was forced to flee Belgrade as the persecution of Jews intensified. Like so many Jewish families in the region, they were escaping the horrors of the Holocaust, which would ultimately lead to the annihilation of the Jewish community in VrÅ¡ac â€“ a community that did not survive.

The family home in Belgrade was later destroyed during bombing raids. After the war, Rosa and Chaim returned to the devastated city. In the rubble of their former home, they searched for what remained â€“ and incredibly, in the ruins of the basement, they found the hidden coin collection, still intact. It had survived when so much else had been lost.

In 1949, the family emigrated to the newly founded State of Israel, bringing the rescued collection with them. They settled in Herzliya, where Joseph quietly rebuilt his life. He continued to care for and expand his collection with great dedication until his death in 1981.

The Joseph Markowitz Collection consists primarily of Roman silver coins, preserved over decades with scholarly care. It reflects not only Joseph Markowitz's love of history and ancient culture, but also a deeply personal journey â€“ shaped by displacement, resilience, and the will to remember.

Leu Numismatik AG offered the collection (702 individual lots and 16 larger lots) at auction on 5â€“8 July 2025, in the hopes that its dispersal might inspire other numismatists to continue in their efforts and to enable further study into history and ancient culture, and to share the story of a man who, in the face of devastation, carried forward a world that others tried to destroy â€“ and who chose to preserve knowledge, memory, and meaning through the language of coins.

+ AD 0162 - Roman Empire - Denarius - Marcus Aurelius:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Empire (-27-395); Nervaâ€“Antonine dynasty (96-192)
Ruler: Marcus Aurelius (161-180)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Bust of Marcus Aurelius, facing right, bare headed
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 07h) IMPMAVRELANTONINVSAVG (IMP M AVREL ANTONINVS AVG)
Traduction: Supreme military commander (Imperator), Marcus Aurelius Antoninus, Emperor (Augustus) (Imperator Marcus Aurelius Antoninus Augustus)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Concordia (Roman goddess and personification of harmony) seated left on a stool, draped, holding a patera in the right hand with the arm extended and resting the left forearm on a statuette of Spes (Roman goddess and personification of hope) which appears to form the backrest of the seat, a cornucopia below the seat
