This coin makes me think of my children LÃ©onie and Louis. ğŸ¦›ğŸ¦“

My son Louis owns 10% of the coin.

Iridescent lustre
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (â†º, 12h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: C Material: Silver
Year: 162 (not dated) Fineness: 790
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 3.59; Expected: 3.2
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 18
Unit: Denarius (Reform of Augustus; -27-215) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Roma Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 162
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients Ch AU; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 5/5 (NGC) Variety: Cornucopia below the seat
References: RIC3#35; RCV2#4882; RSC2#35; Cohen3#35; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.3.m_aur.35; MRK#37.108
Varieties:

There are two varieties, for which the cornucopia is below the seat (RIC3#35) or appears to hold the statuette of Specs further away behind the seat (RIC3#40).
Note:

Following the trend of the debasement of silver introduced by Nero in 64, Marcus Aurelius further devalued the denarius upon his accession in 161 to pay for constant wars and increased expenses. The silver content of the denarius was decreased from 83.5% to 79%, the silver weight dropping from 2.68 g to 2.57 g. In 168, he revalued the denarius, increasing its silver content from 79% to 82%, the silver weight increasing from 2.57 g to 2.67 g. However, two years later he reverted to the previous values because of the military crises facing the empire.

Because of the unprecedented length of time during which Marcus Aurelius bore the junior Imperial rank of Caesar (22 years) his coinage under Antoninus is abundant in the full range of denominations. During his own reign Marcus struck additional issues in the names of his wife Faustina Junior, his daughter Lacilla, his co-emperors Lucius Verus and, later, Commodus, and posthumous issues for Divus Antoninus (161), Divus Verus (169) and Diva Faustina (176). At the very end of the reign (from 178) coins were struck for Crispina, wife of the young co-emperor Commodus. However, as her coinage continued into the sole reign of her husband all issues are normally associated with Commodus.
Historical notes:

Marcus Aurelius (Antoninus) (born on 26 April 121 in Rome; accession on 7 March 161; died on 17 March 180)

(To the right) Busts of the Co-emperors Marcus Aurelius and Lucius Verus, sculpted by an unknown artist between 161 and 170, displayed in Room 70 of the British Museum in London

Originally named Marcus Annius Catilius Severus, the future Emperor Marcus Aurelius Antoninus was born in Rome in 121 and was the nephew of the Empress Faustina Senior, wife of Antoninus Pius (138-161). Following the early death of his father Marcus Annius Verus, brother of the Empress Faustina Senior, in 124, he was brought up in the household of their father and his grandfather, also named Marcus Annius Verus, who had an illustrious public career and was three times consul, a rare distinction for someone outside the Imperial family. The Emperor Hadrian (117-138), who adopted Antoninus Pius, recognised the fine qualities of the youth and arranged for his betrothal to the daughter of Aelius Caesar, who he had also adopted. Later following the death of Aelius Caesar in 138, Hadrian stipulated that the new Caesar, Antoninus Pius, should adopt Marcus Aurelius together with Aelius Caesar's son, Lucius Verus. On the accession of Antoninus Pius in the summer of 138 Marcus Aurelius' career was rapidly advanced and he was even promoted to the rank of Caesar in 139, a clear indication that the new emperor regarded him, rather than Lucius Verus, as the heir to the Imperial throne. The annulment of Marcus Aurelius' betrothal to the daughter of Aelius Caesar provided additional confirmation of Antoninus Pius' intentions, as the young man was now betrothed to the emperor's daughter, Faustina the Younger. In 145 the couple were married and two years later the 26-year-old Caesar was granted the tribunician power. Antoninus Pius survived to the age of 74 and Marcus Aurelius was already in his fortieth year by the time he ascended the throne at his death in 161.

Loyal to the memory of the Emperor Hadrian, one of his first acts as emperor was to associate the younger Lucius Verus with him as co-ruler, thus inaugurating the first joint reign in almost two hundred years of Imperial history. Unfortunately, the experiment was not a resounding success. Lucius Verus proved to be weak and addicted to the pursuit of pleasure and was thus more of a liability than an asset in the demanding task of governing a vast Empire. This merely confirmed Antoninus Pius' earlier judgement and the sudden and untimely death of Lucius Verus in 169 must have come as a considerable relief to Marcus Aurelius. Although gentle and philosophical by nature, Marcus Aurelius was fated to spend long periods of his reign enduring the harsh conditions of military camp life. Throughout the 170s he undertook arduous campaigns on the Rhine and Danube frontiers, where there was much unrest amongst the barbarian tribes, and it was during this trying time that he wrote his celebrated "Meditations" based on the principles of Stoic philosophy. Following the abortive revolt in the East of the general Avidius Cassius in 175, Marcus Aurelius decided to advance his young son Commodus to Imperial status, first as Caesar (175) and then as Augustus and co-emperor late in the following year. Worn out by the cares of state Marcus Aurelius died at the age of 59 in 180 and was succeeded by the 19-year-old co-emperor Commodus. He was immediately deified, an extensive posthumous coinage being issued in his honour. A careful, generous and conscientious autocrat, it has been written of Marcus Aurelius that "in the evening of Rome's greatness her ruler fittingly personified the virtues that had been her glory".

+ AD 0122 - Roman Empire - Denarius - Hadrian:

Open description in new window

Designer: -

Script: Latin

Traduction: Greatest of the Pontifices, holder of tribunician power, consul for the third time (Pontifex Maximus, Tribunicia Potestate, Consul Tertium)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

The front of the NGC holder has a bad scratch, which I believe was caused by mishandling at the eBay International Shipping Hub. The layers of the original packaging must have been opened with a sharp object at the eBay International Shipping Hub, probably to check the contents. I subsequently contacted eBay to report this problem but eBay did not acknowledge any responsability. The only solution proposed by eBay was to return the item for a full refund. Since I had no intention to return the item as I would not be able to find a replacement, I kept the item as is. It can be sent to NGC for reholdering, but I am unlikely to do so since the scratch does not bother me that much.

This coin makes me think of my son Louis. ğŸ¦“
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (â†º, 06h) Technique: Hammered

Unit: Denarius (Reform of Augustus; -27-215) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Roma Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 122
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients AU; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 4/5 (NGC) Variety: None
References: RIC2#113; RCV2#3529var; RSC2#1174C; Cohen2#1174; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.2_3(2).hdn.525; MRK#32.86
Varieties:

Several portrait varieties exist. The details of the galley on the reverse can also vary considerably.
Note:

Hadrian's varied and interesting coinage includes many reverse types commemorating the diversity of the Empire's provinces and the personal interest taken in them by the emperor. Like the bulk of his predessor's issues, the annual advancement of the tribunician power is not recorded in the inscriptions, thereby adding to the difficulties of achieving a precise chronological structure for the coinage. Fortunately, this problem has been overcome by Philip V. Hill in his important work "The Dating and Arrangement of the Undated Coins of Rome, AD 98-148", published in 1970. In addition to coinage in his own name Hadrian produced issues honouring his deified predecessor Trajan, the dowager empress Plotina, his mother-in-law Matidia (both lifetime and posthumous), his wife Sabina, and his first heir Aelius Caesar. Additionally, there was a surprisingly extensive posthumous coinage for his favourite AntinoÃ¼s, produced principally at Alexandria, but also at many other provincial mints.
Historical notes:

(Publius Aelius) Hadrianus (born on 24 January 76 in Italica, Hispania Baetica, Spain; accession on 11 August 117; died on 10 July 138 in Baiae)

(To the top right) Bust of Hadrian, sculpted by an unknown artist between 125 and 130, found in Hadrian's villa in Tibur (modern Tivoli), displayed in the British Museum in London

Publius Aelius Hadrianus, known in english as Hadrian, was born in 76 in Italica, Hispania Baetica, Spain, like his predecessor (Marcus Ulpius) Traianus (53-117; r. 98-117), known in english as Trajan. His father had died when he was still only in his tenth year and he entered the childless household of the future emperor Trajan, eventually marrying Vibia Sabina (83-136 or 137) in 100, daughter of the emperor's favourite niece, Salonia Matidia (68-119). It thus seemed that he had been marked out for the Imperial succession, though no formal adoption ever took place. The young man adopted a military career, serving as tribune of Legiones II Adiatrix and V Macedonica late in the reign of (Titus Flavius) Domitianus (51-96; r. 81-96), known as Domitian, and later as legate of Legio I Minervia during Trajan's Second Dacian War. At the time of Trajan's sudden death in 117 Hadrian was governor of the important province of Syria. After a delay of several days it was announced by the widowed empress Pompeia Plotina (?-121 or 122) that her dying husband had confided to her in secret his desire to adopt Hadrian as his heir. Although there was considerable opposition to the new emperor's accession, especially in senatorial circles, no one dared challenge the word of the late emperor's highly respected consort. In marked contrast to the aristocracy the army was firmly behind him and a reluctant Senate was obliged to ratify what it regarded as a cleverly contrived coup. The hostile relationship between the emperor and the conscript fathers was further exacerbated by the executions of four former consuls, all accused of plotting treason, prior to the new emperor's delayed arrival in Rome in the summer of 118. The philhellene Hadrian had a keen interest in experiencing first hand the diverse people and places of his vast realm. Accordingly, much of his reign was spent in touring virtually all the provinces of the Empire, these peregrinations extending over three great journeys that required his absence from the capital for years at a time. Particular attention was paid to army morale and to frontier defences, his best known undertaking being the construction of the elaborate frontier system in northern England, known as Hadrian's Wall: much of this immense work is still to be seen. The closing years of Hadrian's reign were troubled by a great Jewish uprising known as the Second Revolt or Bar Kokhba War (132-135). This was to result in great loss of life and the rebuilding of Jerusalem as a pagan city (Aelia Capitolina) from which all Jews were excluded. Now in failing health, the emperor retired to his magnificent villa in Tibur (modern Tivoli) to spend his remaining time surrounded by architecture and works of art recalling his travels in the eastern Mediterranean region. Hadrian died in Baiae on 10 July 138 and was succeeded by Titus Aurelius Fulvus Boionius Antoninus (86-161; r. 138-161), soon to be known as Antoninus Pius for his loyal devotion to the memory of his predecessor. The original choice as heir, Lucius Ceionius Commodus (101-138), known as Lucius Aelius Caesar as Imperial heir, had predeceased the emperor on 1 January 138.

(To the bottom right) Photograph of the Sycamore Gap tree (or Robin Hood tree), standing in a dramatic dip in the landscape, next to Hadrian's Wall near Crag Lough (visible in the background) in Northumberland, England, taken by me during an enjoyable walk with my son Louis on 10 August 2022. The 150-year-old sycamore tree was felled in the early morning of 28 September 2023 in what Northumbria Police described as "an act of vandalism". The stump has thrown up seedlings and is still alive, albeit severely coppiced, but is expected to take more than 150 years to recover.

+ AD 0078 - Roman Empire - Denarius - Titus:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Empire (-27-395); Flavian dynasty (69-96)
Ruler: Vespasian (69-79)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Bust of Titus, facing right, laureate
Script: Latin
Lettering: (anticlockwise, starting at 5h) TCAESAR VESPASIANVS (T CAESAR VESPASIANVS)
Traduction: Titus Caesar Vespasianus
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Sow walking left, with three of her youngs (piglets; one ahead below her head, one in between her front and hind legs below her belly and udder, and one behind below her tail), on a base, the inscription "IMPXIII" below in exergue
Script: Latin
Lettering: (in exergue) IMPXIII (IMP XIII)
Traduction: Supreme military commander (Imperator) for the thirteenth time (Imperator Tertium Decimum)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin was submitted to NGC for grading. The grade that I expected it would receive was XFâ˜…; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 5/5 or, more realistically, XF; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 5/5. The grade that it received was Ch VF; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 3/5, which did not quite meet my expectation. I learnt a lesson in the process: eye appeal is to some degree subjective and can affect judgement.

This coin makes me think of my son Louis. ğŸ¦“
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (â†º, 06h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R2 Material: Silver
Year: 78 (not dated) Fineness: 900
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 3.34; Expected: 3.2
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Measured: 19; Expected: 18
Unit: Denarius (Reform of Augustus; -27-215) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Roma Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 78
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients Ch VF; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 3/5 (NGC) Variety: None
References: RIC2#220; RCV1#2443; RSC2#104; Cohen1#104; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.2_1(2).ves.986; MRK#22.23
Varieties:

None
Note:

For several centuries before the rise of Rome there had been a tradition of featuring animals, birds, fish and insects (as well as various mythological beasts) on the coinages of many of the Greek city states. Rome inherited this tradition, and although the representation of fauna is less frequent and varied than on coins of the Greek series, they nevertheless form a most appealing group within the Roman coinage.

Crocodile, heifer, bull, wild boar, lion attacking stag, eagle, crab and butterfly, capricorn, Pegasus and Sphinx all appear on the coinage of Augustus, who was the inheritor of the late Republican tradition of great diversity in the selection of coin types. However, during the course of his long reign that tradition was gradually superseded by a more conservative approach to the type content of the new Imperial coinage. Accordingly, the coinages of the later Julio-Claudian emperors feature virtually no representations of animals, other than the elephants drawing the car of Divus Augustus on a sestertius issued by Tiberius, and the eagle appearing on the reverse of a Divus Augustus as.

The Flavian revival of earlier coin types led to a reintroduction of the tradition of animal depiction on the Imperial coinage. Several types issued in 78 draw from country life. A reverse shows a goat being milked by a goat-herd and another has a sow, with three of her youngs (piglets). These agricultural scenes may be seen as the outline of a programme for the restauration of agricultural prosperity in Italy, of which no detailed record is known. It is worth nothing that little is known about the morphology of domestic pigs and their forms of keeping in ancient Graeco-Roman times from written sources. The depictions of domestic pigs on ancient artefacts such as coins provide important sources of information (see Meyer et al., 2004).

In the 2nd century the Pegasus and the griffin appear on several aes denominations of Hadrian whilst his successor Antoninus Pius struck asses showing an elephant and a sow suckling its young beneath an oak tree, both types probably having reference to the celebrations connected with the 900th anniversary of the foundation of Rome. An attractive representation of a dove appears on an aureus of Antoninus Pius' daughter, the younger Faustina, and elephants occur on an as of Commodus and a denarius of Septimius Severus.

The "king of beasts" is depicted on the coinage of Caracalla, wearing a radiate crown and holding a thunderbolt in its jaws, and several decades later the lion reappears as part of the "Saeculares" series of Philip (I) the Arab. Similarly, the elephant was popular as a coin type during the first half of the 3rd century, appearing on pieces of Caracalla, Geta, and Philip (I) the Arab. To celebrate the millennium (1000th anniversary) of the foundation of Rome in 247-248 Philip (I) the Arab staged magnificent games in which many wild beasts were exhibited in the arenas of the capital. This resulted in a series of coins featuring a gazelle, a European elk (moose), a hippopotamus, a stag, a goat (or hind), and an antelope, in addition to the lion already mentioned. The city's emblem, the she-wolf (suckling the twins Romulus and Remus), also appears as part of this series.

A few years later, during the sole reign of Gallienus (260-268), an extensive series of "animal" reverses was featured on the debased antoninianus denomination. Subsequent to this date such types appear far less frequently and are, in the main, restricted to the "legionary badge" issues of the usurpers Victorinus in Gaul and Carausius in Britannia. The charismatic Carausius also had types showing the milking of a cow, a griffin, and the traditional wolf and twins device.

In the late Empire, the wolf and twins appear on coins of another usurper, Maxentius (306-312), whose policy was to try to revive the past glories of the Imperial capital; and several decades later on small billon pieces (reduced centenionales) of the time of Constantine and his successors. In the mid 4th century a phoenix is shown on half maiorinae of Constantius II and Constans and a very fine representation of a bull, sometimes accompanied by an eagle, occurs on large billon pieces of Julian II towards the end of his short reign (360-67). One of the last animal representations on the Roman coinage is on a tiny bronze numnus of the easter Emperor Leo I (457-474) where a lion appears as a punning allusion to the emperor's name.
Historical notes:

Titus Flavius Vespasianus (born on 30 December 39; accession on 23 June 79; died on 13 September 81)

(To the right) Photograph of a large crowd of Jewish people marching through the Arch of Titus, taken by an anonym on the day of the Declaration of the Establishment of the State of Israel on 14 May 1948. Many of these people were European refugees who were living in camps for "displaced persons" waiting to resettle in Israel. Some people were holding banners in celebration. The message on the banner to the left of the photograph reads "Long Live the Hebrew State" (×ª×—×™ ×”××“×™× ×” ×”×¢×‘×¨×™×ª). It is no accident that the celebration was held by the Arch of Titus, a monument honouring the victory of Titus (Flavius Vespasianus; 39-81; r. 79-81) in Judaea in 70. The monument contains panels depicting the triumphal procession celebrated in 71 after the Roman victory in Judaea, culminating in the fall of Jerusalem. The south inner panel depicts the spoils taken from the (Second) Temple in Jerusalem, also known as the Herod's Temple, including the menorah. The menorah is often used as a symbol representing the Jewish people and Judaism in both the Land of Israel and the Diaspora. It eventually became the official emblem of the State of Israel after its establishment in 1948. The Arch of Titus became a symbol of the exile of the Jewish people, and until the establishment of the State of Israel in 1948 Jewish people followed a tradition not to pass under it. Once the State of Israel was established and the Jewish people could return to their homeland, the tradition was annulled. In fact, this photograph shows the Jewish people passing under the arch in the opposite direction to that of the exiles depicted on the arch. The marchers are seen walking in the direction of Jerusalem, as if they were choosing to leave Rome and declaring their victorious return to the Land of Israel after thousands of years of exile. The Arch of Titus has also provided the general model for many triumphal arches erected since the 16th century. It is for instance the inspiration for the Arc de Triomphe in Paris.

Titus (Flavius Vespasianus) was the elder son of Titus Flavius Vespasianus (9-79; r. 69-79), know as Vespasian, and Flavia Domitilla Major (12-69), known as Domitilla the Elder. He was a close boyhood friend of (Tiberius Claudius Caesar) Britannicus (41-55), son of the Emperor (Tiberius) Claudius (Caesar Augustus Germanicus; 10-54; r. 41-54), with whom he was educated. During the reign of Nero (Claudius Caesar Augustus Germanicus; 37-68; r. 54-68) he served as a military tribune in Germania and Britannia and in 67 accompanied his father to Judaea, where he commanded the Legio XV Apollinaris. When his father made his bid for the imperial throne in 69 Titus was given supreme command over the First Jewishâ€“Roman War. In September 70 he captured Jerusalem, thus effectively ending the Jewish Revolt which had begun four years earlier during the reign of Nero. Although he bore only the junior rank of Caesar throughout Vespasian's reign Titus was, in all other respects, his father's colleague in the rule of the Roman Empire. When Titus returned to Rome in June 71 they celebrated a magnificent joint triumph for the victory in Judaea and Titus was accorded a considerable share in the imperial coinage, with large scale issues in all metals. The share of his younger brother Titus Flavius Domitianus (51-96; r. 81-96), known as Domitian, was considerably smaller and there can be little doubt that the latter felt bitterly resentful of his inferior status (a resentment that was to find expression in the tyranny of Domitian's own reign a decade later). Titus suceeded to the imperial throne on the death of Vespasian on 23 June 79. He reigned for little more than two years, but this brief period witnessed a series of natural disasters. Most famous is the eruption of Vesuvius, which destroyed the towns of Pompeii and Herculaneum in 79, but in the following year in 80 the capital suffered from both plague and a devastating fire. It was in connection with these disasters that Titus issued a series of coins commemorating the services of prayer and propitiation through which he attempted to allay public alarm. One of the rare highlights of the reign was the dedication in June 80 of the great Amphitheatrum Flavium, known as the Colosseum. This magnificent arena, still one of the principal landmarks of modern Rome, had been commenced by Vespasian in 71 on the site of the stagnum (pool), formerly in the gardens of Nero's Golden House. The dedication by Titus was accompanied by lavish celebrations for the Roman populace. Probably exhausted and depressed by his ordeals, Titus died on 13 September 81 at the early age of forty-two. He was succeeded by his younger brother Domitian who, as heir to the throne, had been accorded a considerable coinage in all metals during the reign of Titus.

+ AD 0033 - Roman Empire - Denarius ("Tribute Penny") - Tiberius:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Empire (-27-395); Julioâ€“Claudian dynasty (-27-68)
Ruler: Tiberius (14-37)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Laureate head of Tiberius, facing right (Giard "Group 4")
Script: Latin
Lettering: (anticlockwise, starting at 5h) TICAESARDIVI AVGFAVGVSTVS (TI CAESAR DIVI AVG F AVGVSTVS)
Traduction: Tiberius Caesar, Son of the Divine Augustus, Emperor (Augustus) (Tiberius Caesar Divi Augustus Filius Augustus)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Female figure, who may be identified as Livia (?, Tiberius' mother, Livia Drusilla, who married the triumvir Octavian, who was later to become Rome's first emperor under the name Augustus) or Pax (?, Roman goddess and personification of peace) or Justitia (?, Roman goddess and personification of justice), seated right on a throne with ornate legs, her feet resting on a low footstool, holding vertically a scepter resting on the floor in the right hand and an olive branch in the left hand
Script: Latin
Lettering: (anticlockwise, starting at 10h) MAXIM PONTIF
Traduction: Greatest of the Pontifices (Pontifex Maximus)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin will be sent to NGC for grading. The grade that I expect it will receive is AU; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 4/5.

There is evidence of an unimportant die break on the reverse.

This coin makes me think of my son Louis. ğŸ¦“ It is somewhat a special coin in that I had discussed tens of examples of such "Tribute Penny" with him for a couple of years. Our discussion always revolved around comparing coins struck during the first half of the 1st century. While I was inclined to acquire one of these "Tribute Pennies" for their historical significance, he was not attracted by the reverse design that displays yet another "chair" as we resolved to describe any reverse with a figure seated on a chair.

This coin is called the "Tribute Penny" in numismatics, in reference to the coin that was shown to Jesus Christ in the scene "The Question about Paying Taxes" reported in the three "synoptic" Gospels of Matthew (22.15-22), Mark (12.13-17), and Luke (20.19-26), in the New Testament. In this scene, envoys of Jewish religious and political groups try to trap Jesus Christ by asking him whether or not to pay taxes to the Roman emperor. Jesus qualifies them as "hypocrites", then asks them to show a silver coin that is used to pay these taxes and to tell him who is represented on the coin. They answer that it is Caesar. Jesus then replies to them: "Render unto Caesar the things that are Caesar's, and unto God the things that are God's." The questioners were impressed by the answer and unable to trap Jesus Christ any further.

One interpretation of this scene is that the questioners asking Jesus Christ if taxes should be paid to the Roman emperor were attempting to trap him into admitting his opposition to doing so, and that upon seeing that the coin was a "Tribute Penny", Jesus Christ avoided the trap by saying that it should be given back to Caesar, because it was his anyway.

The original text in Greek identifies the coin as a Î´Î·Î½Î¬ÏÎ¹Î¿Î½ (dÄ“narion), and it is usually thought by scholars that the coin was a Roman denarius with the head of the Roman emperor at this time, Tiberius (Julius Caesar Augustus), who used Caesar as his cognomen, following his two predecessors (Gaius) Julius Caesar and (Gaius Julius Caesar) Augustus. However, it is impossible to determine whether or not Jesus Christ saw this particular type. Denarii in circulation at this time would most probably have included a mix of common Roman Republican, Imperatorial and Imperial types. Besides, it has been suggested by some scholars that denarii were not in common circulation in Judaea during Jesus Christ's lifetime and that the coin may have instead been an Antiochan tetradrachm bearing the head of Tiberius on the obverse and that of Augustus on the reverse (see RPC#4161 and Lewis, 1999a,b).
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (â†º, 04h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: C Material: Silver
Year: 33 (not dated) Fineness: 950
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 3.77; Expected: 3.9
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Measured: 18; Expected: 18
Unit: Denarius (Reform of Augustus; -27-215) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Lugdunum Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 18-35
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients AU; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 4/5 (CCN) Variety: Giard "Group 4"
References: Giard#150; RIC1#30; RCV1#1763; RSC2#16A; Cohen1#16; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.1(2).tib.30; MRK#5.4
Varieties:

Giard divides this type into six groups, based on the evolution of style over time.

Group 1, circa 15-18 â€“ Obverse: Tiberius is depicted as a young man. One of the ribbons of Tiberius' laurel wreath falls over his neck. Reverse: Legs of the throne are plain, the throne is on a raised base represented by a second line above the exergual line, no footstool.

Group 2, circa 15-18 â€“ Obverse: Same as Group 1, except that Tiberius appears older. Reverse: Base under throne (sometimes represented by a triple line, two above the exergue line), Female figure usually holds a reversed spear instead of a scepter, the legs of the throne are ornately decorated, no footstool.

Group 3, circa 18 â€“ Obverse: Same as Group 2. Reverse: Base under the throne is diminished, the ornamentation on the legs of the throne is simplified from Group 2, the female figure's feet rest on a low footstool.

Group 4, circa 18-35 â€“ Obverse: Same as Group 2. Reverse: No base under the throne (just the single exergual line), the female figure usually holds a scepter (or rarely a reversed spear), her feet rest on a low footstool.

Group 5, circa 36-37 â€“ Obverse: The ribbons of Tiberius' laurel wreath fall in small undulations and do not fall over his neck. Tiberius appears older than on Groups 2 to 4. Reverse: Same as Group 4 but the female figure always holds a scepter.

Group 6, circa 36-37 â€“ Obverse: The ribbons of Tiberius' laurel wreath fall more stiffly and usually do not fall over his neck. Tiberius' facial features are older and have become caricatures. Reverse: Same as Group 5.
Note:

Augustus reformed the monetary system between 23 and 15 BC in order to solve the disorder that had been created in Rome's monetary production. Monetary issues were very numerous, thanks to the spoils that the "princeps" had brought back from the new province of Egypt and the Spanish mines, so much so that it resulted in an excess of money, leading to a cut in interest rates and an increase in the value of landed property. The reform brought an end to emergency issues, minted by mobile mints following the various generals of the Roman Empire, as had been the case during the civil wars. The weight of the silver denarius â€“ which remained the reference currency â€“ was restored following a considerable drop during the civil wars. It was now valued 84 to the pound and the gold aureus was valued at 25 denarii and 41 to the pound. The weight of the Roman pound is normally reckoned at 327.45 g, giving the denarius and the aureus theoretical weights in modern terms of 3.90 g and 7.99 g, respectively. Denominations below the denarius were more comprehensively reformed. New ratios were fixed among the currencies: the sestertius was now minted from about an ounce of orichalcum, an alloy of copper and zinc, rather than silver, and fixed at a quarter of a denarius. The dupondius, formerly a two-pound bronze coin, was now orichalcum, valued at half a sestertius and weighing half as much. The half-ounce as, worth half a dupondius, the semis, worth half an as, and the quadrans, worth half a semis, were the pure copper coins. The Augustan currency system was to set the pattern for the Roman Imperial coinage for the first two and a half centuries of its history.

The minting of gold and silver coins was brought under under Augustus' personal control and used the new mint of Lugdunum, while the minting of coins from copper and its alloys was left under senatorial control and used the mint of Rome. The latter coins generally bore the inscription "SC" (Senatus Consultum; "by Decree of the Senate"). The reform also marked the definitive presence of the portrait of a living person on coins.
Historical notes:

Tiberius (Julius Caesar Augustus) (born on 16 November 42 BC in Rome; proclaimed emperor on 17 September AD 14; died on 16 March AD 37 in Misenum)

(To the top right) Bust of Tiberius, sculpted by an unknown artist between 14 and 23, displayed in the MusÃ©e Saint-Raymond in Toulouse

Tiberius was born in -42, the elder son of the aristocratic Tiberius Claudius Nero, whose name he bore, and Livia Drusilla. When he was only three years of age his parents divorced and Livia married the triumvir Octavian, who was later to become Rome's first emperor under the name Augustus. As a young man Tiberius soon proved himself be a most competent general and in a military career which was to span more than three decades (-20-12) he campaigned extensively in many parts of the Empire. His relationship with his stepfather, however, was always strained and his marriage in -11 to Augustus' daughter Julia was most unhappy. This probably contributed to his decision is -6 to go into voluntary exile on the island of Rhodes, where he remained for the following eight years. He returned to Rome in 2 and on the death of Augustus' grandson Gaius Caesar two years later the emperor was reluctantly obliged to adopt Tiberius and acknowledge him as heir to the throne. Ten years later, on the death of Augustus, he became Rome's second emperor. Although an able administrator Tiberius was suspicious and reclusive by nature and always bore a resentment for the unfair treatment which he felt he had received from his stepfather. His reign was marred by a series of tragedies within the imperial family and by the machinations of the powerful praetorian prefect Sejanus who, prior to his downfall in 31, was probably aiming at usurping the imperial power itself. In 26 Tiberius once again retired to island retreat, this time Capreae, and never again set foot in Rome during the remaining eleven years of his life. He died at Misenum on 16 March 37 in his seventy-ninth year and was succeeded by his great-nephew Caligula. His own son, Drusus, had died fourteen years before, probably a victim of Sejanus.

(To the bottom right) The Tribute Money, painted by Tiziano Vecellio (circa 1488-1576), Latinized as Titianus and known in English as Titian, circa 1516, for Alfonso I d'Este (1476-1534), Duke of Ferrara, Modena, and Reggio from 1505 until his death in 1534, displayed in the GemÃ¤ldegalerie Alte Meister in Dresden, Germany. The painting depicts the biblical scene "The Question about Paying Taxes", which is rare in art. Titian may have been the first artist to represent this biblical scene in this painting. That painting served as a cupboard door for the Duke's collection of ancient coins and medals.

BoÃ®te no 02 :

â†’ Avant l'Ã¨re Â« commune Â» :

+ 0048 BC - Roman Empire - Denarius - Lucius Hostilius Saserna:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Republic (509-27 BC); Roman Imperatorial period (49-27 BC)
Ruler: Caesar (-49-44)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Bust of a captive Gallic male warrior (Vercingetorix?), facing right, draped, with beard pointing right and bristling hair, a chain around the neck, a Gallic shield behind, the field surrounded by a grÃ¨netis
Script: -
Lettering: -
Traduction: -
Designer: -

Director: Lucius Hostilius Saserna (48 BC)

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Naked Gallic warrior, facing backwards, holding a shield with the left hand and wielding a spear with the right hand, in a biga galloping right, driven by a charioteer holding a raising whip with the right hand and the reins with the left hand, with divided director (moneyer)'s name (LÂ·HOSTILIVS SASERN or SASERNA) above and below in exergue, the field surrounded by a grÃ¨netis
Script: -
Lettering: -
Traduction: -
Designer: -

Director: Lucius Hostilius Saserna (48 BC)

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin was submitted to NGC for grading. The grade that I expected it would receive was F or, more realistically, VG; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 3/5; bankers marks. The grade that it received was VG; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 2/5; bankers marks, which did not quite meet my expectation. I had requested NGC to include the pedigree to the Helmingham Hoard on the certification label, but my request was not fulfilled. I subsequently contacted NGC to find out what happened with this request and NGC acknowledged that that was this oversight at their end. The certification label was then corrected at no charge to include the pedigree to the Helmingham Hoard.

This coin makes me think of my son Louis. ğŸ¦“

My son Louis owns 10% of the coin.

This coin was recorded as coin No. 680 of the Helmingham Hoard, which was discovered at a find spot with Historic Environment Record (HER), formerly Sites and Monuments Record (SMR), "HLM 050", maintained by the Suffolk Archaeological Service. The data from record has not been made public by the Suffolk Archaeological Service at the request of the landowner, most probably to prevent looters from invading the site of the find. The coin was subsequently catalogued as coin No. 259 by Ghey, the curator of hoards in the Department of Money and Medals at the British Museum in London. The full catalogue is available at the British Museum.

On 9 September of 2019, George Ridgway made a discovery of great historical and numismatic importance: the Helmingham Hoard of British Iron Age and Roman coins. An avid treasure hunter from a tender age â€“ having received his first metal detector at just 12 years old as a gift from his grandmother â€“ George Ridgway was drawn to Helmingham Hall in Suffolk, by its historical significance. Happily, Helmingham Hallâ€™s residents shared his passion for the past, and he was granted private permission to detect the grounds. At the request of the landowner, the exact find spot is to remain undisclosed. However, it can be said that the hoard was found in a field close to a Roman road and that it has produced a general assemblage of Roman material. It can also be said that it was found close to a "small oddly shaped crop-circle"; this feature later transpired to be a natural pond, filled in during the course of agricultural work in the 19th century.

The day of discovery started with a scattering of Roman brooches, several of which have been dated to the first century, making them roughly contemporary with the hoard. Some 30 yards down the field came the first coin: a denarius of (Julius) Caesar, which poked its head up and was revealed. Over the next three hours, 206 coins (including the first coin) were found, spread across an area of approximately one and a half metres. George Ridgway, well aware of the significance of this find, was keen that it be properly recorded and assessed for archaeological significance. The local archaeologist was notified and George Ridgwayâ€™s father offered to camp at the site and keep watch; he stayed for two nights standing guard to protect the hoard. Shortly after, an extensive three-month-long archaeological dig was undertaken; this yielded a further 205 coins, with 314 more (including this coin) being found in the same archeological context (0001) during controlled metal detecting of the site within a 60-yard radius of the initial find. George Ridgway diligently returned to the site on 1st October 2020 and in 2021, finding a further 9 and 14 coins, respectively. All together, 748 coins were found: one Roman gold aureus of (Tiberius) Claudius (Caesar Augustus Germanicus; -10-54; r. 41-54), 724 Roman silver denarii, 19 British Iron Age gold staters and 4 quarter staters of the pre-Roman Britain king and chieftain of the Catuvellauni, Cunobelin (?-circa 40; r. circa 9-circa 40). This makes this hoard the largest mixed hoard of British Iron Age and Roman coins found to date in Britain.

Sherds of pottery were found near the corner of the field, in very close proximity to one of the denarii. Almost all the sherds are likely to belong to the same vessel, which probably contained the hoard; they are fragments of a grey ware bowl or jug. Among the grey ware fragments an undiagnostic, probably construction building material, fragment was also found.

The hoard was taken to the British Museum in London where the coins were conserved and catalogued, following the application of the 1996 Treasure Act, as Treasure case Nos. 2019T794, 2020T915 and 2021T655, for the finds in 2019, 2020 and 2021, respectively. The finds were recorded with the Portable Antiquities Scheme (PAS; see https://finds.org.uk) with record IDs SF-8C645E, SF-521A7C and SF-AEA396, respectively. Sixty three coins were retained by various museums, with the rest being returned in early 2024 to the finder and landowners, who brought them to Noonans shortly after. Noonans offered 666 coins of the hoard (235 coins as individual lots and 431 coins as part of larger lots) at auction on 18 September 2024, in the hopes that its dispersal might inspire other treasure hunters and numismatists to continue in their efforts and to enable further study into this important part of Britain's history. When asked what he will do with the money raised from the auction, after splitting it with the landowners, George Ridgway said he will buy his dad a pint!

The earliest coin in the hoard is a denarius of the Roman Republic issued circa 206-195 BC and the latest are two denarii of Claudius issued in 46-47. The terminus post quem for the burial hoard is therefore 46-47, during the rule of the Roman emperor Claudius, just a few years after the beginning of the Roman conquest of Britain. The Claudian invasion of Britain began in 43, with the forces initially led by (Aulus) Plautius (?-before 65). By 47 Plautius had conquered and negotiated treaties with many of the southern tribes, only to be replaced in his role by (Publius) Ostorius (Scapula; ?-52). Early in 47 Ostorius introduced into law the compulsory disarmament of the British tribes, with exception granted for hunting equipment. Unsurprisingly, this was not well received by the subjugated locals; a guerrilla campaign ensued and the western tribes led by Caratacus (circa 10-circa 50; r. circa 40-50), the son of Cunobelin, and king and chieftain of the Catuvellauni, marched eastwards to face the Romans. Ostorius, in response, prepared his men for battle. Today this series of events is known as the Iceni Revolt of 47. Almost everyone, historian or not, has heard of the queen of the Iceni, Boudica (?-60/61; r. circa 60/61), who led the Iceni Rebellion of 60/61. In contrast, the Iceni Revolt of 47 remains far more obscure, both within academic circles and public consciousness; the discovery of the Helmingham Hoard offers a tangible insight into this fascinating period of our Britainâ€™s history.

Helmingham Hall lies just short of twenty seven miles north of Camulodunum (now Colchester in Essex), an important early Roman settlement. It is here that veterans of the Legio XX Valeria Victrix retired to prior to 49. According to (Publius Cornelius) Tacitus (circa 56-circa 120), Ostorius brought down the Iceni Revolt with "allied troops, without the strength of the legions"; it seems quite plausible that legionary veterans would be included in this number. Sixty five miles to the north of Helmingham Hall is Stonea Camp, a hillfort which has been identified as the place where the Romans, finally and ultimately, put down the Iceni Revolt.

Helmingham Hall, then, fell right in the middle of these dramatic events. It is tempting to assume that the hoardâ€™s original owner was an active participant in this conflict. One can speculate from the hoardâ€™s considerable value, with the 724 Denarii equating to just over three years salary for an ordinary legionary, that its owner might have been a high-ranking legionary (e.g., an "optio"). One can go further still, sketching in loosest terms his career in Britain: he came over to Britain in 43 with the Legio XX Valeria Victrix, then travelled up north with Plautiusâ€™ forces, settled in Camulodunum for a short while, before heeding Ostorius call to arms to put down the Iceni Revolt; he travelled north to the region of Helmingham Hall where the hoard was buried by the pond, before going onwards up to Stonea Camp where he fell in battle. However, none of this need be true. It was quite common for people who had access neither to banks nor vaults to conceal their wealth in the ground, even in times of peace. Whatever the case, a hoard of this size would not easily be forgotten and its retrieval must have been prevented by some great personal misfortune. The truth is that no one will never know the name or position of the Helmingham Hoardâ€™s original owner; what can be said is that the original owner was a participant in one of the most dramatic and impactful chapters in Britain's history.
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (â†º, 12h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R2 Material: Silver
Year: 48 BC (not dated) Fineness: 950
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 3.52; Expected: 3.9
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 18
Unit: Denarius (Revaluation from 10 to 16 asses; 141-27 BC) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Roma Mintage: 570,000
Mint mark: None Emission period: 48 BC
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients VG; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 2/5; Attribute(s): bankers marks (NGC) Variety: ?
References: RRC1#448/2A,2B; RCV1#418; RSC1#2; RSC1#2A; Babelon1#Hostilia/2; CRRO#http://numismatics.org/crro/id/rrc-448.2a; CRRO#http://numismatics.org/crro/id/rrc-448.2b; PAS#https://finds.org.uk/database/search/results/q/2019T794
Varieties:

There are two varieties, for which the cognomen "Saserna" is written as "Sasern" (RRC1#448/2A and RSC1#2) or "Saserna" (RRC1#448/2B and RSC1#2).

RCC1 noted 57 obverse dies and 63 reverse dies. The question of the number of coins that could be struck from a single ancient die before it was discarded is contentious. Modern experiments suggest that an obverse die could strike about 15,000 acceptable coins, a reverse die only about half as many. However, often more than two reverse dies were used with an obverse die, since dies were often replaced before they wore out. Using a conservative figure of 10,000 coins per die, the production of this denarius type would be 570,000 denarii for 57 obverse dies.
Note:

The regular coinage of the Republican moneyers is typically arranged under the family name of the moneyer responsible for the issue of the coins, when these were identifiable, and then numbered them under each family. This arrangement is widely adopted for reference because it is so much easier than a chronological arrangement. Republican moneyers almost always acted as a board of three members, called the "tresviri monetales" or "tresviri aere argento auro flando feriundo", literally "three men for casting (and) striking bronze, silver (and) gold (coins)", with an annual tenure. Individually, they are often referred to as "triumvir monetalis", which is the singular form of "tresviri monetales". The "tresviri monetales" were included in the "Vigintisexvirate", a college of twenty-six minor magistrates. An office in the "Vigintisexvirate" was for most of them the first step on the cursus honorum. The long title "tresviri aere argento auro flando feriundo" was abbreviated "III. VIR. AAAFF." or even "III. VIR. A.P.F." for "tresviri ad pecuniam feriundam" on the coinage.

The "tresviri monetales" were not simple "monetarii" (mint workers), they were officials who controlled the process, including the design on the coins themselves. The moneyers' control of the legend on the coinage lent itself to the production of coins often containing propagandist political messaging. This served as self-advertising to further the potential political careers of the moneyers themselves, their families or that of those controlling them.
Historical notes:

(To the right) Equestrian statue of Vercingetorix, designed by FrÃ©dÃ©ric Auguste Bartholdi (1834-1904) in 1899, erected in Place de Jaude in Clermont-Ferrand since 1903

This coin bears the name of the "triumvir monetalis" Lucius Hostilius Saserna (?-?). Hoards showed that he belonged as a "triumvir monetalis" in the same year as the "tresviri monetales" Caius (Vibius) Pansa (Caetronianus; ?-43 BC) and Decimus (Junius) Brutus (Albinus; 81-43 BC). Decimus Brutus certainly belongs in 48 BC since he was besieging Massalia in 49 BC and was appointed to Gallia Transalpina late in 48 BC; Caius Pansa was in Rome in 48 BC. Hence, this coin was most likely struck in 48 BC. Julius Caesar (100-44 BC) designated Caius Pansa as consul for 43 BC, who took office, and Decimus Brutus for 42 BC, but he died before taking office. Lucius Saserna is not known to have held further office.

The cognomen Saserna was common in the "gens" Hostilia. It is then probable that he is the brother of two other people with this cognomen, a Saserna (?-?) whose first name is not known, and Publius Saserna (?-?). The three Saserna (brothers?) were lieutenants of Caesar during the battle of Africa in 46 BC. Lucius Saserna had always remained very attached to Caesar. (Marcus Tullius) Cicero (106-43 BC) indicated that, after the death of Caesar, Lucius Saserna became friend with Marcus Antonius (83-30 BC), known in English as Mark Antony, and Gaius Octavius (-63-14), also known as Octavian and future Augustus.

Lucius Saserna is known to have struck under his name three types (e.g., RRC1#448). The types refer without exception to Caesar's victories during his command in Gaul. The head on the obverse of this coin is frequently identified as that of the celebrated Gallic king and chieftain of the Arverni, Vercingetorix, but this identification must be regarded as highly conjectural. It can also be identified as the head of Pavor (Roman god and personification of fear), a companion of Mars (Roman god and personification of war) along with Pallor (Roman goddess and personification of paleness). Pavor would then appear with the traits of a bearded man with bristling hair; perhaps Pavor was given the traits of Vercingetorix; the Gallic shield placed behind the head allows this conjecture. Lucius Saserna would have thus reminded his contemporaries, at the same time as the recent victorious campaign of Caesar in Gaul, of a family tradition: his ancestor, the legendary third king of Rome Tullus Hostilius (r. circa 673â€“642 BC) had for the first time erected temples dedicated to Pavor and Pallor. It is recounted that these temples were erected on account of the fear that seized the Roman army in a battle against the Fidenates and Veians. Their allies, the Albans, suddenly turned against them in this battle, and the Roman army fled in fear. Tullus Hostilius then vowed, if he was victorious, to raise a temple dedicated to Pavor and Pallor.

+ 0049 BC - Roman Empire - Denarius - Julius Caesar:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Republic (509-27 BC); Roman Imperatorial period (49-27 BC)
Ruler: Caesar (-49-44)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Elephant walking right, with its trunk defiantly raised upwards, about to trample on what appears to be a "horned serpent" (or a carnyx, a S-shaped trumpet with a bell styled in the shape of the head of some animal, here a horned serpent, used by the Celtic tribes in Gaul), on a base, the inscription "CAESAR" below in exergue, the field surrounded by a grÃ¨netis
Script: -
Lettering: -
Traduction: -
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Pontifical implements: (from left to right) simpulum (small vessel or ladle with a long handle, used to make libations at sacrifices), aspergillum (stick with long horse-hair attached at one end, used to sprinkle holy water at sacrifices), sacena (pontifical securis; axe used to slaughter animals at sacrifices) with the top of the haft surmounted by a dog or wolf head, and apex (skull-cap with a chin-strap and a pointed piece of olive wood on its top, like a spindle, mounted on a little disk of wool at its base, worn by the flamines and Salii, who were Roman priests in charge, amongst other duties, of sacrifices); the field surrounded by a grÃ¨netis
Script: -
Lettering: -
Traduction: -
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin makes me think of my son Louis. ğŸ¦“

My son Louis owns 10% of the coin.

This is the first coinage to bear (Julius) Caesar's name. These coins were produced in huge numbers (several millions) in order to finance Caesar's military operations after he crossed the Rubicon and invaded Italy from the north in January 49 BC, driving Pompey (the Great) from Rome to seek refuge in Greece. While the size of this production could raise eyebrows, it must be remembered that by the end of his tenure in Gaul Caesar had no fewer than eight legions of about 5,000 men expecting payment, and that the gross salary for an ordinary legionary was 225 denarii per year. Still, minting several millions of coins required vast amount of bullion. As pointed out by Nousek (2008), and as evidence of a proposed minting date in early 49 BC, one need not look far to find a probable source. On 1st April 49 BC, Caesar addressed the remnants of the Senate and the Concilium Plebis (People's Assembly), promising grain distribution and a gift of 75 denarii per man. He then proceeded to the treasury at the Temple of Saturn and demanded access to the aerarium sanctius, the special "emergency" reserve. Although he met with stubborn opposition, Caesar managed to make off with 15,000 bars of gold, 30,000 bars of silver, and a great quantity of silver coins. This purloined bullion is likely to be the source of silver for this coin issue.

Despite being the most widespread of all Caesarâ€™s coins, the design of this type is still somewhat mysterious and subject to interpretation (see Rowan, 2019, for a summary of possible interpretations). Authorities have even debated which side of the coin is which: RCC1 describes the side with the elephant as the obverse, but other experts dispute this. The symbolism of this side of the coin is commonly held to show the triumph of good, represented as an elephant, over evil, represented as a "horned serpent". Alternatively, the "horned serpent" may be intended to represent a carnyx, a S-shaped trumpet with a bell styled in the shape of the head of some animal, here a horned serpent, used by the Celtic tribes in Gaul, whom Caesar had recently overcome in his epic eight-year conquest. In this case the elephant would again represent Caesar himself, or the unstoppable juggernaut of Rome. Unlike Pompey, Caesar brazenly placed his own name on the coinage without having the constitutional authority to do so, as Lucius Cornelius Sulla Felix (138-78 BC), commonly known as Sulla, had done 33 years before, in 82 BC. The other side of the coin depicts pontifical implements, which symbolise the prestigious lifetime office of pontifex maximus that he had held since 63 BC.
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (â†º, 02h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R Material: Silver
Year: 49 BC (not dated) Fineness: 950
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 3.73; Expected: 3.9
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 18
Unit: Denarius (Revaluation from 10 to 16 asses; 141-27 BC) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Military mint travelling with Caesar (in Mutina, for instance) Mintage: 7,500,000
Mint mark: None Emission period: 49-48 BC
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients VF; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 4/5 (NGC) Variety: Realistic elephant
References: RRC1#443/1; CRI#9; CRR#1006; RCV1#1399; RSC1#49; Babelon2#Julia/9; CRRO#http://numismatics.org/crro/id/rrc-443.1; MRK#1.8
Varieties:

There are two main varieties, for which the elephant is realistic or cartoonish. One speculation is that the cartoonish elephant was minted in Spain.

RCC1 noted 750 obverse dies and 833 reverse dies. The question of the number of coins that could be struck from a single ancient die before it was discarded is contentious. Modern experiments suggest that an obverse die could strike about 15,000 acceptable coins, a reverse die only about half as many. However, often more than two reverse dies were used with an obverse die, since dies were often replaced before they wore out. Using a conservative figure of 10,000 coins per die, the production of this denarius type would be 7.5 million denarii for 750 obverse dies.
Note:

The Roman Imperatorial period commences with the outbreak of civil war between (Julius) Caesar (100-44 BC) and Pompey (the Great; 106-48 BC) at the beginning of 49 BC and ends about twenty-two years later on 16 January 27 BC when Caesar's heir Gaius Octavius (-63-14), also known as Octavian, was given the name Augustus and effectively became the autocratic ruler of the Roman Empire. The Imperatorial coinage represents the transitional stage between the traditional Republican series and the revolutionary new Imperial coinage of Augustus and his successors.

In its earlier phase (49-45 BC) the Imperatorial series comprised issues bearing the names, though not yet the portraits, of the principal contenders for power. These issues existed side by side with the regular coinage of the Republican moneyers at the Capitoline mint in Rome, though in reality these were nothing more than a propaganda tool in the hands of Caesar and his successors who controlled the output of the Capitoline mint almost from the start of the civil war down to the closure of the establishment by Octavian in 40 BC. Additional coinages were produced at various provincial locations by supporters of Pompey (the Great) and his sons. A major turning point came at the beginning of 44 BC, when Caesar took the unprecedented step of placing his own portrait on the coinage. His assassination followed almost exactly three months later but, once initiated, this revolutionary innovation was irrevocable and portraiture rapidly became the norm, thus paving the way for the coinage of the Roman Empire.

In the post-Caesarian phase of the Imperatorial coinage (44-27 BC) issues initially were divided between the faction of the Second Triumvirate, led by Marcus Antonius (83-30 BC), known in English as Mark Antony, Octavian and (Marcus Aemilius) Lepidus (circa 89-13 BC), and the Republicans, most prominent amongst whom were the tyrannicides (Marcus Junius) Brutus (circa 85-42 BC) and his brother-in-law (Gaius) Cassius (Longinus; circa 86-42 BC). After the pivotal battle of Philippi in the autumn of 42 BC only the two principal Triumvirs, Mark Antony and Octavian, remained to contend for supreme authority in the Roman state. That struggle was finally resolved by the battle of Actium in 31 BC and the subsequent conquest the following year of Mark Antony's last strong-hold, the Ptolemaic kingdom of Egypt.

The Imperatorial coinage subdivides conveniently into four major categories: (1) issues of Pompey (the Great), his sons and their adherents; (2) issues of (Julius) Caesar; (3) issues of the Republican tyrannicides and their adherents; and (4) issues of the Triumvirs and their adherents. Between the years 49 and 40 BC it is important to remember that these essentially military coinages must be viewed in association with the contemporary coinage of the Roman moneyers. These were augmented, between 43 and 41 BC, by an exceptional output of moneyers' gold.
Historical notes:

(Gaius) Julius Caesar (born on 13 July 100 BC in Rome; dictator from 49 BC; died on 15 March 44 BC)

(To the right) Caesar on his chariot, painted by Andrea Mantegna (circa 1431-1506) between the mid-1480s and 1506. This painting is the final painting of a series of nine known as "The Triumphs of Caesar", which can be counted amongst the finest achievements in Italian Renaissance art. They were probably painted for Francesco II Gonzaga (1466-1519), who became the 4th Marquis of Mantua in Italy in 1484. The nine paintings form a sequence, which should really be called the "Triumph of Caesar", because it depicts a single procession, culminating in this final episode â€“ the arrival of Caesar borne on a chariot passing in front of a triumphal arch. The procession cannot be connected with a particular campaign, which is probably why it was seen more generally to celebrate the triumphs of Caesar as an ancient Roman soldier, statesman and historian revered during the Renaissance. "The Triumphs of Caesar" were acquired by the british monarch Charles I (1600-1649; r. 1625-1649) in 1629 when he purchased a large part of the collections formed by the Gonzaga family. They were clearly then considered to be the masterpiece of the collection. The paintings were hung at Hampton Court Palace near London soon after the probable date of their arrival in England in 1630. Since then, they have seldom left Hampton Court Palace, but their dedicated gallery is now undergoing refurbishment (with its completion planned for 2026). Having been generously loaned by the british monarch Charles III (1948-Present; r. 2022-Present), the first six of the nine paintings are now on display in The National Gallery in London, in newly made frames that echo the original arrangement in Mantua. The seventh canvas is off-display, to be analysed in The National Galleryâ€™s conservation studio, while the final two are on view in the Queenâ€™s Presence Chamber in Hampton Court Palace.

(Julius) Caesar pursued the traditional cursus honorum of the young aristocrat and did not rise to political prominence until the latter part of the 60s BC. He was elected to the prestigious lifetime office of pontifex maximus in 63 BC and the next year held a praetorship followed by a successful military command in Spain. Caesar was now poised to occupy the highest magistracy of the Roman Republic and in 59 BC he embarked on the first of his five consulships.

Being now in a position to take the initiative in the political game being played out in Rome he proposed a coalition between himself, Gnaeus Pompeius Magnus (106-48 BC), known in English as Pompey (the Great), and (Marcus Licinius) Crassus (115-53 BC), which has come to be known as the First Triumvirate. Although not an officially constituted body, like the Second Triumvirate sixteen years later, this alliance between the three most powerful and influential men in Rome was a force to be reckoned with and one that could not easily be opposed, even by the Senate. It led to Caesar obtaining a 5-year proconsular command in Gaul, which was to provide him with the military prestige and resources that he needed to make his ultimate bid for supreme power a decade later.

The delicate balance of power was fatally disrupted in 53 BC when Crassus was defeated and killed in the East during his invasion of Parthian Mesopotamia. Caesar and Pompey were now left to face one another as rivals for supremacy in the Roman world. A build-up of tensions starting in late 50 BC, with both Caesar and Pompey refusing to back down, led to the outbreak of Caesar's civil war. Pompey and his allies induced the Senate to demand Caesar give up his provinces and armies in early January 49 BC. Matters escalated a few days later when Caesar refused and instead crossed the Rubicon and invaded Italy from the north, driving Pompey from Rome to seek refuge in Greece. The eventual outcome was Caesar's victory over his rival at Pharsalus on 9 August 48 BC, resulting in Pompey's political downfall and assassination a few weeks later. The struggle between Caesar and the Pompeians, led by the late triumvir's generals and his two sons, continued for several years and was only finally resolved on the battlefield of Munda in Spain in March 45 BC. Caesar's political pre-eminence was now undisputed and at the beginning of the year 44 BC the dictator gave orders for his portrait to be placed on the regular silver coinage of Rome.

Undoubtedly, this development was instrumental in fueling the grievances of those republicans who feared that Caesar was aiming at the establishment of a monarchy. Accordingly, on the Ides (15th) of March 44 BC he was struck down by a conspiracy of senators led by (Marcus Junius) Brutus (circa 85-42 BC) and his brother-in-law (Gaius) Cassius (Longinus; circa 86-42 BC). He had adopted as his heir Gaius Octavius (-63-14), the grandson of his sister Julia (Minor; before 100-51 BC). Remarkably, the young man was willing to take up the heavy mantle of his great-uncle's political ambitions and was destined to become the founder of autocratic government in Rome under the name Augustus.

Il existe Ã©galement de nombreuses variÃ©tÃ©s dans les symboles devant le poitrail du cheval : annelet perlÃ©, globule, Ã©toile Ã  trois branches, astre, etc. Cet exemplaire est une rare variÃ©tÃ© avec une Ã©toile Ã  trois branches et non l'habituelle rouelle Ã  quatre branches (DLT#2402).
Note:

Les premiÃ¨res monnaies frappÃ©es dans la Gaule Celtique Ã©taient des imitations aussi serviles que possible du statÃ¨re d'or du roi de MacÃ©doine Philippe II (332-336 BC ; r. 359-336 BC), sur lequel figure Ã  l'avers la tÃªte laurÃ©e d'Apollon et au revers un bige galopant conduit par un aurige, tenant les rÃªnes de la main gauche et levant un aiguillon de la main droite, sur une base, l'inscription "Î¦Î™Î›Î™Î Î ÎŸÎ¥" (Philippe en grec ancient) en exergue. Les premiÃ¨res tribus Ã  en avoir fait des imitations assez fidÃ¨les semblent Ãªtre les Arvernes et les HelvÃ¨tes. Au fil des annÃ©es, des imitations, et des modifications, ces espÃ¨ces dÃ©viÃ¨rent de plus en plus du modÃ¨le, Ã  l'avers la tÃªte d'Apollon devenant de plus en plus abstraite, et au revers le bige se transformant progressivement en un seul cheval entourÃ© de divers Ã©lÃ©ments de dÃ©composition du reste du modÃ¨le : l'aurige semble voler au-dessus du cheval, une roue se trouve parfois entre les jambes du cheval. Au delÃ  de l'Ã©volution de leur composition artistique, ces espÃ¨ces ont Ã©galement Ã©tÃ© fortement affectÃ©es par l'Ã©volution de leur forme, poids et composition mÃ©tallique.

Les Ã©missions Ã©taient le fait de tribus (pagi) au sein mÃªme des peuples et non des peuples en tant qu'entitÃ©. Ces tribus pouvaient Ãªtre d'Ã©gale puissance (conduisant possiblement Ã  de nombreuses Ã©missions monÃ©taires) ou de taille et de poids politique diffÃ©rent (conduisant possiblement Ã  des Ã©missions monÃ©taires dominantes et un systÃ¨me de droit monÃ©taire pour d'autres Ã©missions). Les types dominants d'une tribu Ã©tait copiÃ©s plus ou moins fidÃ¨lement par les ateliers monÃ©taires, ce qui explique les Ã©volutions de composition artistique et les transformations de type monÃ©taire.

Dans l'immense masse des monnayages d'or du nord-ouest de la Gaule, ceux frappÃ©s dans la basse vallÃ©e de la Seine se distinguent par leur style, hÃ©ritÃ© d'un art celtique des plus Ã©nigmatiques, et par quelques traits caractÃ©ristiques comme la spÃ©cialisation dans la frappe d'un Ã©talon hÃ©mistatÃ¨re. Ces Ã©missions sont gÃ©nÃ©ralement attribuÃ©es au peuple des Aulerques Ã‰burovices. Cependant, comme l'a montrÃ© Guihard (2012), ces hÃ©mistatÃ¨res de la basse vallÃ©e de la Seine rÃ©pondaient Ã  une organisation complexe qui ne peut guÃ¨re se limiter ou s'accommoder d'une attribution Ã  un peuple dÃ©terminÃ©.

Ces hÃ©mistatÃ¨res et leur division prÃ©sentent des types stables d'une sÃ©rie Ã  l'autre : Ã  l'avers figure un profil stylisÃ© de tradition apollinienne ornÃ© d'un rappel de la couronne de laurier, dans une formation triangulaire en arriÃ¨re de la chevelure ; au revers apparaÃ®t toujours un cheval surmontÃ© d'un aurige et accompagnÃ© de divers symboles.

Dans le tableau des monnaies d'or attribuÃ©es aux Aulerques Ã‰burovices, un ensemble se distingue des autres par son ampleur. Il s'agit de deux sÃ©ries d'hÃ©mistatÃ¨res faisant intervenir un animal au revers : celle marquÃ©e d'un loup et celle marquÃ©e d'un sanglier. Devant le poitrail du cheval, on relÃ¨ve Ã©galement de nombreuses marques secondaires, reprÃ©sentant gÃ©nÃ©ralement des symboles (annelet perlÃ©, globule, Ã©toile Ã  trois branches, astre, etc.).

Les affinitÃ©s stylistiques et typologiques entre ces deux sÃ©ries sont si Ã©troites qu'il convient de les examiner conjointement. La composition Ã  l'avers et au revers est en cela significative. Ã€ l'avers, elles sont liÃ©es par le mÃªme dessein de mÃ©tamorphose. Le style gÃ©nÃ©ral du profil est trÃ¨s proche d'une monnaie Ã  l'autre. Le traitement obÃ©it Ã  une structure particuliÃ¨re d'une remarquable stabilitÃ©. L'accent a Ã©tÃ© mis sur certains Ã©lÃ©ments du visage. L'arcade sourciliÃ¨re, le nez, la bouche et la joue (tatouÃ©e ou non) sont clairement individualisÃ©s. En outre, le traitement de la chevelure prÃ©sente des ressemblances assez prÃ©cises. Il est constituÃ© d'une succession de globules entre deux lignes perlÃ©es formant un Â« V Â». Sous la ligne perlÃ©e de droite, des courbes symbolisent des mÃ¨ches. Ã€ la base du cou, un svastika ou un triskÃ¨le est systÃ©matiquement reprÃ©sentÃ©. La composition au revers est tout autant rÃ©guliÃ¨re. Elle a pour thÃ¨me principal un cheval aux membres dÃ©sarticulÃ©s. Celui-ci est surmontÃ© d'un aurige qui paraÃ®t en voltige et hÃ©site entre une apparence humaine, animale ou monstrueuse. Toutes ces remarques conduisent Ã  considÃ©rer ces deux sÃ©ries comme un ensemble monÃ©taire particuliÃ¨rement homogÃ¨ne.

Ces deux sÃ©ries sont prÃ©cÃ©dÃ©es d'Ã©missions sur des flans plus larges qui leur sont Ã©troitement liÃ©es par trois traits communs et caractÃ©ristiques : la permanence d'un profil de tÃªte Ã  l'avers et d'un cheval conduit par un aurige au revers ; la prÃ©sentation et l'arrangement des cheveux composÃ©s d'un assemblage de globules entre deux lignes perlÃ©es et de courbes reprÃ©sentant les mÃ¨ches derriÃ¨re la nuque ; le symbole du loup sous le cheval. En revanche, leur style n'est pas tout Ã  fait comparable. La dÃ©composition et la simplification des sujets y sont moins marquÃ©es : les Ã©lÃ©ments du visage et du corps ne s'individualisent pas encore clairement. Ces arguments montrent que les Ã©missions interviennent avant les deux sÃ©ries Ã  flan court Â« au loup Â» et Â« au sanglier Â». D'autre part, la prÃ©sence de simulacre de lÃ©gende au revers sur certains exemplaires rappelle l'inscription "Î¦Î™Î›Î™Î Î ÎŸÎ¥" sur le statÃ¨re d'or du roi de MacÃ©doine Philippe II, ce qui conforte l'ordre de succession des Ã©missions.

Une chronologie absolue est cependant difficile Ã  Ã©tablir. Il est plausible que les Ã©missions Ã  flan large rÃ©interprÃ©tant profondÃ©ment le statÃ¨re d'or du roi de MacÃ©doine Philippe II de MacÃ©doine, commencÃ¨rent vers -150. Ã€ partir de la fin de ce siÃ¨cle, de nouvelles monnaies, frappÃ©es sur un flan court, apparurent. Le dÃ©but de ces Ã©missions fut probablement contemporain des derniÃ¨res Ã©missions au flan large. Deux sÃ©ries circulÃ¨rent alors parallÃ¨lement, l'une marquÃ©e d'un Â« loup Â» et l'autre d'un Â«sanglierÂ». Leur frappe se prolongea, semble-t-il, jusqu'Ã  la conquÃªte de la Gaule par CÃ©sar en -51.

Guihard (2012) mit en Ã©vidence que ces hÃ©mistatÃ¨res circulaient sur un espace bien dÃ©terminÃ© dans la basse vallÃ©e de la Seine, en territoires que l'on attribue aux VÃ©liocasses et aux Aulerques Ã‰burovices. La sÃ©rie Â« au loup Â» se concentre sur la rive droite de la Seine, en territoire vÃ©liocasse, tandis que celle Â« au sanglier Â» se concentre principalement sur la rive gauche, en territoire aulerque Ã©burovice. Cela confirme l'attribution de la sÃ©rie Â« au sanglier Â» aux Aulerques Ã‰burovices, et suggÃ¨re que la sÃ©rie Â« au loup Â» pourrait plutÃ´t Ãªtre attribuÃ©e aux VÃ©liocasses. Ces deux sÃ©ries peuvent Ãªtre considÃ©rÃ©es comme une sÃ©rie uniforme, signalant ainsi une alliance monÃ©taire entre ces deux tribus partageant une vie Ã©conomique et commerciale facilitÃ©e par la Seine et ses affluents.
Historical notes:

(To the right) Statue de CamulogÃ¨ne, crÃ©Ã©e par EugÃ¨ne-Louis Lequesne (ou le Quesne ; 1815-1887), exposÃ©e au Palais des Beaux-Arts de Lille

Les Aulerques Ã‰burovices Ã©taient un peuple gaulois, fraction du grand peuple des Aulerques, Ã©tablis globalement entre la Seine et la Loire, et dÃ©signÃ©s par diffÃ©rents qualificatifs selon la portion du territoire oÃ¹ ils se trouvaient. Ceux de la rÃ©gion de la basse vallÃ©e de la Seine portaient le qualificatif Â« Ã‰burovices Â». Ils occupaient une position stratÃ©gique sur la rive gauche de la Seine. Leur nom serait composÃ© du prÃ©fixe ablatif Â« au- Â» signifiant Â« loin de Â» attachÃ© Ã  la racine Â« lerg- Â» signifiant Â« trace Â» et peut ainsi Ãªtre interprÃ©tÃ© comme Â« ceux qui sont loin de leurs traces Â». Le qualificatif Â« Ã‰burovices Â» serait composÃ© des Ã©lÃ©ments celtiques Â« eburo- Â» signifiant ceux qui vainquent et Â« -vice Â» dÃ©signant l'if (botanique). Les Ã‰burovices seraient alors Â« ceux qui vainquent par l'if Â», ce bois ayant Ã©tÃ© utilisÃ© pour fabriquer des armes, notamment des arcs en raison de sa flexibilitÃ© et de sa rÃ©sistance. L'ethnogenÃ¨se du peuple des Aulerques n'est pas connue, mais elle peut Ãªtre placÃ©e avant 600 BC puisque les Aulerques faisaient partie de la migration lÃ©gendaire vers l'Italie menÃ©e vers 600 BC par Bellovesus, le chef des Bituriges, accompagnÃ©es des Ã‰duens, des Ambarres, des Arvernes, des Carnutes et des SÃ©nons. Leur principal oppidum se trouvait dans les environs dâ€™Ã‰vreux, probablement non loin de Mediolanum Aulercorum (Ã‰vreux) et de Gisacum (le Vieil-Evreux). Les Aulerques Ã‰burovices participÃ¨rent Ã  la coalition des peuples armoricains contre les Romains et leurs alliÃ©s gaulois en -56. Ils se coalisÃ¨rent de nouveau avec les SÃ©nons et les Parisii en -52. CommandÃ©s par le chef de guerre aulerque CamulogÃ¨ne, ils affrontÃ¨rent le gÃ©nÃ©ral romain et lieutenant de CÃ©sar, Titus Labienus (vers 100-45 BC), lors de la bataille de LutÃ¨ce. Ils participÃ¨rent Ã©galement Ã  la coalition belge du soulÃ¨vement des Bellovaques contre les Suessions alors sous l'autoritÃ© des RÃ¨mes, alliÃ©s des Romains, en -51. En ajoutant Ã  ces trois coalitions, celle de -52 commandÃ©e par VercingÃ©torix (vers 80 BC-46 BC), les Aulerques Ã‰burovices est un des peuples gaulois les plus engagÃ©s dans la rÃ©sistance face aux Romains. Cette rÃ©sistance n'aura pas Ã©viter la conquÃªte de la Gaule par CÃ©sar. La TroisiÃ¨me RÃ©publique (1870-1940) n'exista personnellement dans ses propres types monÃ©taires qu'Ã  compter de 1895.

En 1895, le ministre des Finances Joseph Athanase Doumer, dit Paul Doumer (1857-1932), graveur lui-mÃªme, fit appel Ã  trois artistes, Jules-ClÃ©ment Chaplain (1839-1909), Louis Oscar Roty (1846-1911) et Jean-Baptiste Daniel-Dupuis (1849-1899) pour crÃ©er de nouveaux types pour les monnaies d'or, d'argent et de cuivre, en toute libertÃ© de choix de sujet. Le seul Ã©lÃ©ment commun devait Ãªtre le bonnet phrygien.

Chaplain et Daniel-Dupuis proposaient un buste fÃ©minin moderne, restÃ© trÃ¨s sÃ©vÃ¨re chez le premier. Roty prÃ©senta la premiÃ¨re RÃ©publique en pied, la semeuse. Les trois, nÃ©anmoins, faisaient passer la reprÃ©sentation du symbole de l'idÃ©al, le mythe Ã  plus de rÃ©alitÃ©, de naturalisme : la divinitÃ© laissait la place Ã  la fÃ©minitÃ©, notamment celle de Daniel-Dupuy, douce et souriante. Le rayonnement de la France rÃ©publicaine ne se reprÃ©sentait donc plus par une Ã©toile, mais par une jeune femme.

Pour la monnaie d'or, successeur du louis et du napolÃ©on, marque populaire de la fortune, le type de Chaplain fut retenu. Chaplain choisit le coq pour le revers. Il apparaissait dÃ©jÃ  comme Ã©lÃ©ment secondaire de type sur les monnaies de la monarchie constitutionnelle (1791-1792) avec le GÃ©nie de la France. Le coq Ã  l'allure Ã©nergique voire martiale symbolisait pour les uns la vigilance et le courage, pour les autres la nation franÃ§aise, le mot latin Â« gallus Â» ayant depuis la Renaissance latinisante donnÃ© lieu Ã  un jeu de mot Ã  cause de sa double signification, Â« Gaulois Â» et Â« coq Â».

Pour la monnaie dâ€™argent, la semeuse de Roty, fut retenue. La semeuse marche d'un pas dÃ©terminÃ©, semant Ã  contre-vent le bon grain sur un fond irradiÃ© par le soleil levant. Le geste est plus symbolique que rÃ©aliste â€“ on ne sÃ¨me pas contre le vent â€“ mais la semeuse est ainsi rendue plus dynamique, ses cheveux et sa robe flottant en arriÃ¨re. L'origine de la semeuse de Roty est antÃ©rieure Ã  ce concours monÃ©taire. Elle remonte Ã  1887, lorsque Roty conÃ§oit un modÃ¨le de mÃ©daille de rÃ©compense pour le ministÃ¨re de l'Agriculture. Pour la monnaie de cuivre, câ€™est le type de Daniel-Dupuy qui fut retenu. Le revers du type de Daniel-Dupuy est plus complexe : la RÃ©publique casquÃ©e tenant le drapeau national d'une main et une branche d'olivier de l'autre, figure la France vaincue par l'Allemagne pendant la guerre franco-allemande de 1870-1871, prÃªte Ã  la guerre mais aspirant Ã  la paix ; sous sa protection, l'enfant tient d'une main un Ã©pi de blÃ©, de lâ€™autre un maillet pour signifier que les FranÃ§ais peuvent travailler, prospÃ©rer et faire prospÃ©rer l'agriculture et l'industrie nationales Ã  l'abri du rÃ©gime rÃ©publicain.

La semeuse de Roty parut Ã  partir de 1897 sur les piÃ¨ces de 50 centimes, 1 et 2 francs (1898) en argent, le type de Daniel-Dupuy Ã  partir de 1898 pour les monnaies divisionnaires de cuivre de 5 et 10 centimes, et le type de Chaplain Ã  partir de 1899 sur les piÃ¨ces d'or.
