There are two varieties, for which the hippopotamus looks down (the most common; RSC4#63 and Cohen5#63) or up (the least common; RSC4#64 and Cohen5#64).
Note:

In 215 Caracalla reformed the monetary system to finance ever increasing imperial expenditures by introducing the antoninianus, named after Caracalla's official name "Antoninus". The newly introduced antoninianus had the same silver purity as the denarius (51.5%) but weighed 5.1 g, compared to 3.23 g for the denarius. Although its silver content was only equivalent to about one and a half denarii, the antoninianus was apparently officially tariffed as the equivalent of two. For this reason, it is sometimes referred to as "double-denarius". This new coin always shows the emperor wearing the radiate crown instead of the laurel wreath of the denarius. In the case of empresses, the coin is distinguished by the addition of a crescent placed beneath the bust. It was initially mostly silver, but was slowly debased, following the trend of the debasement of silver during the Severan dynasty (193-235), to bronze with a minimal silver content (see Pense, 1992). Elagabalus demonetised the antoninianus in 219 in favour of the denarius. The antoninianus was re-introduced in 238 by Gordian III who, in turn, saw to it intentionally or otherwise that the denarius would be phased out for good.

Rome remained the principal mint for the production of coinage throughout this reign, though in the minting of antoniniani it was assisted at various times by at least two, and possibly three, provincial mints. One of these was at Viminacium, an important city of the Danubian province of Upper Moesia, though the rare products of this mint have only recently been identified. Another mint was located at Antioch in Syria, though as under Gordian III the issues usually attributed to it fall into two distinct groups, one early (244-245), the other late (247-249). Stylistically these groups are quite different from one another, which has led some numismatists to believe that only the later group should be assigned to Antioch, whilst the earlier coinage should instead be given to the same uncertain eastern mint that had produced some of Gordian III's later coinage.

During the years 247 and 248 the "Saeculares" coinage struck to commemorate the millennium (1000th anniversary) of the foundation of Rome included the following reverse inscriptions: "SAECLARES AVGG" (the age of the Two Emperors), "SAECVLVM NOVVM" (the new age) and "MILIARIVM SAECVLVM" (the millenia). The "Saeculares" coinage is divided into two reverse series: the reverse animal series showing wild animals (with the inscription "SAECLARES AVGG" for all the denominations) and the reverse architectural series illustrating either a hexastyle temple (containing a seated statue of Roma) (with the inscription "SAECVLVM NOVVM" for the denominations in gold and silver and the inscription "SAECLARES AVGG" for the denominations in bronze) or a cippus (column) (with the inscription "SAECLARES AVGG" for all the denominations or the inscription "MILIARIVM SAECVLVM" for the denominations in bronze). The reverse animal series shows at least eight different wild animals: a lion, a she-wolf (suckling the twins Romulus and Remus), a gazelle, a European elk (moose), a hippopotamus, a stag, a goat (or hind), and an antelope. Struck in a wide range of denominations the series included the gold aureus, the silver antoninianius and quinarius, and the bronze sestertius, dupondius and as. Included also are issues of Otacilia Severa, wife of Philip (I) the Arab, and Philip (Il) the Younger, their son who had been raised to the rank of Augustus in 247.

The "Ludi Saeculares" (Secular Games) organised for the millennium of the foundation of Rome was highlighted by a splendid array of wild animals. These wild animals had originally been collected for the intended triumph of Gordian III in the Persian war, which saw his death and the associated proclamation of Philip (I) the Arab as emperor in 244. The animals were used by Philip (I) the Arab in magnificent displays and (slaughter) games put on in the key venues, like the Circus Maximus and the Colosseum. This large collection of exotic wild beasts included several specimens of antelope, elephant, European elk (moose), gazelle, giraffe, goat, hippopotamus, wild horse, hyena, leopard, lion, rhinoceros, stag, tiger and wild ass. It was these animals, collected for Gordian III, which, no doubt, inspired the many animal reverse types found on the "Saeculares" coinage struck to commemorate the millennium of the foundation of Rome. Besides, the she-wolf (suckling the twins Romulus and Remus) would have been recognised as the symbol of Rome rather than as a reminder of the games' arena.

A remarkable feature of this "Saeculares" coinage was the earliest appearance of officina (workshop) marks at the mint of Rome. The mint of Rome at this time was apparently divided into six officinae. These six officinae produced the "Saeculares" issue with marks as Roman numerals I to VI (only for the silver antoninianius) and are of much interest in that the eight animals illustrated on the reverse were divided among them with Officina I striking only the lion, II the lion and the she-wolf, III the gazelle and the European elk (moose), IV the hippopotamus, V the stag, and VI the goat (or hind) and the antelope. At almost the same time the same six officinae produced a different issue with marks as ancient Greek numerals Î‘ to ↅ (only for the silver antoninianius) rather than Roman numerals I to VI. Also, generally speaking, the six officinae were assigned to the production of issues in the name of a single imperial personage shown on the obverse: Officinae I/Î‘, II/Î’, V/Î• and VI/ↅ minted for Philip (I) the Arab, Officina III/Î“ minted for Philip (II) the Younger, and Officina IV/Î” minted for Otacilia Severa.

Although the practice of adding officina marks was not immediately adopted for succeeding issues, this development nevertheless marked an important numismatic turning point. Before long mint marks of increasing complexity began appearing not only on the issues of the mint of Rome itself, but also on those of the ever-expanding network of provincial mints.
Historical notes:

(Marcia) Otacilia Severa (born circa 220; given the title of Augusta in 244; died in or after 249)

(To the right) Bust of Otacilia Severa, sculpted by an unknown artist between 244 and 249, displayed in the Hall of the Machines of the Centrale Montemartini in Rome

Marcia Otacilia Severa married Philip (I) the Arab (circa 204-249; r. 244-249) in 234, though very little is known of the biographical details of her life. She may have been of noble Roman birth, as suggested by her name, though if so we can only speculate on how she came to mary the son of an Arab chieftain. She gave birth to their only son, Philip (II) the Younger, about 237 (that is about seven years before her husband's accession as Emperor) and was accorded the title of Augusta early in the reign in 244. She enjoyed a generous share of the imperial coinage, with one of the six officinae (workshops) of the Rome mint being assigned to the production of issues in her name. The Antioch mint also struck antoniniani for her, though these are by no means common. Otacilia's ultimate fate is shrouded in mystery. She was in Rome when her husband was defeated and killed at the Battle of Verona in 249 following a rebellion led by his successor, (Gaius Messius Quintus Trajanus) Decius (circa 201-251), also known as Trajan Decius. However, it is unclear whether she was murdered as their son Philip (II) the Younger by the Praetorians shortly after the death of her husband or merely permitted to live a private life in obscurity.

+ AD 0248 - Roman Empire - Antoninianus - Philip (I) the Arab:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Empire (-27-395); Crisis of the Third Century (235-284)
Ruler: Philip (I) the Arab (244-249)
Type: Commemorative issue (Secular Games); Collection thÃ©matique â€“ CÃ©lÃ©brations du millÃ©naire de la fondation de Rome en 247-248; La mÃ©nagerie
Obverse:

Design: Bust of Philip (I) the Arab, facing right, radiate, draped, cuirassed (RIC "Type B")
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) IMPPHILIPPVSAVG (IMP PHILIPPVS AVG)
Traduction: Supreme military commander (Imperator), Philippus, Emperor (Augustus) (Imperator Philippus Augustus)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Stag walking right, on a base, the officina mark (V) below in exergue
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) SAECVLARESAVGG (SAECVLARES AVGG)
Traduction: Secular Games of the Two Emperors (Augusti) (Saeculares Duorum Augustorum)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin was submitted to NGC for grading. The grade that I expected it would receive was Ch AU; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 5/5 or, more realistically, AU; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 5/5. The grade that it received was Ch XF; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 4/5, which did not quite meet my expectation.

This coin makes me think of my son Louis. ğŸ¦“
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (â†º, 01h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: C Material: Silver
Year: 248 (not dated) Fineness: 466
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 3.45; Expected: 3.9
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Measured: 24; Expected: 23
Unit: Antoninianus (Reform of Caracalla; 215-301) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Roma Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 248
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients Ch XF; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 5/5 (NGC) Variety: Stag walking right
References: RIC4_3#19; RCV3#8958; RSC4#182; Cohen5#182; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.4.ph_i.19; MRK#74.22.8
Varieties:

There are two varieties, for which the stag walks right (the most common; RIC4_3#19, RCV3#8958, RSC4#182, Cohen5#182, and MRK#74.22.8) or left (the least common; RIC4_3#20, RSC4#185, Cohen5#185, and MRK#74.22.7).
Note:

In 215 Caracalla reformed the monetary system to finance ever increasing imperial expenditures by introducing the antoninianus, named after Caracalla's official name "Antoninus". The newly introduced antoninianus had the same silver purity as the denarius (51.5%) but weighed 5.1 g, compared to 3.23 g for the denarius. Although its silver content was only equivalent to about one and a half denarii, the antoninianus was apparently officially tariffed as the equivalent of two. For this reason, it is sometimes referred to as "double-denarius". This new coin always shows the emperor wearing the radiate crown instead of the laurel wreath of the denarius. In the case of empresses, the coin is distinguished by the addition of a crescent placed beneath the bust. It was initially mostly silver, but was slowly debased, following the trend of the debasement of silver during the Severan dynasty (193-235), to bronze with a minimal silver content (see Pense, 1992). Elagabalus demonetised the antoninianus in 219 in favour of the denarius. The antoninianus was re-introduced in 238 by Gordian III who, in turn, saw to it intentionally or otherwise that the denarius would be phased out for good.

Rome remained the principal mint for the production of coinage throughout this reign, though in the minting of antoniniani it was assisted at various times by at least two, and possibly three, provincial mints. One of these was at Viminacium, an important city of the Danubian province of Upper Moesia, though the rare products of this mint have only recently been identified. Another mint was located at Antioch in Syria, though as under Gordian III the issues usually attributed to it fall into two distinct groups, one early (244-245), the other late (247-249). Stylistically these groups are quite different from one another, which has led some numismatists to believe that only the later group should be assigned to Antioch, whilst the earlier coinage should instead be given to the same uncertain eastern mint that had produced some of Gordian III's later coinage.

During the years 247 and 248 the "Saeculares" coinage struck to commemorate the millennium (1000th anniversary) of the foundation of Rome included the following reverse inscriptions: "SAECLARES AVGG" (the age of the Two Emperors), "SAECVLVM NOVVM" (the new age) and "MILIARIVM SAECVLVM" (the millenia). The "Saeculares" coinage is divided into two reverse series: the reverse animal series showing wild animals (with the inscription "SAECLARES AVGG" for all the denominations) and the reverse architectural series illustrating either a hexastyle temple (containing a seated statue of Roma) (with the inscription "SAECVLVM NOVVM" for the denominations in gold and silver and the inscription "SAECLARES AVGG" for the denominations in bronze) or a cippus (column) (with the inscription "SAECLARES AVGG" for all the denominations or the inscription "MILIARIVM SAECVLVM" for the denominations in bronze). The reverse animal series shows at least eight different wild animals: a lion, a she-wolf (suckling the twins Romulus and Remus), a gazelle, a European elk (moose), a hippopotamus, a stag, a goat (or hind), and an antelope. Struck in a wide range of denominations the series included the gold aureus, the silver antoninianius and quinarius, and the bronze sestertius, dupondius and as. Included also are issues of Otacilia Severa, wife of Philip (I) the Arab, and Philip (Il) the Younger, their son who had been raised to the rank of Augustus in 247.

The "Ludi Saeculares" (Secular Games) organised for the millennium of the foundation of Rome was highlighted by a splendid array of wild animals. These wild animals had originally been collected for the intended triumph of Gordian III in the Persian war, which saw his death and the associated proclamation of Philip (I) the Arab as emperor in 244. The animals were used by Philip (I) the Arab in magnificent displays and (slaughter) games put on in the key venues, like the Circus Maximus and the Colosseum. This large collection of exotic wild beasts included several specimens of antelope, elephant, European elk (moose), gazelle, giraffe, goat, hippopotamus, wild horse, hyena, leopard, lion, rhinoceros, stag, tiger and wild ass. It was these animals, collected for Gordian III, which, no doubt, inspired the many animal reverse types found on the "Saeculares" coinage struck to commemorate the millennium of the foundation of Rome. Besides, the she-wolf (suckling the twins Romulus and Remus) would have been recognised as the symbol of Rome rather than as a reminder of the games' arena.

A remarkable feature of this "Saeculares" coinage was the earliest appearance of officina (workshop) marks at the mint of Rome. The mint of Rome at this time was apparently divided into six officinae. These six officinae produced the "Saeculares" issue with marks as Roman numerals I to VI (only for the silver antoninianius) and are of much interest in that the eight animals illustrated on the reverse were divided among them with Officina I striking only the lion, II the lion and the she-wolf, III the gazelle and the European elk (moose), IV the hippopotamus, V the stag, and VI the goat (or hind) and the antelope. At almost the same time the same six officinae produced a different issue with marks as ancient Greek numerals Î‘ to ↅ (only for the silver antoninianius) rather than Roman numerals I to VI. Also, generally speaking, the six officinae were assigned to the production of issues in the name of a single imperial personage shown on the obverse: Officinae I/Î‘, II/Î’, V/Î• and VI/ↅ minted for Philip (I) the Arab, Officina III/Î“ minted for Philip (II) the Younger, and Officina IV/Î” minted for Otacilia Severa.

Although the practice of adding officina marks was not immediately adopted for succeeding issues, this development nevertheless marked an important numismatic turning point. Before long mint marks of increasing complexity began appearing not only on the issues of the mint of Rome itself, but also on those of the ever-expanding network of provincial mints.
Historical notes:

(Marcus Julius) Philippus (born circa 204; proclaimed emperor circa late February 244; died in September 249)

(To the right) Bust of Philip (I) the Arab, sculpted by an unknown artist between 244 and 249, displayed in the State Hermitage Museum in Saint Petersburg

Marcus Julius Philippus, a native of Arabia Trachonitis, was born about 204 and was the son of an Arab chieftain named Marinus (?-?) who had attained Roman equestrian rank. Philip (I) the Arab, as he became known, held a high command in the Roman army during the Persian campaign of his predecessor (Marcus Antonius) Gordianus (225-244; r. 238-244), known as Gordian III, and during the winter of 243-244 he became praetorian prefect in place of Gordian III's father-in-law (Gaius Furius Sabinius Aquila) Timesitheus (190-243), in whose sudden death he may have been implicated. It soon became clear that the new praetorian prefect had designs on the throne itself and he set about undermining the authority of the young Gordian III. By late February 244 he felt sufficiently secure to make his move and the unfortunate emperor was deposed by the army and put to death, Philip (I) the Arab being proclaimed in his place. Anxious to return to Rome as soon as possible he hastily negotiated a peace treaty with the Persian shahanshah Shapur I (?-270; r. circa 240-270) and assumed the title of "Persicus Maximus". His wife, (Marcia) Otacilia Severa (circa 220-in or after 249), was given the rank of Augusta and their young son, Philip (the Younger; about 237-249), became Caesar, both being granted a share in the imperial coinage. In further moves to strengthen the stability of his new dynasty Philip (I) the Arab appointed his brother (Gaius Julius) Priscus (?-?) to the governorship of Mesopotamia (later supreme commander in the East), and his father- (or brother-) in-law Severianus (?-?) to the governorship of Moesia. He even granted posthumous deification to his father Marinus and coins in honour of the new deity were struck at the recently established colony of Philippopolis in Arabia, probably the emperor's birthplace. Philip was back in Rome by the summer and received formal ratification of his accession from an obedient Senate. Much of the following two years was spent in campaigning on the northern frontier against the Dacian Carpi and the German Quadi and in 247 the emperor celebrated a triumph in Rome. The event was used as the setting for the further elevation of his son Philip (the Younger) to the status of Augustus and co-emperor. The following year magnificent games and other spectacles were staged in the capital in celebration of the millennium (1000th anniversary) of the foundation of Rome and the occasion was marked by an extensive issue of coinage in all metals. This was to be the high-point of Philip (I) the Arab's reign. Later in the year serious revolts broke out in Moesia, where the uprising was headed by (Tiberius Claudius Marcus) Pacatianus (?-circa 248), known as Pacatian, and in Cappadocia and northern Syria, where (Marcus Fulvius Rufus) Jotapianus (?-circa 249), known as Jotapian, was proclaimed emperor. Although neither rebellion was successful they were enough to undermine confidence in Philip (I) the Arab's ability to rule. When he sent his general (Gaius Messius Quintus Trajanus) Decius (circa 201-251), also known as Trajan Decius, to Moesia to settle the disturbed situation there the army proclaimed their commander emperor in his place. Although reputedly reluctant to accept the doubtful honour Decius nevertheless marched on Italy and met Philip (I) the Arab in battle at Verona. Philip (I) the Arab and his son Philip (II) the Younger were both killed in the disastrous defeat and Decius was left in uncontested possession of the imperial throne in September 249. The tradition has come down to us that Philip (I) the Arab had strong Christian sympathies. However, this may be due to nothing more than the stark contrast between his tolerant attitude in religious matters and the cruel persecutions of his successor, Decius.

The silver denarius, though still occasionally minted under Philip (I) the Arab, was no longer part of the regular monetary system and specimens today are of considerable rarity. It was replaced as the principal denomination by the antoninianus. Gold coinage was also much rarer than under Gordian III, but sestertii continued to be issued in large quantities. In addition to coinage in the name of Philip (I) the Arab himself, issues were made in the names of his son Philip (II) the Younger (as Caesar until 247, thereafter as Augustus) and his wife Otacilia Severa.

+ AD 0248 - Roman Empire - Antoninianus - Philip (I) the Arab:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Empire (-27-395); Crisis of the Third Century (235-284)
Ruler: Philip (I) the Arab (244-249)
Type: Commemorative issue (Secular Games); Collection thÃ©matique â€“ CÃ©lÃ©brations du millÃ©naire de la fondation de Rome en 247-248; La mÃ©nagerie

Traduction: Supreme military commander (Imperator), Philippus, Emperor (Augustus) (Imperator Philippus Augustus)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Antelope walking left, on a base, the officina mark (VI) below in exergue
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) SAECVLARESAVGG (SAECVLARES AVGG)
Traduction: Secular Games of the Two Emperors (Augusti) (Saeculares Duorum Augustorum)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -

This coin was submitted to NGC for grading. The grade that I expected it would receive was XF; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 4/5. The grade that it received was Ch XF; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 4/5, which exceeded my expectation.

Alignment: Variable (â†º, 05h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: C Material: Silver

Mint: Roma Mintage:

Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients Ch XF; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 4/5 (NGC) Variety: Antelope walking left
References: RIC4_3#21; RCV3#8959; RSC4#189; Cohen5#189; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.4.ph_i.21; MRK#74.22.9
Varieties:

There are two varieties, for which the antelope walks left (the most common; RIC4_3#21, RCV3#8959, RSC4#189, Cohen5#189, and MRK#74.22.9) or right (the least common; RIC4_3#22, RSC4#188, Cohen5#188, and MRK#74.22.10).
Note:

In 215 Caracalla reformed the monetary system to finance ever increasing imperial expenditures by introducing the antoninianus, named after Caracalla's official name "Antoninus". The newly introduced antoninianus had the same silver purity as the denarius (51.5%) but weighed 5.1 g, compared to 3.23 g for the denarius. Although its silver content was only equivalent to about one and a half denarii, the antoninianus was apparently officially tariffed as the equivalent of two. For this reason, it is sometimes referred to as "double-denarius". This new coin always shows the emperor wearing the radiate crown instead of the laurel wreath of the denarius. In the case of empresses, the coin is distinguished by the addition of a crescent placed beneath the bust. It was initially mostly silver, but was slowly debased, following the trend of the debasement of silver during the Severan dynasty (193-235), to bronze with a minimal silver content (see Pense, 1992). Elagabalus demonetised the antoninianus in 219 in favour of the denarius. The antoninianus was re-introduced in 238 by Gordian III who, in turn, saw to it intentionally or otherwise that the denarius would be phased out for good.

Rome remained the principal mint for the production of coinage throughout this reign, though in the minting of antoniniani it was assisted at various times by at least two, and possibly three, provincial mints. One of these was at Viminacium, an important city of the Danubian province of Upper Moesia, though the rare products of this mint have only recently been identified. Another mint was located at Antioch in Syria, though as under Gordian III the issues usually attributed to it fall into two distinct groups, one early (244-245), the other late (247-249). Stylistically these groups are quite different from one another, which has led some numismatists to believe that only the later group should be assigned to Antioch, whilst the earlier coinage should instead be given to the same uncertain eastern mint that had produced some of Gordian III's later coinage.

During the years 247 and 248 the "Saeculares" coinage struck to commemorate the millennium (1000th anniversary) of the foundation of Rome included the following reverse inscriptions: "SAECLARES AVGG" (the age of the Two Emperors), "SAECVLVM NOVVM" (the new age) and "MILIARIVM SAECVLVM" (the millenia). The "Saeculares" coinage is divided into two reverse series: the reverse animal series showing wild animals (with the inscription "SAECLARES AVGG" for all the denominations) and the reverse architectural series illustrating either a hexastyle temple (containing a seated statue of Roma) (with the inscription "SAECVLVM NOVVM" for the denominations in gold and silver and the inscription "SAECLARES AVGG" for the denominations in bronze) or a cippus (column) (with the inscription "SAECLARES AVGG" for all the denominations or the inscription "MILIARIVM SAECVLVM" for the denominations in bronze). The reverse animal series shows at least eight different wild animals: a lion, a she-wolf (suckling the twins Romulus and Remus), a gazelle, a European elk (moose), a hippopotamus, a stag, a goat (or hind), and an antelope. Struck in a wide range of denominations the series included the gold aureus, the silver antoninianius and quinarius, and the bronze sestertius, dupondius and as. Included also are issues of Otacilia Severa, wife of Philip (I) the Arab, and Philip (Il) the Younger, their son who had been raised to the rank of Augustus in 247.

The "Ludi Saeculares" (Secular Games) organised for the millennium of the foundation of Rome was highlighted by a splendid array of wild animals. These wild animals had originally been collected for the intended triumph of Gordian III in the Persian war, which saw his death and the associated proclamation of Philip (I) the Arab as emperor in 244. The animals were used by Philip (I) the Arab in magnificent displays and (slaughter) games put on in the key venues, like the Circus Maximus and the Colosseum. This large collection of exotic wild beasts included several specimens of antelope, elephant, European elk (moose), gazelle, giraffe, goat, hippopotamus, wild horse, hyena, leopard, lion, rhinoceros, stag, tiger and wild ass. It was these animals, collected for Gordian III, which, no doubt, inspired the many animal reverse types found on the "Saeculares" coinage struck to commemorate the millennium of the foundation of Rome. Besides, the she-wolf (suckling the twins Romulus and Remus) would have been recognised as the symbol of Rome rather than as a reminder of the games' arena.

A remarkable feature of this "Saeculares" coinage was the earliest appearance of officina (workshop) marks at the mint of Rome. The mint of Rome at this time was apparently divided into six officinae. These six officinae produced the "Saeculares" issue with marks as Roman numerals I to VI (only for the silver antoninianius) and are of much interest in that the eight animals illustrated on the reverse were divided among them with Officina I striking only the lion, II the lion and the she-wolf, III the gazelle and the European elk (moose), IV the hippopotamus, V the stag, and VI the goat (or hind) and the antelope. At almost the same time the same six officinae produced a different issue with marks as ancient Greek numerals Î‘ to ↅ (only for the silver antoninianius) rather than Roman numerals I to VI. Also, generally speaking, the six officinae were assigned to the production of issues in the name of a single imperial personage shown on the obverse: Officinae I/Î‘, II/Î’, V/Î• and VI/ↅ minted for Philip (I) the Arab, Officina III/Î“ minted for Philip (II) the Younger, and Officina IV/Î” minted for Otacilia Severa.

Although the practice of adding officina marks was not immediately adopted for succeeding issues, this development nevertheless marked an important numismatic turning point. Before long mint marks of increasing complexity began appearing not only on the issues of the mint of Rome itself, but also on those of the ever-expanding network of provincial mints.
Historical notes:

(Marcus Julius) Philippus (born circa 204; proclaimed emperor circa late February 244; died in September 249)

(To the right) Bust of Philip (I) the Arab, sculpted by an unknown artist between 244 and 249, displayed in the State Hermitage Museum in Saint Petersburg

Marcus Julius Philippus, a native of Arabia Trachonitis, was born about 204 and was the son of an Arab chieftain named Marinus (?-?) who had attained Roman equestrian rank. Philip (I) the Arab, as he became known, held a high command in the Roman army during the Persian campaign of his predecessor (Marcus Antonius) Gordianus (225-244; r. 238-244), known as Gordian III, and during the winter of 243-244 he became praetorian prefect in place of Gordian III's father-in-law (Gaius Furius Sabinius Aquila) Timesitheus (190-243), in whose sudden death he may have been implicated. It soon became clear that the new praetorian prefect had designs on the throne itself and he set about undermining the authority of the young Gordian III. By late February 244 he felt sufficiently secure to make his move and the unfortunate emperor was deposed by the army and put to death, Philip (I) the Arab being proclaimed in his place. Anxious to return to Rome as soon as possible he hastily negotiated a peace treaty with the Persian shahanshah Shapur I (?-270; r. circa 240-270) and assumed the title of "Persicus Maximus". His wife, (Marcia) Otacilia Severa (circa 220-in or after 249), was given the rank of Augusta and their young son, Philip (the Younger; about 237-249), became Caesar, both being granted a share in the imperial coinage. In further moves to strengthen the stability of his new dynasty Philip (I) the Arab appointed his brother (Gaius Julius) Priscus (?-?) to the governorship of Mesopotamia (later supreme commander in the East), and his father- (or brother-) in-law Severianus (?-?) to the governorship of Moesia. He even granted posthumous deification to his father Marinus and coins in honour of the new deity were struck at the recently established colony of Philippopolis in Arabia, probably the emperor's birthplace. Philip was back in Rome by the summer and received formal ratification of his accession from an obedient Senate. Much of the following two years was spent in campaigning on the northern frontier against the Dacian Carpi and the German Quadi and in 247 the emperor celebrated a triumph in Rome. The event was used as the setting for the further elevation of his son Philip (the Younger) to the status of Augustus and co-emperor. The following year magnificent games and other spectacles were staged in the capital in celebration of the millennium (1000th anniversary) of the foundation of Rome and the occasion was marked by an extensive issue of coinage in all metals. This was to be the high-point of Philip (I) the Arab's reign. Later in the year serious revolts broke out in Moesia, where the uprising was headed by (Tiberius Claudius Marcus) Pacatianus (?-circa 248), known as Pacatian, and in Cappadocia and northern Syria, where (Marcus Fulvius Rufus) Jotapianus (?-circa 249), known as Jotapian, was proclaimed emperor. Although neither rebellion was successful they were enough to undermine confidence in Philip (I) the Arab's ability to rule. When he sent his general (Gaius Messius Quintus Trajanus) Decius (circa 201-251), also known as Trajan Decius, to Moesia to settle the disturbed situation there the army proclaimed their commander emperor in his place. Although reputedly reluctant to accept the doubtful honour Decius nevertheless marched on Italy and met Philip (I) the Arab in battle at Verona. Philip (I) the Arab and his son Philip (II) the Younger were both killed in the disastrous defeat and Decius was left in uncontested possession of the imperial throne in September 249. The tradition has come down to us that Philip (I) the Arab had strong Christian sympathies. However, this may be due to nothing more than the stark contrast between his tolerant attitude in religious matters and the cruel persecutions of his successor, Decius.

The silver denarius, though still occasionally minted under Philip (I) the Arab, was no longer part of the regular monetary system and specimens today are of considerable rarity. It was replaced as the principal denomination by the antoninianus. Gold coinage was also much rarer than under Gordian III, but sestertii continued to be issued in large quantities. In addition to coinage in the name of Philip (I) the Arab himself, issues were made in the names of his son Philip (II) the Younger (as Caesar until 247, thereafter as Augustus) and his wife Otacilia Severa.

â†’ Collection thÃ©matique â€“ Les ateliers monÃ©taires romains en 247-248 :

+ AD 0248 - Roman Empire - Antoninianus - Philip (I) the Arab:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Empire (-27-395); Crisis of the Third Century (235-284)
Ruler: Philip (I) the Arab (244-249)
Type: Regular issue; Collection thÃ©matique â€“ Les ateliers monÃ©taires romains en 247-248
Obverse:

Design: Bust of Philip (I) the Arab, facing right, radiate, draped, cuirassed (RIC "Type B")
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) IMPPHILIPPVSAVG (IMP PHILIPPVS AVG)
Traduction: Supreme military commander (Imperator), Philippus, Emperor (Augustus) (Imperator Philippus Augustus)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Mars (Roman god of war) standing left, on a base, holding an olive branch in the right hand, resting the left hand on a shield, a spear propped against the left arm, the officina mark (Î‘) in the field to the left
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 07h) PMTRPVCOSIIIPP (P M TR P COS III PP)
Traduction: Greatest of the Pontifices, holder of tribunician power, consul for the third time, father of the country (Pontifex Maximus, Tribunicia Potestate, Consul Tertium, Pater Patriae)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin will be sent to NGC for grading. The grade that I expect it will receive is Ch AU; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 4/5.

This coin makes me think of my son Louis. ğŸ¦“

This coin is a "gift" from my son Louis, my mother GeneviÃ¨ve, and my sister Marie, for Christmas 2025. ğŸ¦“ğŸğŸ¦¦
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (â†º, 08h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R Material: Silver
Year: 248 (not dated) Fineness: 466
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 4.04; Expected: 3.9
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 23
Unit: Antoninianus (Reform of Caracalla; 215-301) Thickness (mm): -
Mint: Roma Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 248
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients Ch AU; Strike: 5/5; Surface: 4/5 (CCN) Variety: None
References: RIC4_3#7; RCV3#8949; RSC4#145; Cohen5#145; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.4.ph_i.7; MRK#74.19
Varieties:

None
Note:

In 215 Caracalla reformed the monetary system to finance ever increasing imperial expenditures by introducing the antoninianus, named after Caracalla's official name "Antoninus". The newly introduced antoninianus had the same silver purity as the denarius (51.5%) but weighed 5.1 g, compared to 3.23 g for the denarius. Although its silver content was only equivalent to about one and a half denarii, the antoninianus was apparently officially tariffed as the equivalent of two. For this reason, it is sometimes referred to as "double-denarius". This new coin always shows the emperor wearing the radiate crown instead of the laurel wreath of the denarius. In the case of empresses, the coin is distinguished by the addition of a crescent placed beneath the bust. It was initially mostly silver, but was slowly debased, following the trend of the debasement of silver during the Severan dynasty (193-235), to bronze with a minimal silver content (see Pense, 1992). Elagabalus demonetised the antoninianus in 219 in favour of the denarius. The antoninianus was re-introduced in 238 by Gordian III who, in turn, saw to it intentionally or otherwise that the denarius would be phased out for good.

Rome remained the principal mint for the production of coinage throughout this reign, though in the minting of antoniniani it was assisted at various times by at least two, and possibly three, provincial mints. One of these was at Viminacium, an important city of the Danubian province of Upper Moesia, though the rare products of this mint have only recently been identified. Another mint was located at Antioch in Syria, though as under Gordian III the issues usually attributed to it fall into two distinct groups, one early (244-245), the other late (247-249). Stylistically these groups are quite different from one another, which has led some numismatists to believe that only the later group should be assigned to Antioch, whilst the earlier coinage should instead be given to the same uncertain eastern mint that had produced some of Gordian III's later coinage.

A remarkable feature of Philip (I) the Arab's coinage was the earliest appearance of officina (workshop) marks at the mint of Rome. The mint of Rome at this time was apparently divided into six officinae. These six officinae produced at almost the same time in 248 the reverse animal series of the "Saeculares" issue, showing wild animals (with the inscription "SAECLARES AVGG"), with marks as Roman numerals I to VI (only for the silver antoninianius), and a different series of a different issue, more banal and following a familiar Greco-Roman iconographic tradition, with marks as ancient Greek numerals Î‘ to ↅ (only for the silver antoninianius) rather than Roman numerals I to VI. Both series were struck in a wide range of denominations, including the gold aureus, the silver antoninianius and quinarius, and the bronze sestertius, dupondius and as. Also, generally speaking, the six officinae were assigned to the production of issues in the name of a single imperial personage shown on the obverse: Officinae I/Î‘, II/Î’, V/Î• and VI/ↅ minted for Philip (I) the Arab, Officina IV/Î” minted for Otacilia Severa, wife of Philip (I) the Arab, and Officina III/Î“ minted for Philip (II) the Younger, their son who had been raised to the rank of Augustus in 247.

Although the practice of adding officina marks was not immediately adopted for succeeding issues, this development nevertheless marked an important numismatic turning point. Before long mint marks of increasing complexity began appearing not only on the issues of the mint of Rome itself, but also on those of the ever-expanding network of provincial mints.
Historical notes:

(Marcus Julius) Philippus (born circa 204; proclaimed emperor circa late February 244; died in September 249)

(To the top right) Bust of Philip (I) the Arab, sculpted by an unknown artist between 244 and 249, displayed in the State Hermitage Museum in Saint Petersburg

Marcus Julius Philippus, a native of Arabia Trachonitis, was born about 204 and was the son of an Arab chieftain named Marinus (?-?) who had attained Roman equestrian rank. Philip (I) the Arab, as he became known, held a high command in the Roman army during the Persian campaign of his predecessor (Marcus Antonius) Gordianus (225-244; r. 238-244), known as Gordian III, and during the winter of 243-244 he became praetorian prefect in place of Gordian III's father-in-law (Gaius Furius Sabinius Aquila) Timesitheus (190-243), in whose sudden death he may have been implicated. It soon became clear that the new praetorian prefect had designs on the throne itself and he set about undermining the authority of the young Gordian III. By late February 244 he felt sufficiently secure to make his move and the unfortunate emperor was deposed by the army and put to death, Philip (I) the Arab being proclaimed in his place. Anxious to return to Rome as soon as possible he hastily negotiated a peace treaty with the Persian shahanshah Shapur I (?-270; r. circa 240-270) and assumed the title of "Persicus Maximus". His wife, (Marcia) Otacilia Severa (circa 220-in or after 249), was given the rank of Augusta and their young son, Philip (the Younger; about 237-249), became Caesar, both being granted a share in the imperial coinage. In further moves to strengthen the stability of his new dynasty Philip (I) the Arab appointed his brother (Gaius Julius) Priscus (?-?) to the governorship of Mesopotamia (later supreme commander in the East), and his father- (or brother-) in-law Severianus (?-?) to the governorship of Moesia. He even granted posthumous deification to his father Marinus and coins in honour of the new deity were struck at the recently established colony of Philippopolis in Arabia, probably the emperor's birthplace. Philip was back in Rome by the summer and received formal ratification of his accession from an obedient Senate. Much of the following two years was spent in campaigning on the northern frontier against the Dacian Carpi and the German Quadi and in 247 the emperor celebrated a triumph in Rome. The event was used as the setting for the further elevation of his son Philip (the Younger) to the status of Augustus and co-emperor. The following year magnificent games and other spectacles were staged in the capital in celebration of the millennium (1000th anniversary) of the foundation of Rome and the occasion was marked by an extensive issue of coinage in all metals. This was to be the high-point of Philip (I) the Arab's reign. Later in the year serious revolts broke out in Moesia, where the uprising was headed by (Tiberius Claudius Marcus) Pacatianus (?-circa 248), known as Pacatian, and in Cappadocia and northern Syria, where (Marcus Fulvius Rufus) Jotapianus (?-circa 249), known as Jotapian, was proclaimed emperor. Although neither rebellion was successful they were enough to undermine confidence in Philip (I) the Arab's ability to rule. When he sent his general (Gaius Messius Quintus Trajanus) Decius (circa 201-251), also known as Trajan Decius, to Moesia to settle the disturbed situation there the army proclaimed their commander emperor in his place. Although reputedly reluctant to accept the doubtful honour Decius nevertheless marched on Italy and met Philip (I) the Arab in battle at Verona. Philip (I) the Arab and his son Philip (II) the Younger were both killed in the disastrous defeat and Decius was left in uncontested possession of the imperial throne in September 249. The tradition has come down to us that Philip (I) the Arab had strong Christian sympathies. However, this may be due to nothing more than the stark contrast between his tolerant attitude in religious matters and the cruel persecutions of his successor, Decius.

The silver denarius, though still occasionally minted under Philip (I) the Arab, was no longer part of the regular monetary system and specimens today are of considerable rarity. It was replaced as the principal denomination by the antoninianus. Gold coinage was also much rarer than under Gordian III, but sestertii continued to be issued in large quantities. In addition to coinage in the name of Philip (I) the Arab himself, issues were made in the names of his son Philip (II) the Younger (as Caesar until 247, thereafter as Augustus) and his wife Otacilia Severa.

(To the bottom right) Photography of Dieter Widhalm (1943-Present), taken by an anonym

Dieter Widhalm was born on 9 September 1943 in Nikolsburg (now Mikulov) in South Moravia, then occupied by the Greater German Reich. His father was an administrative clerk at Nikolsburg Castle, the ancestral castle of the Princes of Dietrichstein. On 30 April 1945, the Wehrmacht evacuated Nikolsburg and Czech forces took control of the town. These were very difficult times for the German population, and so in the spring of 1946, the family fled to Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg. They found accommodation in emergency housing in Fellbach until they were finally allocated an apartment in Waiblingen. After attending elementary and secondary school in Waiblingen, Dieter Widhalm attended a business school in Stuttgart from 1963, graduating with an intermediate diploma, and studied at the Friedrich-Alexander University in Nuremberg from 1967 to 1971. There he graduated with a degree in business education, and in 1971 joined the teaching staff at a business school in Stuttgart, where he worked as a senior teacher until his retirement in 2006.

Dieter Widhalm was already interested in coins during his school days. When he was 9-year old, in 1952, his mother received a 5-mark Germanisches Museum coin as change in a grocery store. It happened that he had previously read an article in the Waiblinger Zeitung newspaper about this first commemorative coin of the Federal Republic of Germany. This coin was his first collector's coin. Shortly afterwards, he was able to purchase a small book for 5 marks at a charity bazaar organised by his Catholic parish: "Introduction to the Numismatics of the Roman Empire". That was what got him into (Roman) numismatics, and when the word got around in Waiblingen that Roman coins had been found at a large demolition site there, he went to the construction site after work and found several Roman coins. While still a schoolboy, he took his treasures to the coin cabinet of the WÃ¼rttemberg State Museum at the Old Palace in Stuttgart to have them examined. Dr. Elisabeth Nau, then director of the coin cabinet, welcomed him warmly and was extremely helpful, answering all his questions.

On 5 December 1967, Dieter Widhalm came across an advertisement in the newspaper announcing a coin auction by the coin dealer H. H. Kricheldorf in Stuttgart the following day. He immediately made his way to the company's Stuttgart office in the Marquardtbau (German for Marquardt Building) and purchased his first auction catalogue. The following day, at the auction in the Hotel am Schlossgarten, he purchased an antoninianus of Emperor Philip II for a hammer price of 32 marks, plus a buyer premium. During his studies in Nuremberg, he added a second area of interest to his coin collection: small coins from the imperial city of Nuremberg from the 16th century to 1807. He also became a member of the WÃ¼rttemberg Coin Association, chaired by Dr. Elisabeth Nau. Today, he is the oldest member of this association and got to know numerous dedicated coin collectors there. He learned a great deal from them and broadened not only his horizons but also his areas of interest. In 1976, Dieter Widhalm published a paper on "The Nuremberg lamb ducat coinage from 1632 to 1806" in the BeitrÃ¤ge zur SÃ¼ddeutschen MÃ¼nzgeschichte, published by the association, which is still cited today. He subsequently gave several interesting presentations at the monthly members' meetings and was always present at the cosy get-togethers of the members in a nearby pub.

Following in the footsteps of his family roots, Dieter Widhalm also collected coins and medals belonging to the Counts and Princes of Dietrichstein. Another area of his collection was the silver baroque medals by Philipp Heinrich MÃ¼ller (1654-1719), with the edge signed by Friedrich Kleinert (1633-1714) from Nuremberg, who issued them. The series of these medals that he assembled is unsurpassed in terms of completeness, at least in private collections. Dieter Widhalm added to his collection medals by Konrad Lange (1806-1856), who came from Geislingen an der Steige. This artist, trained by Carl (Friedrich) Voigt (1800-1874) in Munich, worked in Munich, Athens and Vienna and created magnificent medals based on classicism. As Dieter Widhalm developed interest in minting technology, he began to collect coins and medals produced using different minting processes. His interest in river gold panning is also particularly noteworthy. For years, he spent his holidays in the Salzburg region and established close contacts with the gold panners on the Salzach river. Over the years he acquired a considerable amount of river gold granules, and in 1989 he had a medal minted as a klippe (with a square flan) using round dies, which he designed himself.

Despite all these areas of collecting, Dieter Widhalm never lost sight of his beloved Roman coins from the late imperial period. He was particularly fond of the Severan dynasty and the Constantinian dynasty. Later, he expanded his collection to include gold coins of the Byzantine Empire.

As of late 2025, Stefan Sonntag, who runs the auction house Auktionen MÃ¼nzhandlung Sonntag, has known and appreciated Dieter Widhalm for over 50 years, and has learned a great deal from him. It was therefore an honour and a duty for him to present his extraordinary and beautiful collection in a dedicated auction on 3rd December 2025 (Auction 45: The Dieter Widhalm Collection). Dieter Widhalm has been in a care home in Lauffen am Neckar since 2023 and Stefan Sonntag has been looking after him since then.

+ AD 0248 - Roman Empire - Antoninianus - Philip (Il) the Younger, son of Philip (I) the Arab and Otacilia Severa:

References: RIC4_3#223; RCV3#9277; RSC4#88; Cohen5#88; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.4.ph_i.223; MRK#76.22
Varieties:

None
Note:

In 215 Caracalla reformed the monetary system to finance ever increasing imperial expenditures by introducing the antoninianus, named after Caracalla's official name "Antoninus". The newly introduced antoninianus had the same silver purity as the denarius (51.5%) but weighed 5.1 g, compared to 3.23 g for the denarius. Although its silver content was only equivalent to about one and a half denarii, the antoninianus was apparently officially tariffed as the equivalent of two. For this reason, it is sometimes referred to as "double-denarius". This new coin always shows the emperor wearing the radiate crown instead of the laurel wreath of the denarius. In the case of empresses, the coin is distinguished by the addition of a crescent placed beneath the bust. It was initially mostly silver, but was slowly debased, following the trend of the debasement of silver during the Severan dynasty (193-235), to bronze with a minimal silver content (see Pense, 1992). Elagabalus demonetised the antoninianus in 219 in favour of the denarius. The antoninianus was re-introduced in 238 by Gordian III who, in turn, saw to it intentionally or otherwise that the denarius would be phased out for good.

Rome remained the principal mint for the production of coinage throughout this reign, though in the minting of antoniniani it was assisted at various times by at least two, and possibly three, provincial mints. One of these was at Viminacium, an important city of the Danubian province of Upper Moesia, though the rare products of this mint have only recently been identified. Another mint was located at Antioch in Syria, though as under Gordian III the issues usually attributed to it fall into two distinct groups, one early (244-245), the other late (247-249). Stylistically these groups are quite different from one another, which has led some numismatists to believe that only the later group should be assigned to Antioch, whilst the earlier coinage should instead be given to the same uncertain eastern mint that had produced some of Gordian III's later coinage.

A remarkable feature of Philip (I) the Arab's coinage was the earliest appearance of officina (workshop) marks at the mint of Rome. The mint of Rome at this time was apparently divided into six officinae. These six officinae produced at almost the same time in 248 the reverse animal series of the "Saeculares" issue, showing wild animals (with the inscription "SAECLARES AVGG"), with marks as Roman numerals I to VI (only for the silver antoninianius), and a different series of a different issue, more banal and following a familiar Greco-Roman iconographic tradition, with marks as ancient Greek numerals Î‘ to ↅ (only for the silver antoninianius) rather than Roman numerals I to VI. Both series were struck in a wide range of denominations, including the gold aureus, the silver antoninianius and quinarius, and the bronze sestertius, dupondius and as. Also, generally speaking, the six officinae were assigned to the production of issues in the name of a single imperial personage shown on the obverse: Officinae I/Î‘, II/Î’, V/Î• and VI/ↅ minted for Philip (I) the Arab, Officina IV/Î” minted for Otacilia Severa, wife of Philip (I) the Arab, and Officina III/Î“ minted for Philip (II) the Younger, their son who had been raised to the rank of Augustus in 247.

Although the practice of adding officina marks was not immediately adopted for succeeding issues, this development nevertheless marked an important numismatic turning point. Before long mint marks of increasing complexity began appearing not only on the issues of the mint of Rome itself, but also on those of the ever-expanding network of provincial mints.
Historical notes:

Marcus Julius Severus Philippus (born about 237; given the title of Augustus in 247; died in 249)

(To the right) Bust of Philip (II) the Younger, sculpted by an unknown artist between 247 and 249, displayed in the MusÃ©e Saint-Raymond in Toulouse

Philip (II) the Younger, the son of Philip (I) the Arab (circa 204-249; r. 244-249) and Otacilia Severa (circa 220-in or after 249), was born about 237, that is about seven years before his father's accession as Emperor in 244. On his father's accession as Emperor in 244, he was immediately granted the junior imperial rank of Caesar and this he retained for the following three years. He seems to have accompanied his father during the campaigns of 245-247 against the Quadi and the Carpi on the northern frontier and on their return to Rome to celebrate a triumph the boy was rewarded by advancement to the rank of Augustus and co-emperor with his father. When their regime was threatened two years later in 249 by the revolt of (Gaius Messius Quintus Trajanus) Decius (circa 201-251), also known as Trajan Decius, the father and son marched together against the usurper, only to perish in battle at Verona. An alternative version of the story is that Philip (II) the Younger survived the battle but was brought back to Rome where he was put to death by the Praetorians.

The coinage of Philip (II) the Younger is divided into two main groups, those issued berween 244 and 247, when he bore the title of Caesar, and those issued after his elevation to the rank of Augustus. The former are all from the mint of Rome, but after he became co-emperor with his father he also shared in the issue of antoniniani from the mint of Antioch. During this latter period he used the same obverse legends as his father and differentiation on some issues from the mint of Antioch may sometimes be confusing, though the younger features of his portrait are generally discernible. Like his mother, Philip (II) the Younger was assigned one of the six officinae (workshops) of the Rome mint to produce issues in his name.

+ AD 0248 - Roman Empire - Antoninianus - Philip (I) the Arab:

Open description in new window
Period: Antiquity; Roman Empire (-27-395); Crisis of the Third Century (235-284)
Ruler: Philip (I) the Arab (244-249)

References: RIC4_3#8; RCV3#8938; RSC4#98; Cohen5#98; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.4.ph_i.8; MRK#74.14
Varieties:

None
Note:

In 215 Caracalla reformed the monetary system to finance ever increasing imperial expenditures by introducing the antoninianus, named after Caracalla's official name "Antoninus". The newly introduced antoninianus had the same silver purity as the denarius (51.5%) but weighed 5.1 g, compared to 3.23 g for the denarius. Although its silver content was only equivalent to about one and a half denarii, the antoninianus was apparently officially tariffed as the equivalent of two. For this reason, it is sometimes referred to as "double-denarius". This new coin always shows the emperor wearing the radiate crown instead of the laurel wreath of the denarius. In the case of empresses, the coin is distinguished by the addition of a crescent placed beneath the bust. It was initially mostly silver, but was slowly debased, following the trend of the debasement of silver during the Severan dynasty (193-235), to bronze with a minimal silver content (see Pense, 1992). Elagabalus demonetised the antoninianus in 219 in favour of the denarius. The antoninianus was re-introduced in 238 by Gordian III who, in turn, saw to it intentionally or otherwise that the denarius would be phased out for good.

Rome remained the principal mint for the production of coinage throughout this reign, though in the minting of antoniniani it was assisted at various times by at least two, and possibly three, provincial mints. One of these was at Viminacium, an important city of the Danubian province of Upper Moesia, though the rare products of this mint have only recently been identified. Another mint was located at Antioch in Syria, though as under Gordian III the issues usually attributed to it fall into two distinct groups, one early (244-245), the other late (247-249). Stylistically these groups are quite different from one another, which has led some numismatists to believe that only the later group should be assigned to Antioch, whilst the earlier coinage should instead be given to the same uncertain eastern mint that had produced some of Gordian III's later coinage.

A remarkable feature of Philip (I) the Arab's coinage was the earliest appearance of officina (workshop) marks at the mint of Rome. The mint of Rome at this time was apparently divided into six officinae. These six officinae produced at almost the same time in 248 the reverse animal series of the "Saeculares" issue, showing wild animals (with the inscription "SAECLARES AVGG"), with marks as Roman numerals I to VI (only for the silver antoninianius), and a different series of a different issue, more banal and following a familiar Greco-Roman iconographic tradition, with marks as ancient Greek numerals Î‘ to ↅ (only for the silver antoninianius) rather than Roman numerals I to VI. Both series were struck in a wide range of denominations, including the gold aureus, the silver antoninianius and quinarius, and the bronze sestertius, dupondius and as. Also, generally speaking, the six officinae were assigned to the production of issues in the name of a single imperial personage shown on the obverse: Officinae I/Î‘, II/Î’, V/Î• and VI/ↅ minted for Philip (I) the Arab, Officina IV/Î” minted for Otacilia Severa, wife of Philip (I) the Arab, and Officina III/Î“ minted for Philip (II) the Younger, their son who had been raised to the rank of Augustus in 247.

Although the practice of adding officina marks was not immediately adopted for succeeding issues, this development nevertheless marked an important numismatic turning point. Before long mint marks of increasing complexity began appearing not only on the issues of the mint of Rome itself, but also on those of the ever-expanding network of provincial mints.
Historical notes:

(Marcus Julius) Philippus (born circa 204; proclaimed emperor circa late February 244; died in September 249)

(To the top right) Bust of Philip (I) the Arab, sculpted by an unknown artist between 244 and 249, displayed in the State Hermitage Museum in Saint Petersburg

Marcus Julius Philippus, a native of Arabia Trachonitis, was born about 204 and was the son of an Arab chieftain named Marinus (?-?) who had attained Roman equestrian rank. Philip (I) the Arab, as he became known, held a high command in the Roman army during the Persian campaign of his predecessor (Marcus Antonius) Gordianus (225-244; r. 238-244), known as Gordian III, and during the winter of 243-244 he became praetorian prefect in place of Gordian III's father-in-law (Gaius Furius Sabinius Aquila) Timesitheus (190-243), in whose sudden death he may have been implicated. It soon became clear that the new praetorian prefect had designs on the throne itself and he set about undermining the authority of the young Gordian III. By late February 244 he felt sufficiently secure to make his move and the unfortunate emperor was deposed by the army and put to death, Philip (I) the Arab being proclaimed in his place. Anxious to return to Rome as soon as possible he hastily negotiated a peace treaty with the Persian shahanshah Shapur I (?-270; r. circa 240-270) and assumed the title of "Persicus Maximus". His wife, (Marcia) Otacilia Severa (circa 220-in or after 249), was given the rank of Augusta and their young son, Philip (the Younger; about 237-249), became Caesar, both being granted a share in the imperial coinage. In further moves to strengthen the stability of his new dynasty Philip (I) the Arab appointed his brother (Gaius Julius) Priscus (?-?) to the governorship of Mesopotamia (later supreme commander in the East), and his father- (or brother-) in-law Severianus (?-?) to the governorship of Moesia. He even granted posthumous deification to his father Marinus and coins in honour of the new deity were struck at the recently established colony of Philippopolis in Arabia, probably the emperor's birthplace. Philip was back in Rome by the summer and received formal ratification of his accession from an obedient Senate. Much of the following two years was spent in campaigning on the northern frontier against the Dacian Carpi and the German Quadi and in 247 the emperor celebrated a triumph in Rome. The event was used as the setting for the further elevation of his son Philip (the Younger) to the status of Augustus and co-emperor. The following year magnificent games and other spectacles were staged in the capital in celebration of the millennium (1000th anniversary) of the foundation of Rome and the occasion was marked by an extensive issue of coinage in all metals. This was to be the high-point of Philip (I) the Arab's reign. Later in the year serious revolts broke out in Moesia, where the uprising was headed by (Tiberius Claudius Marcus) Pacatianus (?-circa 248), known as Pacatian, and in Cappadocia and northern Syria, where (Marcus Fulvius Rufus) Jotapianus (?-circa 249), known as Jotapian, was proclaimed emperor. Although neither rebellion was successful they were enough to undermine confidence in Philip (I) the Arab's ability to rule. When he sent his general (Gaius Messius Quintus Trajanus) Decius (circa 201-251), also known as Trajan Decius, to Moesia to settle the disturbed situation there the army proclaimed their commander emperor in his place. Although reputedly reluctant to accept the doubtful honour Decius nevertheless marched on Italy and met Philip (I) the Arab in battle at Verona. Philip (I) the Arab and his son Philip (II) the Younger were both killed in the disastrous defeat and Decius was left in uncontested possession of the imperial throne in September 249. The tradition has come down to us that Philip (I) the Arab had strong Christian sympathies. However, this may be due to nothing more than the stark contrast between his tolerant attitude in religious matters and the cruel persecutions of his successor, Decius.

The silver denarius, though still occasionally minted under Philip (I) the Arab, was no longer part of the regular monetary system and specimens today are of considerable rarity. It was replaced as the principal denomination by the antoninianus. Gold coinage was also much rarer than under Gordian III, but sestertii continued to be issued in large quantities. In addition to coinage in the name of Philip (I) the Arab himself, issues were made in the names of his son Philip (II) the Younger (as Caesar until 247, thereafter as Augustus) and his wife Otacilia Severa.

(To the bottom right) Photography of Dieter Widhalm (1943-Present), taken by an anonym

Dieter Widhalm was born on 9 September 1943 in Nikolsburg (now Mikulov) in South Moravia, then occupied by the Greater German Reich. His father was an administrative clerk at Nikolsburg Castle, the ancestral castle of the Princes of Dietrichstein. On 30 April 1945, the Wehrmacht evacuated Nikolsburg and Czech forces took control of the town. These were very difficult times for the German population, and so in the spring of 1946, the family fled to Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg. They found accommodation in emergency housing in Fellbach until they were finally allocated an apartment in Waiblingen. After attending elementary and secondary school in Waiblingen, Dieter Widhalm attended a business school in Stuttgart from 1963, graduating with an intermediate diploma, and studied at the Friedrich-Alexander University in Nuremberg from 1967 to 1971. There he graduated with a degree in business education, and in 1971 joined the teaching staff at a business school in Stuttgart, where he worked as a senior teacher until his retirement in 2006.

Dieter Widhalm was already interested in coins during his school days. When he was 9-year old, in 1952, his mother received a 5-mark Germanisches Museum coin as change in a grocery store. It happened that he had previously read an article in the Waiblinger Zeitung newspaper about this first commemorative coin of the Federal Republic of Germany. This coin was his first collector's coin. Shortly afterwards, he was able to purchase a small book for 5 marks at a charity bazaar organised by his Catholic parish: "Introduction to the Numismatics of the Roman Empire". That was what got him into (Roman) numismatics, and when the word got around in Waiblingen that Roman coins had been found at a large demolition site there, he went to the construction site after work and found several Roman coins. While still a schoolboy, he took his treasures to the coin cabinet of the WÃ¼rttemberg State Museum at the Old Palace in Stuttgart to have them examined. Dr. Elisabeth Nau, then director of the coin cabinet, welcomed him warmly and was extremely helpful, answering all his questions.

On 5 December 1967, Dieter Widhalm came across an advertisement in the newspaper announcing a coin auction by the coin dealer H. H. Kricheldorf in Stuttgart the following day. He immediately made his way to the company's Stuttgart office in the Marquardtbau (German for Marquardt Building) and purchased his first auction catalogue. The following day, at the auction in the Hotel am Schlossgarten, he purchased an antoninianus of Emperor Philip II for a hammer price of 32 marks, plus a buyer premium. During his studies in Nuremberg, he added a second area of interest to his coin collection: small coins from the imperial city of Nuremberg from the 16th century to 1807. He also became a member of the WÃ¼rttemberg Coin Association, chaired by Dr. Elisabeth Nau. Today, he is the oldest member of this association and got to know numerous dedicated coin collectors there. He learned a great deal from them and broadened not only his horizons but also his areas of interest. In 1976, Dieter Widhalm published a paper on "The Nuremberg lamb ducat coinage from 1632 to 1806" in the BeitrÃ¤ge zur SÃ¼ddeutschen MÃ¼nzgeschichte, published by the association, which is still cited today. He subsequently gave several interesting presentations at the monthly members' meetings and was always present at the cosy get-togethers of the members in a nearby pub.

Following in the footsteps of his family roots, Dieter Widhalm also collected coins and medals belonging to the Counts and Princes of Dietrichstein. Another area of his collection was the silver baroque medals by Philipp Heinrich MÃ¼ller (1654-1719), with the edge signed by Friedrich Kleinert (1633-1714) from Nuremberg, who issued them. The series of these medals that he assembled is unsurpassed in terms of completeness, at least in private collections. Dieter Widhalm added to his collection medals by Konrad Lange (1806-1856), who came from Geislingen an der Steige. This artist, trained by Carl (Friedrich) Voigt (1800-1874) in Munich, worked in Munich, Athens and Vienna and created magnificent medals based on classicism. As Dieter Widhalm developed interest in minting technology, he began to collect coins and medals produced using different minting processes. His interest in river gold panning is also particularly noteworthy. For years, he spent his holidays in the Salzburg region and established close contacts with the gold panners on the Salzach river. Over the years he acquired a considerable amount of river gold granules, and in 1989 he had a medal minted as a klippe (with a square flan) using round dies, which he designed himself.

Despite all these areas of collecting, Dieter Widhalm never lost sight of his beloved Roman coins from the late imperial period. He was particularly fond of the Severan dynasty and the Constantinian dynasty. Later, he expanded his collection to include gold coins of the Byzantine Empire.

As of late 2025, Stefan Sonntag, who runs the auction house Auktionen MÃ¼nzhandlung Sonntag, has known and appreciated Dieter Widhalm for over 50 years, and has learned a great deal from him. It was therefore an honour and a duty for him to present his extraordinary and beautiful collection in a dedicated auction on 3rd December 2025 (Auction 45: The Dieter Widhalm Collection). Dieter Widhalm has been in a care home in Lauffen am Neckar since 2023 and Stefan Sonntag has been looking after him since then.

Le 27 dÃ©cembre 1958 l'institution du Â« nouveau franc Â», valant 100 Â« anciens francs Â», impliqua la crÃ©ation de types monÃ©taires nouveaux. La date d'entrÃ©e en circulation du Â« nouveau franc Â» fut fixÃ©e au 1er janvier 1960 par dÃ©cret le 18 novembre 1959. Le type des nouvelles piÃ¨ces de monnaie a Ã©tÃ© dÃ©terminÃ© par des arrÃªtÃ©s ministÃ©riels dont le premier est intervenu le 22 dÃ©cembre 1959. La semeuse conÃ§ue par Louis Oscar Roty (1846-1911) fut choisie pour se rattacher Ã  la stabilitÃ© du franc germinal du dÃ©but du XXÃ¨me siÃ¨cle, Ã  la fois sur les piÃ¨ces de 1 franc en nickel, de 2 francs en argent et de 5 francs en argent. La piÃ¨ce de 2 francs initialement prÃ©vue ne sera pas retenue. Les piÃ¨ces de 1 franc et 5 francs entrent en circulation au 1er janvier 1960. Le type des piÃ¨ces de 1 centime, 2 centimes et 5 centimes en acier inoxydable sera conforme au modÃ¨le exÃ©cutÃ© par l'atelier de gravure de l'administration des monnaies et mÃ©dailles, lequel fut chargÃ© de la crÃ©ation d'un nouveau type. Ce type, complÃ¨tement original, prÃ©sente un Ã©pi de blÃ© trÃ¨s sobre Ã  l'avers et des lÃ©gendes exclusivement en Ã©criture cursive. Un arrÃªtÃ© ministÃ©riel du 27 juillet 1961 a augmentÃ© lÃ©gÃ¨rement le module et le poids antÃ©rieurement prÃ©vus pour ces piÃ¨ces. La piÃ¨ce de 5 centimes entrent en circulation plus tard la mÃªme annÃ©e, alors que celle de 1 centime entre en circulation l'annÃ©e suivante en 1962. La piÃ¨ce de 2 centimes initialement prÃ©vue ne sera pas retenue. Le type des piÃ¨ces de 10 centimes, 20 centimes et 50 centimes en cupro-aluminium sera fixÃ© ultÃ©rieurement. Ce type fit l'objet d'un concours dont le cadre fut fixÃ© par arrÃªtÃ© ministÃ©riel le 29 octobre 1960. C'est finalement le travail mixte des graveurs en mÃ©dailles Henri Albert Lagriffoul (1907-1981) pour l'avers et Adrien DieudonnÃ© (1912-1982) pour le revers qui est choisi et ce type est fixÃ© par arrÃªtÃ© ministÃ©riel le 27 juillet 1961. L'avers exÃ©cutÃ© par Lagriffoul prÃ©sente la RÃ©publique, dite Â« Marianne Â», dont les mÃ¨ches de cheveux longs flottent hors du bonnet phrygien et dont le visage gracile correspond au canon esthÃ©tique contemporain. Un arrÃªtÃ© ministÃ©riel du 13 novembre 1961 a modifiÃ© l'alliage de ces piÃ¨ces, ajoutant au cupro-aluminium un faible apport en nickel dont les avantages s'Ã©taient rÃ©vÃ©lÃ©s lors des essais de frappe. Ce nouvel alliage offre l'avantage d'Ãªtre plus brillant et moins sujet Ã  se ternir. La fabrication des piÃ¨ces de 10, 20 et 50 centimes commence Ã  partir de 1962, mais elle n'est pas considÃ©rÃ©e comme prioritaire car ces piÃ¨ces ont des caractÃ©ristiques analogues Ã  celles de 10, 20 et 50 anciens francs. La nouvelle piÃ¨ce de 50 centimes avait un diamÃ¨tre plus rÃ©duit que la piÃ¨ce de 50 anciens francs qui Ã©tait assez grosse et encombrante. Cependant, sa similitude de type, de mÃ©tal et de diamÃ¨tre avec la piÃ¨ce de 20 centimes a posÃ© des problÃ¨mes d'utilisation. Il a alors Ã©tÃ© dÃ©cidÃ© en 1964 de la remplacer par une piÃ¨ce de 1/2 franc de type Â« Semeuse Â». Afin de la diffÃ©rencier de la piÃ¨ce de 1 franc, un diamÃ¨tre proche de la piÃ¨ce de 5 centimes de type Â« Ã‰pi Â» est nÃ©cessaire. Il faut alors changer la piÃ¨ce de 5 centimes de type Â« Ã‰pi Â» en une piÃ¨ce plus petite rentrant dans la sÃ©rie de type Â« Marianne Â». Un arrÃªtÃ© ministÃ©riel du 8 juin 1965 fixe les caracteÌristiques des nouvelles piÃ¨ces de 1/2 franc de type Â« Semeuse Â» et de 5 centimes de type Â« Marianne Â».

Cette monnaie est un piÃ©fort (ou pied-fort) en argent. Un piÃ©fort est un modÃ¨le de monnaie produite en peu d'exemplaires, au type d'une monnaie de frappe courante mais beaucoup plus Ã©paisse. Il a le plus souvent une Ã©paisseur double, mais occasionnellement triple ou quadruple, de la monnaie dÃ©finitive. Parfois, le modÃ¨le n'a pas Ã©tÃ© retenu pour une frappe courante, et il peut porter ou pas la mention Â« Essai Â». Le piÃ©fort est souvent produit en plusieurs mÃ©taux courants ou nobles. Autrefois, le piÃ©fort Ã©tait destinÃ© Ã  Ãªtre transmis comme un modÃ¨le aux ateliers monÃ©taires, ou bien Ã  Ãªtre prÃ©sentÃ© Ã  des dignitaires. De nos jours, toujours produit, il prend une valeur de prestige et d'objet de collection, au mÃªme titre que les essais, les monnaies frappÃ©es en qualitÃ© supÃ©rieure Â« Brillant Universel Â» (Â« Brilliant Uncirculated Â» en anglais) ou Â« Belle Ã‰preuve Â» (Â« Proof Â» en anglais), et les monnaies issues de sÃ©ries Â« Fleur de Coin Â» rassemblant des exemplaires numismatiques de l'ensemble des monnaies du mÃªme millÃ©sime. AprÃ¨s 1968, la plupart des piÃ©forts modernes ont Ã©tÃ© fabriquÃ©s de faÃ§on rÃ©guliÃ¨re et en parallÃ¨le Ã  chaque Ã©mission annuelle de monnaies de frappe courante, mais en trÃ¨s petite quantitÃ©. Pour cette monnaie de 5 centimes, dit Â« Marianne Â», il a Ã©tÃ© frappÃ© des piÃ©forts en or (920â€°), argent (950â€° de 1966 Ã  1973 et de 1985 Ã  1992, et 925â€° de 1974 Ã  1984) et cupro-aluminium au nickel, auxquels ont Ã©tÃ© attribuÃ©s des numÃ©ros de certification. Pour le millÃ©sime 1978, ont Ã©tÃ© frappÃ©s 150 exemplaires en or (dont 144 seulement furent vendus), 300 exemplaires en argent (dont 295 seulement furent vendus) et 150 exemplaires en cupro-aluminium au nickel (dont 148 seulement furent vendus). Les coins spÃ©ciaux ayant servi Ã  la frappe de ces piÃ©forts ont Ã©tÃ© biffÃ©s en prÃ©sence des agents de contrÃ´le.

Ce piÃ©fort de 5 centimes, dit Â« Marianne Â» en or a Ã©tÃ© frappÃ© en qualitÃ© Â« Belle Ã‰preuve Â». Â« Ã‰preuve Â» se traduit en anglais par Â« Proof Â» (PF). Les coins de frappe de ces Ã©preuves sont spÃ©cialement prÃ©parÃ©s de sorte que le champ est rÃ©flÃ©chissant comme un miroir et que le relief apparaÃ®t plus ou moins Â« givrÃ© Â» (mat), ou inversement pour certaines piÃ¨ces. L'aspect Â« grivrÃ© Â» du relief des Ã©preuves est obtenu en traitant les coins de frappe pour leur donner une texture, par exemple par sablage. La partie des coins de frappe correspondant au champ est polie pour donner au champ des Ã©preuves un effet de miroir. Il est Ã  noter que le relief des Ã©preuves prÃ©sentent des degrÃ©s variables de Â« givrage Â» du relief et de l'effet de miroir du champ. Comme les coins de frappe sont utilisÃ©s Ã  plusieurs reprises lors de la production de piÃ¨ces, l'aspect Â« grivrÃ© Â» du relief et l'effet de miroir du champ des Ã©preuves peuvent s'estomper. Les sociÃ©tÃ©s Numismatic Guaranty Company (NGC) et Professional Coin Grading Service (PCGS) utilise des dÃ©signations pour dÃ©crire le degrÃ© de Â« grivrage Â» du relief des Ã©preuves uniquement si les deux faces des ces piÃ¨ces sont concernÃ©es : Cameo (CAMEO pour NGC et CAM pour PCGS) pour un Â« givrage Â» lÃ©ger Ã  modÃ©rÃ©, et Ultra Cameo (ULTRA CAMEO) pour NGC et Deep Cameo (DCAM) pour PCGS pour un Â« givrage Â» prononcÃ©.

Le type des nouvelles piÃ¨ces de monnaie a Ã©tÃ© dÃ©terminÃ© par des arrÃªtÃ©s ministÃ©riels dont le premier est intervenu le 22 dÃ©cembre 1959. La piÃ¨ce de 2 francs initialement prÃ©vue ne sera pas retenue. Les piÃ¨ces de 1 franc et 5 francs entrent en circulation au 1er janvier 1960. Le type des piÃ¨ces de 1 centime, 2 centimes et 5 centimes en acier inoxydable sera conforme au modÃ¨le exÃ©cutÃ© par l'atelier de gravure de l'administration des monnaies et mÃ©dailles, lequel fut chargÃ© de la crÃ©ation d'un nouveau type. La piÃ¨ce de 5 centimes entrent en circulation plus tard la mÃªme annÃ©e, alors que celle de 1 centime entre en circulation l'annÃ©e suivante en 1962. La piÃ¨ce de 2 centimes initialement prÃ©vue ne sera pas retenue. Le type des piÃ¨ces de 10 centimes, 20 centimes et 50 centimes en cupro-aluminium sera fixÃ© ultÃ©rieurement. Ce type fit l'objet d'un concours dont le cadre fut fixÃ© par arrÃªtÃ© ministÃ©riel le 29 octobre 1960. C'est finalement le travail mixte des graveurs en mÃ©dailles Henri Albert Lagriffoul (1907-1981) pour l'avers et Adrien DieudonnÃ© (1912-1982) pour le revers qui est choisi et ce type est fixÃ© par arrÃªtÃ© ministÃ©riel le 27 juillet 1961. L'avers exÃ©cutÃ© par Lagriffoul prÃ©sente la RÃ©publique, dite Â« Marianne Â», dont les mÃ¨ches de cheveux longs flottent hors du bonnet phrygien et dont le visage gracile correspond au canon esthÃ©tique contemporain. Un arrÃªtÃ© ministÃ©riel du 13 novembre 1961 a modifiÃ© l'alliage de ces piÃ¨ces, ajoutant au cupro-aluminium un faible apport en nickel dont les avantages s'Ã©taient rÃ©vÃ©lÃ©s lors des essais de frappe. Ce nouvel alliage offre l'avantage d'Ãªtre plus brillant et moins sujet Ã  se ternir. La nouvelle piÃ¨ce de 50 centimes avait un diamÃ¨tre plus rÃ©duit que la piÃ¨ce de 50 anciens francs qui Ã©tait assez grosse et encombrante.
